DOC.HEAD: Paper Cites IG Report on Rapes at Navy Training Facility
DOC.TEXT: There were at least six rapes of female students or recruits at the Orlando Naval Training Center during the 18 months ending June 30, but the Navy has not prosecuted anyone for them, according to a published report. Citing a Navy inspector general's report it obtained Friday by request, The Washington Post said 24 rapes or sexual assaults were reported during the 18-month period and that Navy law enforcement officials ``substantiated or resolved'' eight of the rape cases and five instances of sexual assault -- including indecent exposure and attempted rape. The report in Monday's editions of the paper said only one of the 13 cases, an assault case, resulted in court-martial proceedings. The Post said the investigation found that some alleged offenders, often instructors of supervisors of the women involved, were returned to their jobs and continued working near the victims. It said others were transferred from Orlando or released from the Navy -- avoiding prosecution -- an that some victims may have been so intimidated by investigators that they did not press charges. The IG report was quoted as saying that the Navy's failure to move against offenders in numerous sex-related cases has contributed to an atmosphere at the Florida facility that makes women ``feel like they are second-class members of the Navy.'' The Post quoted Vice Adm. John S. Disher, the Navy's chief of education and training, as characterizing the problems cited at Orlando as occurring ``throughout the entire Navy'' and saying ``much more must be done'' to solve the problem. Rep. Beverley B. Byron, D-Md., chairman of the House Armed Services military personnel and compensation subcommittee, was quoted as blaming the problems at the training center on ``a breakdown in leadership and oversight of the leadership.'' The Post said she received a copy of the report under a Navy policy that requires such reviews to be provided to Congress 24 hours before they ar released to journalists. The paper quoted Vice Adm. Michael Boorda, the Navy's personnel chief, as saying: ``I've looked at the numbers. They certainly are not pleasing. But the problem is not being ignored. The training is being done and the people are aware of the problem. People are being found guilty and punished. Is the punishment fair or not fair? That is a personal judgment.''

DOC.HEAD: Gadhafi Gives Sudanese Rebels Ultimatum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES extraneous `he' in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi on Sunday threatened to throw his forces into the battle against anti-government rebels in Sudan unless the rebels end their revolt within a year. Gadhafi said he would attempt to persuade rebel leader John Garang - whose rebellion Gadhafi supported in the past - to suspend his seven-year fight now that Sudan has proposed adopting a Libyan-style government. But Gadhafi said Libya ``will have no option but to stand by the Sudanese people and government against Garang'' if a cease-fire is not reached by Oct. 21, 1991. The rebels operating in southern Sudan - mostly Christians and members of traditional African religions - are seeking economic and political reforms from the Moslem-dominated government and greater autonomy for three southern Sudanese provinces. Gadhafi's comments were made during the closing session of a six-week conference that recommended Sudan copy Libya's ``jamaheriya'' - or ``republic of the masses'' - system of local and provincial councils instead of elected officials. Military ruler Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, who led a coup last year to oust a civilian government, is expected to ratify the recommendations by the 1,000-member conference. Gadhafi, a principal advocate of a pan-Arab state, said Libya, Sudan and Egypt should forge a political and social union. ``Sudan, Egypt and Libya constitute the heart, the main body of the Arab nation, the movement of which control the movement of the other Arab states,'' said Gadhafi, whose speech was televised throughout Sudan. Egypt, which follows a parliamentary system, has rebuffed Gadhafi's earlier calls for unity. Gadhafi has unsuccessfully attempted to unify Libya with most Arab nations since taking power in 1969. He said peaceful rallies would be staged in all Arab countries beginning Jan. 1 to support pan-Arab unity. Libya has had close relations with Sudan since a 1985 uprising that overthrew the pro-U.S. President Gaafar Nimeiri. El-Bashir banned political parties and dismissed the elected parliament. Gadhafi admitted Libya trained and armed the rebel People's Liberation Army, but said he stopped assistance after Nimeiri's ouster.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Bargainers Narrow Differences on Gasoline Tax; Adjourn Until Monday
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 2nd graf, ``Congressional leakers xxx with talks ending for night; should stand
DOC.TEXT: Democrats and Republicans narrowed differences Sunday over new taxes on the rich, gasoline levies, and Medicare cuts, even as Bush administration officials angrily stalked out of deficit-reduction talks. Congressional leaders of both parties negotiated until about 11:30 p.m. Sunday over a $250 billion package of tax increases and spending cuts in agriculture, student loans and dozens of other programs. They said they would resume talking Monday. ``We've made good progress in many areas,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. But he conceded, ``The remaining areas of disagreement are important ones.'' Weekend bargaining saw the two sides move toward each other in several areas, including the question of how - and how high - to raise taxes on the rich. The talks proceeded on the eve of what lawmakers hoped would be Congress' last week before adjournment for the year. In the scant time left, House and Senate leaders say they would still like to tackle bills dealing with civil rights, air pollution and child care. Budget negotiators seemed willing to raise the income-tax rate on the wealthy to 31 percent, up from its current 28 percent. They were also close on proposals to limit the deductions the wealthiest taxpayers could claim. But Democrats were insisting on a 7.5 percent surtax on incomes exceeding $1 million annually. The proposal, if adopted, would allow Democrats to claim that rates on millionaires were raised substantially. ``We think it's good public policy and fair,'' said Mitchell. Republicans were adamantly against that idea, and instead wanted higher limitations on millionaires' deductions. White House Chief of Staff John Sununu accused Democrats of being too divided to respond to the latest GOP offer. ``We're not going to negotiate with Democrats who can't come to an agreement among themselves,'' he said as he left the Capitol with White House budget chief Richard Darman and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. ``This was a great offer.'' But Mitchell denied that, saying, ``I can say to you Democrats are unified.'' Despite the standoff over taxes, the two sides moved closer in other areas, said a Democratic congressional official who asked to not be identified. Democrats offered to raise the gasoline tax 5 cents above its current 9-cent-a-gallon level. Republicans were seeking a 7-cent increase. Democrats were offering to reduce Medicare by as much as $44 billion, $3 billion less than Republicans were demanding. In addition, Democrats were seeking to boost the $51,300 wage cap from which Medicare taxes are deducted to $125,000. Republicans want to increase the cap to $98,000. The 1.45 percent Medicare tax is part of the Social Security deduction. Republicans have been fearful of late that Democrats have made the tax-the-rich battle cry their own barely two weeks from Election Day. Earlier in the day, White House aides said higher levies on the rich were on the way. ``This is one of the all-time false issues, the rich-poor thing,'' said administration budget director Richard Darman. ``This compromise in the end will tax the rich.'' Working against a Wednesday deadline when stopgap spending authority expires, bargainers were trying to find middle ground between separate deficit-reduction plans approved by the House and Senate last week. The Senate bill - preferred by Bush - had more moderate tax increases on the wealthy, took a bigger bite out of Medicare spending and doubled the gasoline tax. ``We feel very strongly there should be a surcharge and a rate increase on higher-income levels,'' House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., told reporters. ``It's got to move in the direction of being fairer in terms of taxes, in other words, asking the wealthiest Americans to pay their fair share,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., who like Darman appeared on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' program. Darman said Bush would accept a 31 percent rate on the rich, up from 28 percent, if the rate on those slightly less well-off was reduced from 33 percent to 31 percent. That tradeoff, eliminating the so-called bubble, would increase taxes for 700,000 people and reduce them for 5 million others while raising an estimated $7 billion in additional revenue. But Mitchell said Democrats would not accept that offer alone. ``It obviously would have to be accompanied by other measures'' so people whose taxes were cut ``would be required to pay something to offset that reduction,'' Mitchell said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program. ``We're not hung up on any one formula, but rather the principle of fairness,'' Mitchell added. The Senate approved a bipartisan budget Friday shrinking the growth of Medicare by $49 billion over the next five years, including $17 billion to be directed at the elderly and handicapped served by the program. The House plan, which attracted only 10 GOP votes, limited those cuts to $43 billion, of which participants would bear $10 billion in reduced benefits and higher costs. The House would leave the 9-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax alone, while the Senate would raise it gradually to 18.5 cents. Democrats have conceded that the final compromise is likely to include some increase in the gasoline levy. They also have said another feature of the House bill likely will be dropped: a one-year delay in inflation adjustments on income-tax brackets and the personal exemption, which would have caused slight increases in the tax bills of everyone who pays income tax. Virtually certain to emerge in the final product are several other features the two bills had in common, including higher taxes on alcohol, tobacco, airline tickets and luxury items such as yachts and jewelry. Spending cuts would be administered to agriculture, student loan and veterans programs. The deficit-reduction bill combined with other savings - mainly defense cuts and reduced interest payments on the debt - would lower the deficit by $40 billion for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1 and $460 billion more over the next five years. The budget stalemate cost the government $1.6 million when agencies shut down over the Columbus Day weekend earlier in October, the General Accounting Office said in a report. The government had closed because in an effort to keep pressure on budget writers, Bush vetoed emergency spending legislation after federal authority to spend money had elapsed.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Re-Emerging as Issue in Campaigns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: After taking a back seat to worries about taxes, the economy and the Middle East, abortion is re-emerging as a potentially decisive issue in the final days of the 1990 election season. ``It's one of the few issues that's still out there that distinguishes people,'' said Harrison Hickman, a pollster for abortion-rights causes. ``I would predict you'll see a lot of people using it at the last minute to try to push undecided voters.'' Conventional political wisdom has held that abortion-rights candidates had the upper hand this year and that opponents of abortion were on the defensive after a 1989 Supreme Court ruling revived the issue. Electoral losses for abortion foes in 1989 contributed to that view. Yet abortion hasn't proven to be the ``silver bullet'' for abortion-rights candidates, in the words of Democrat Donald Avenson, a pro-choice candidate for Iowa governor. And abortion opponents point to races where their candidates have stood firm and are leading - including governor's races in Ohio, Pennsylvania, Texas and Iowa. ``It's not the issue some thought a year ago. On the other hand, it's more salient this year than it has been in the past in a lot of states,'' said Doug Johnson, legislative director for the National Right to Life Committee. As a result, some thought abortion was fizzling this year as an issue. But strategists for abortion-rights campaigns say there will be a flurry of last-minute advertising pushing the abortion issue. In some races it's already begun. Sometimes the push will be on television. But in other cases it will be more selectively targeted toward young women voters through direct-mail or telephone. ``People are thinking this is a dead issue. I think that's just a fundamental misunderstanding of this issue,'' said Celinda Lake, who has conducted polling for abortion-rights candidates around the country. ``It's a last-minute issue,'' she said. ``It's something you lay out in the last weeks of a campaign.'' Abortion-rights strategists say their target audience, younger voters, typically does not pay attention to campaigns until the final stages. Lake says polling shows that increasing economic worries and lack of trust of Democrats on the economy has caused a drop-off in support for Democrats among younger women, she said. Abortion may lure them back. ``It's a big drop off - 10 points,'' she said. ``Because of that you'll see more pro-choice direct-mail geared toward that audience at the end.'' In North Carolina's Senate race, both anti-abortion Sen. Jesse Helms and his Democratic challenger, Harvey Gantt, have been airing ads on the issue. But in most states, it's the abortion-rights candidates who have been using the issue in television ads. In Oregon, Democrat Harry Lonsdale has drawn even in his challenge to GOP Sen. Mark Hatfield, according to recent polls, after airing ads that attack Hatfield's opposition to abortion among other issues. One race where abortion hasn't been the factor that was expected is in Florida, where former Sen. Lawton Chiles is challenging GOP Gov. Robert Martinez, who opposes abortion. Chiles, who supports abortion rights, has found the issue uncomfortable for him and isn't airing ads despite Martinez' seeming vulnerability on the issue. The issue is important in Iowa's Senate race, where Democratic incumbent Tom Harkin has a double-digit lead over anti-abortion challenger Rep. Tom Tauke, according to recent polls. Harkin has been the abortion-rights point-man in the Senate, and he led the fight last week to oppose an amendment requiring teen-age girls to notify their parents before getting an abortion. Parental consent on abortion tends to gain strong support in most polls, but Harkin said the overall abortion issue helps him. ``The last thing my opponent wants to talk about is the choice issue,'' Harkin said. ``I'm watching my tracking polls ... and the number of people viewing his position as extreme is going like this,'' he added, pointing upward. The Senate adopted the parental consent provision on a 48-48 vote, but the amendment was expected to be deleted in later congressional action. Harkin's side was surprised it drew 48 votes. That vote has become an issue in California, where both candidates for governor are trying to appeal to abortion-rights supporters. Democratic candidate Dianne Feinstein blasted her GOP rival, Sen. Pete Wilson, for missing the vote while campaigning. Abortion opponents have the upper hand in several races. In Kansas, Democratic gubernatorial candidate Joan Finney has had difficulty explaining her anti-abortion position recently. But she still leads GOP Gov. Mike Hayden, an abortion-rights supporter, in the polls. Anti-abortion Republican George Voinovich has the lead in Ohio's governor race, where Democrat Anthony Celebrezze has been criticized for a startling flip-flop in which he dropped his long-standing opposition to abortion. A September poll by the University of Cincinnati found that the issue was helping Voinovich more than Celebrezze. Voinovich led among the 13 percent of respondents who said abortion was the single most important issue. In Iowa's governor's race, Democrat Avenson is running abortion-rights ads but has yet to catch up with anti-abortion GOP incumbent Terry Branstad. Abortion opponents in Idaho were angered by Gov. Cecil Andrus' veto of a restrictive abortion bill this year, but he is in strong shape in his re-election bid. It's become more of an issue in Idaho's Senate and House races, however. Idaho Republican Senate candidate Larry Craig surprised his anti-abortion supporters when he was asked in a debate what he would do if his wife became pregnant as a result of rape. He responded that it was her decision, which seemed at odds with his opposition to legal abortions. Democrat Ron Twilegar jumped on the response, saying he wanted all women to have that choice but Craig seemed to want it only for his wife. Craig says he was misinterpreted and hasn't strayed from his opposition to abortion. Abortion also is an issue in about a dozen congressional races. In northern Virginia, for example, Democrat James Moran is airing abortion-rights ads against GOP Rep. Stan Parris. Democrats see the issue helping Moran, the Alexandria mayor, since the district was won by Gov. Doug Wilder in an important abortion test last year.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Who Steered Souter to Court Sits Atop Ethics, Budget Battles
LaserPhoto NY305 of Oct. 18
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Warren Rudman was wearing a big smile and he didn't mind showing a guest the reason why. Walking to a tall window in his Senate office, the New Hampshire Republican pointed to the unremarkable looking U-Haul parked on the street below. ``See that truck,'' he said. ``That's David's belongings. His buddies in New Hampshire said, `We'll load it up for you and send it down.' And there it is.'' David, of course, is David Souter: the newest Supreme Court justice. As Souter's long-time friend and mentor, Rudman suggested that President Bush nominate him, then guided the protege through his Senate confirmation. But more than pride was behind that smile. There was relief. The truck was evidence Rudman was at last losing the houseguest he'd put up since the nation was introduced to David Souter on July 23. And he could use the break. Rudman, 60, a likeable second-term senator, has found himself caught in a swirl of major battles. Besides shepherding Souter through the Senate, he's been near the center of budget debates that bear his name. And he's the top Republican on the Senate Ethics Committee that is weighing the fate of five senators' involvement in the savings-and-loan scandals, a decision with enormous political potential. ``I'm just on the thin edge,'' Rudman said. ``It's been an unbelievable time. I'm ready to just go on top of a mountain in a log cabin. That's what I'm ready for. ``It's been a very intensive, satisfying in many ways, three months,'' he added. ``In some ways, it's been very unsatisfying.'' Rudman, a moderate Republican, was swept into office with Ronald Reagan in 1980. He unseated Democratic Sen. John Durkin, who four years earlier had blocked President Ford's appointment of Rudman to a top agency post. Rudman won the GOP nomination over a wide field that included John Sununu, who later became governor and now is Bush's chief of staff. Rudman is far more affable and far less ideological than Sununu. That Souter was Rudman's protege and not Sununu's was of intense comfort to many Democrats and in no small way eased his confirmation. Rudman is Jewish, and during the confirmation hearings Souter sought to display his sensitivity on civil rights by mentioning their private discussions of the discrimination Rudman has felt as a result of his religion. Souter and Rudman go back more than 20 years, when Rudman was attorney general of New Hampshire and Souter worked for him. Few brothers are closer, Rudman says. On his office wall are pictures chronicling the intertwined careers of Rudman and Souter and the other member of their trio, Tom Rath, a New Hampshire lawyer and Republican activist. ``It was incredible - very satisfying to me,'' Rudman said. ``After all, he's one of my closest friends, very, very close. He's someone who I set on his path 20-some-odd years ago. I told him he ought to be a judge. To watch him being sworn in was just enormously satisfying to me.'' Less satisfying, he says, is the crisis over the budget. He is the Rudman of Gramm-Rudman, a law written with Sens. Phil Gramm of Texas and Ernest Hollings of South Carolina that is the nation's shorthand for budget crisis. The law imposed the deadline for deficit-cutting that has triggered political brinkmanship and brought the government to potential shutdown. Rudman is blunt without being a bully, as Sununu is often called. He points to blame within his own party for the deficit mess, and particularly faults House Republicans for refusing to go along with new taxes. ``I don't meant this to be funny: I truly understand the new Politburo in the Soviet Union ... better than I understand the Republicans in the House of Representatives,'' he said. ``I don't understand what they're doing. I truly don't understand it. ``Divided government is bad enough,'' he said. ``When you have a divided party within a divided government, it is even more frustrating.'' Rudman's background as an attorney general helped earn him the unenvied seat on the ethics committee, which investigates and prosecutes senators caught in scandal or misdeeds. The panel is now deciding what to do about five senators, the so-called Keating Five, accused of improperly intervening with federal regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr., whose S&L was near insolvency. Keating contributed $1.3 million to the senators' campaigns or groups affiliated with them. Rudman says he doesn't know when the panel will decide, but acknowledges the job draws political heat. ``Oh sure, this is still a political institution. Everything we do has some political aspects that relate to it,'' he said. ``Up to now I cannot say I've seen politics enter into the Ethics Committee. We'll see how this plays out.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Boats Block Taiwanese Delegation to Disputed Islands
DOC.TEXT: Japanese coast guard boats have turned back two Taiwanese vessels carrying politicians and athletes toward a group of tiny uninhabited islands claimed by both nations, officials said. The Taiwanese had sought to land the delegation on the islands - called the Senkakus in Japan and Diaoyutai in Taiwan - on Sunday to reinforce their claim to the territory and promote a sports event. Taiwan's Premier Hau Pei-tsun said he was displeased by the Japanese intervention and stressed that his nation ``will stand by the claim'' to the islands about 120 miles northeast of Taiwan's capital of Taipei. Athletes had planned to plant flags of Taiwan's Nationalist Chinese government and run a torch relay on the main island before returning Sunday night. They also intended to publicize the annual Taiwan Athletic Championships that are scheduled to begin on Friday in their country. The premier said the Nationalist government would seek diplomatic means to solve the 45-year-old territorial dispute. Kiyoshi Harada of the Maritime Safety Agency, Japan's coast guard, said the Taiwanese vessels entered 12-mile territorial waters claimed by Japan despite warnings from patrol boats and helicopters. He said the two boats turned back about two hours after entering the waters. Harada declined to say how many patrol boats and helicopters were involved or give other details of the incident. In Taiwan, the Fishermen's Association in Suao, about 35 miles southeast of Taipei, said a radio message indicated about 12 Japanese vessels and two helicopters interdicted the Taiwanese boats about seven miles from the islands. The two boats had set out earlier Sunday with a flotilla of 30 fishing boats. The islands were claimed by Japan in 1895. But the Nationalists, who claim to be China's legitimate government, say the islands came under Chinese sovereignty in 1945 when Japan was defeated in World War II. The United States took over administration of the islands after the war and returned them, along with Okinawa, to Japan in 1972. A year earlier, the Communist government in China laid claim to the islands. Japan's Kyodo News Service said Japan tightened patrols after about 300 Chinese fishing boats approached the islands in 1978 and claimed territorial rights. The latest dispute followed reports that a Japanese right-wing political group received government permission to renovate a lighthouse on one of the islands. Hau said last week that the Nationalists would not tolerate Japan's occupation of the territory.

DOC.HEAD: Saving the Whales: Iceland's Critics Dispute Its Whale Research
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: On the face of it, the United States government and environmentalists may seem an unlikely alliance, but allied they are in their opposition to the resumption of commercial whaling in Iceland. In the second of two stories, AP Science Editor Paul Raeburn examines the efforts to blunt Iceland's contentions that its whales are not endangered. ---

``A whale is the most beautiful animal I have ever seen,'' the poet W.H. Auden wrote during a visit to Iceland in 1936. ``To see it torn to pieces with steam winches and cranes is enough to make one a vegetarian for life.'' That kind of revulsion has helped make the global save-the-whales campaign one of the most dramatic successes of the environmental movement. An international moratorium on commercial whaling was instituted in 1986, and environmentalists now are pushing for a permanent ban on all whaling. ``We would certainly be against whaling until we could definitely show it would not affect the (whale) stocks,'' says Kevin Chu. ``If there is any doubt, we want to err on the side of conservation.'' That's tough talk - and it doesn't come from an environmentalist. Chu is a foreign affairs officer in the U.S. State Department's Bureau of Oceans and International Environmental and Scientific Affairs. Asked to describe the U.S. position on whaling, Chu says: ``The United States is against it.'' The perhaps unusual consensus among the government and environmental groups is fueled by two things: concern that whales are in danger of extinction and the kind of sentiments evoked by Auden. The government takes a strong anti-whaling stance because ``the only voices we hear are the voices of the environmentalists,'' Chu said. Iceland, one of the three major whaling nations along with Norway and Japan, argues strenuously that the whales it wants to hunt are not endangered and that it should be allowed to resume commercial whaling. But even if scientists eventually agree the populations are indeed not endangered, the campaign to save the whales is unlikely to die. ``Politically, it comes down to a relatively simple thing,'' said William Evans, the U.S. representative to the International Whaling Commission. ``There are a number of countries and scientists that believe . . . there is not a justification, or need, for any country to continue to harvest these animals.'' ``I'm completely of the mindset that we have to protect oceans for our own survival, and the whales are a component of this ecosystem,'' said Sally Shoup of Greenpeace. ``We have to stop this devastation of the other creatures on the planet if we want to protect ourselves. ``I think whales are special,'' she said. ``I think they are intelligent creatures. I think Icelanders can understand that as well.'' The save-the-whales campaign began in 1972, when the landmark U.N. Conference on the Environment, in a 53-0 vote, passed a resolution calling for a 10-year moratorium on whaling. Whalers killed 46,000 whales that year. The United States immediately proposed the moratorium to the whaling commission, which rejected it. But the U.S. continued to push. In 1982, the commission finally approved a moratorium, beginning in 1986. ``What we were going to do was take five years of no whaling,'' said Evans, the U.S. representative to the commission. ``Well, we haven't had five years of no whaling, because Iceland invented scientific whaling.'' A clause in the international whaling convention allows the killing of whales for scientific purposes. Iceland exploited it. ``You have the same boats and the same people and you take the same whales and you sell it to the same people and you call it scientific whaling,'' said Roger Payne, a noted whale expert and president of the Long Term Research Institute in Lincoln, Mass. ``It's a joke.'' Johann Sigurjonsson, senior whale specialist at Iceland's Marine Research Institute, vigorously disagreed. ``Those who have been following what we're doing understand the seriousness of what we're doing,'' he said. In 1985, the last year of its commercial whaling operation, Iceland killed 344 whales. It caught 116 in 1986, and the number declined to 68 in 1989. This year, Iceland shut down its whaling operation entirely, but it continues to press vigorously for a resumption of commercial killing of fin, sei and minke whales. Congress has passed several laws that allow the United States to impose economic sanctions against countries that violate whaling commission regulations. Iceland's critics have argued that the scientific whaling is merely commercial whaling under another name, and have pressed the United States to impose sanctions. The United States might be reluctant to do so, however, because Iceland is the site of a strategic NATO base. Payne said the methods used to estimate whale populations are highly imprecise, and that the Icelandic scientific research has ``shown us nothing we didn't know before.'' It could take as long as 100 years to know how many whales can be captured without reducing the size of a given whale population, he said. The International Whaling Commission has stopped releasing estimates of whale populations as it undertakes new assessments because it fears its previous estimates could be wildly inaccurate, said Martin Harvey, the commission's executive officer. The old estimates suggest that since the advent of whaling, the population of fin whales has been reduced from 548,000 to 120,000, while sei whales declined from 256,000 to 54,000. The commission completed its assessment of minke whales this year and concluded that about 28,000 are in Icelandic waters, ``which we think is not too far from the number there ever was,'' said Ray Gambell, a whale biologist and the commission's secretary. Some 600,000 minke whales live in Antarctic waters. Sigurjonsson calls the debate over population numbers a stalling tactic. ``You can set catch limits very cautiously,'' he said. ``But to reject any catch because you don't know the exact figure, that's a difficult question. And it may take you years to find out the exact number.'' ``Part of the problem we're having with Iceland is: What is a reasonable doubt?'' said Chu, of the State Department. ``The scientific committee (of the whaling commission) did say a take of 200 minkes would probably not harm the stock,'' Chu said. ``It was the `probably' that first catches one's attention. We're simply not prepared to let the moratorium lapse at this point.'' Even if the moratorium was lifted or modified, Iceland couldn't resume commercial whaling until at least 1992, Gambell said. The commission can't decide until May, at the earliest, to allow Iceland to proceed. And any such decision would not take effect until 90 days later - too late for the 1991 season. Chu said one alternative might be for the whaling commission to allow Iceland to resume hunting whales up to a quota, rather than have Iceland withdraw from the commission as it has threatened to do. If Iceland withdrew, it no longer would be bound by the moratorium. ``I'm afraid the conservation of whales will suffer if we take too strong a stand,'' said Chu, who said he was expressing his personal views, not those of the State Department. ``On the other hand, I think the United States is not in a position to allow them some sort of a quota. It would be extremely difficult to bend the moratorium.'' Iceland's whalers also may be facing problems on a new front - at home. ``The opinion of the Icelandic public is changing,'' said Gudmundur Hermansson, who covers whaling for Morgunbladid, Iceland's largest daily newspaper. In 1986, ``probably 80 percent to 90 percent of the public supported the government,'' Hermansson said. But that figure is dropping, he said. ``Opinion polls show clearly this support was getting less and less every year,'' Hermansson said. ``I don't think whaling will be taken up again.''

Cincinnati Reds Sweep Oakland Athetics in World Series
DOC.TEXT: The Cincinnati Reds completed one of the biggest upsets in baseball history Saturday night, rallying past the awesome Oakland Athletics by 2-1 and winning the World Series in four quick games. The Reds, who began the season with nine straight victories and held first place all year, closed it with four wins in a row. Cincinnati saved its best for last - finishing off the defending World Series champions despite losing Billy Hatcher and Eric Davis with first-inning injuries. Jose Rijo allowed just two hits in 8 1-3 innings, retiring the final 20 batters he faced, before Randy Myers got the last two outs, finishing a series in which Reds relievers pitched 13 scoreless innings. It was Rijo's second victory over Dave Stewart and it earned him the Series MVP award. For the Reds, it was their ninth straight World Series win, a streak that started in the days of the Big Red Machine. They took advantage of Stewart's first error of the season and scored in the eighth on Glenn Braggs' RBI forceout with the bases loaded and Hal Morris' sacrifice fly. Barry Larkin tied the score on Braggs' effort and Herm Winningham ran in for the winning run on Morris' sacrifice fly. For the A's, it was a bitter disappointment. They were outhit 45-28 and outscored 22-8 in the Series, and the loss marked only their second four-game losing streak of the season. Willie McGee of the A's scored on a base hit by Carney Lansford in the first inning, and it was seven more innings before Cincinnati could get on the board.

DOC.HEAD: One Dead, Two Injured in Quake; Heavy Snow Hampering Rescue
DOC.TEXT: Rescue workers have found only one fatality from a powerful earthquake that hit northwest China, but heavy snowfall hampered their search for casualties, the Central Seismology Bureau said Sunday. ``At the moment, we have one dead and two injured, but I believe there will be more,'' said Li Qianghua of the bureau. The temblor, measuring 6.2 on the Richter scale, hit central Gansu province Saturday afternoon. Another quake measuring 5.1 struck 32 minutes later. Thirty percent of the buildings in the area collapsed and nearly all the others sustained damage making them too dangerous to live in, Li said. Provincial rescue workers arrived in the area during the night but were confronted by a heavy snowfall. The area is between 6,600 and 9,900 feet above sea level, Li said. The quake's epicenter was near the Tianzhu Tibetan Autonomous County, 124 miles northwest of the provincial capital of Lanzhou and 750 miles west of Beijing. Aftershocks were felt as far away as Lanzhou. Li said the area was not heavily populated. A severe earthquake last April hit an area less than 124 miles away in neighboring Qinghai province, killing 126 people. Aftershocks from that quake also were felt in Lanzhou. The Richter scale is an open-ended gauge of the energy released by a quake, as measured by ground motion recorded on a seismograph. An earthquake measuring 6 can cause extensive damage in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Buddhist Monks Appear to Give in to Military Threats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with monks reportedly preparing to resume ministering to soldiers; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Burma's rebellious Buddhist monks, their monasteries ringed by troops, appeared Sunday to have given in to an ultimatum by the country's authoritarian rulers to end their boycott of the military. Reports reaching the Burmese capital from Mandalay, the center of the defiance campaign, said the monks would end their refusal to minister to soldiers in a formal announcement later Sunday. Armed troops cordoned off Buddhist monasteries in the central Burma city Saturday after the military government said it would dissolve monks' groups involved in the boycott. A state radio announcement repeated throughout the day Saturday, interspersed with martial music, said ``illegal'' monks' organizations had been participating in politics, against the rules of Buddhism. ``Such illegal organizations will be dissolved ... from (midnight) tonight, and members of such illegal organizations are not eligible to be members of the Sangha,'' Rangoon Radio said. The Sangha is the main religious governing body in predominately Buddhist Burma. At least six major Mandalay monasteries were surrounded by troops and police and closed their gates. But witnesses contacted by telephone said the gates were opened and monks came out on their morning alms rounds Sunday without interference from the troops. Monks traditionally receive offerings of food from the faithful in the early morning. It was not clear whether action would be taken against the monks, who began their boycott after troops put down an anti-government demonstration in Mandalay last August. The boycott spread to other areas, including Rangoon, located 350 miles south of Mandalay. Western observers in Rangoon said the monks refusal to minister to the soldiers was ``the equivalent of excommunication.'' The government said ``such organizations have jeopardized the peace and stability of the country and threatened the breakup of the central Sangha organization by various means, including threats, blackmail and boycott.'' A Western observer in Rangoon said any move against members of the Sangha is ``bound to cause some kind of popular reaction.'' He spoke by telephone and on condition of anonymity, like other observers who commented on the situation. About 85 percent of Burma's 40 million people are Buddhist and some 300,000 monks live in monasteries around the country. In Buddhist societies, monks are regarded as spiritual leaders of the community and also play a key role in popular celebrations and various rites. Another Burma expert said the government is challenging Burma's religious soul and going against traditions that revere the monks. ``It's going to be very difficult for the soldiers to fire on the monks. If ordered to shoot, it will really bring into question how reliant the soldiers are,'' said Josef Silverstein, a U.S. political scientist in New Jersey. ``If they shoot defenseless monks who are only withholding religious services as a moral weapon, there could be enormous street protests. This is morality vs. weapons. What's left for people whose vote has been rejected by the military?'' The groups singled out by the government included the Young Monks' Organization in Mandalay. On Sept. 6, the organization announced a boycott of religious ceremonies for soldiers and their families after troops broke up an anti-government protest in the city a month earlier. During the Aug. 8 demonstration troops killed four people, including two monks, according to Western diplomats in Rangoon. From Mandalay, in central Burma, the monks' boycott spread west to the district of Monya and to some monasteries in the capital, Rangoon, 350 miles south of Mandalay. Monks emerged at the head of anti-government protests during the 1988 pro-democracy uprising, in which the army killed thousands of people. A Western source said about 160 monasteries in the capital have taken up the protest, involving about 15,000 monks, a quarter of those in the city. However, it appeared the boycott was most widespread in Mandalay, where there are about 20,000 monks, he said. Mandalay was a major center of unrest during the 1988 uprising and monks took over the city administration for several weeks. The military government held a national election May 27 that was easily won by the National League for Democracy, the main opposition group. But the government has refused to hand over power and has arrested the main opposition leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Collaborator Slain in West Bank
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with three stabbing deaths on Sunday; pickup 3rd graf pvs, `Assuming Halaf...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XJRL1
DOC.TEXT: A retired Palestinian high school principal was found gagged, bound and stabbed to death Saturday in the occupied West Bank, and Arab villagers said he was suspected of collaborating with Israel. Three Israeli Jews, including a police officer, died in a stabbing attack Sunday in a Jerusalem neighborhood, army radio reported. The radio said police apprehended one suspect, but it was not clear if he was an Arab or Jew. According to the radio, the attacker first stabbed to death a woman in her 20s, then ran down a major street and stabbed two other people, including the policeman. In the West Bank stabbing death, villagers said Musleh Halaf, 50, was kidnapped five days ago by four masked men in the main street of Jenin. Halaf had been appointed a councilman by the Israeli authorities but had resigned the post, villagers said. Assuming Halaf was slain as a collaborator, his death raised to 282 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs since December 1987, when the uprising against Israeli rule began. Most were killed on suspicion of working with Israeli authorities. Since the uprising began, 761 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 48 Israelis have died in the violence. In Jerusalem, meanwhile, about 100 Israeli women urged international intervention to protect Palestinians in the occupied territories. The protest followed a decision by U.N. chief Javier Perez de Cuellar not to send envoys to investigate the killings of at least 19 Palestinians in Jerusalem unless Israel changes its mind and cooperates with the panel. More than 140 Palestinians were also wounded on Oct. 8, when Israeli security forces fired on protesters on the Temple Mount. The protesters had thrown rocks at Jews praying at the nearby Western Wall. About 30 Israeli police and civilians were injured. The killings on the Mount, known to Moslems as Haram es-Sharif, were condemned in a resolution passed unanimously by the U.N. Security Council despite Israel's attempts to persuade its chief ally, the United States, to veto it. The women, dressed in black and holding placards with slogans opposing the Israeli occupation, held a silent vigil across from a police prison in the center of town. Police had earlier barred the women from holding their vigil in Arab east Jerusalem, saying it could incite violence. One woman was arrested when she and others began shouting slogans. ``We have to demand pressure from outside because we've seen a drastic swing to the right inside Israel and our effect is becoming less and less,'' said Judy Green, who moved to Israel 10 years ago from Little Rock, Ark. ``Most of us here believe that this occupation is destroying Israel and is destroying the morality of Israelis,'' she added. Israel captured the West Bank and Gaza Strip from Jordan and Egypt during the 1967 Middle East war. ``What we are asking for is some kind of odsend from outside to shake this country back into its senses,'' said Ruth Cohen as she held a poster reading: ``Down with the Occupation.''

DOC.HEAD: Arab Slays Three Israelis in Jerusalem Rampage
DOC.TEXT: An Arab wielding a long-bladed knife stabbed three Israelis to death in a rampage through the streets of a quiet Jerusalem neighborhood Sunday, police said. The 19-year-old construction worker from Bethlehem killed an woman soldier in uniform, a gardener and an off-duty police officer who shot him in both legs, Jerusalem Police Commander Aryeh Bibi said. Witnesses heard him shouting ``Allahu Aqbar,'' or ``God is Great,'' suggesting the attack stemmed from Moslem militancy. It came 13 days after Israeli gunfire killed at least 19 Palestinians during a riot on the hallowed Temple Mount. The rampage began just before 7 a.m. in the residential neighborhood of Baka in southern Jerusalem, where the Arab was employed on a construction job, Bibi told a news conference. First to fall victim was an 18-year-old soldier, followed by a 43-year-old man who was walking to his garden nursery carrying plants, authorities said. The attacker then stabbed a 13-year-old boy, slightly injuring him in his arm, chest and head with his 16-inch blade, police said. A 28-year-old officer of the police force's anti-terrorism unit heard screams and ran out of his house chasing the Arab, Bibi said. He said the officer fired two warning shots from his 9mm pistol, then shot him once in each leg, but the attacker lunged at him and stabbed him in the chest. The attacker was being questioned, Bibi said. He and the dead Israelis were not immediately identified. The wounded boy, Amikam Kovner, was being treated at Hadassah Ein Karem Hospital. The Arab was caught by Baka Jews who turned him over to the police, Israel radio said. Bibi said police reinforcements were ``streaming into the city'' to prevent further attacks and patrol the streets to head off Jewish acts of vengeance. Israel radio said 2,000 extra police were being mobilized. Bibi appealed for calm, but enraged Baka Jews swarmed into the streets and attacked at least one Arab laborer who had to be rescued by police, Israel radio said. They also poured kerosene into a car belonging to an Arab they said tried to run over a group of Jews, but did not manage to start a fire, the radio said. Baka was an Arab neighborhood until Israel gained control of the western sector of Jerusalem in the 1948 Arab-Israeli war. It is now populated by Jews, with a scattering of Arab families who did not join the 1948 Palestinian exodus from Israel. The Temple Mount riots have reignited the flagging Palestinian uprising in the territories Israel captured in the 1967 Middle East War. During the 34-month uprising, 761 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 282 byf fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Before Sunday, at least 48 Israelis had died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Staunch Aoun Supporter and Wife and two children Slain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to ADD that Aoun remains in French Embassy; pickup 3rd graf pvs, `Police said...'
DOC.TEXT: Five uniformed gunmen on Sunday shot to death a staunch supporter of ousted Gen. Michel Aoun and his wife and two small sons at their home east of Beirut, police said. The identities of the gunmen were not known and there was no immediate claim of responsibility for the slaying of Dany Chamoun, son of the late President Camille Chamoun. The slayings came a week after Syrian and government troops of President Elias Hrawi's army crushed Aoun's mutiny in Lebanon's Christian heartland. Aoun remains in the French Embssy, where he sought asylum when his forces were attacked. Police said the assailants, using 9mm pistols equipped with silencers, riddled the Chamouns with bullets in their fifth-floor apartment in the hilltop suburb of Baabda. Chamoun, 56, Ingrid Abdel-Noor and their son Tarek, 7, died instantly. The other son, Julien, 5, was taken to a nearby hospital where he died 15 minutes after admission, police said. The Christian leader's 11-month-old daughter, Tamara, escaped unharmed. Reporters saw her held by her weeping governess at the Chamoun apartment. The assassins arrived in two cars at the entrance to the nine-story building at 6 a.m. while four guards assigned to protect the Chamoun family were changing shifts, police said. Chamoun, a Maronite Catholic, was one of the most outspoken critics of Hrawi and Syria's military presence in Lebanon. Chamoun inherited the leadership of the righist Christian National Liberal Party in 1987 upon the death of his father, who ruled Lebanon from 1952 to 1958. The younger Chamoun sought the presidency in 1988, when former President Amin Gemayel's term expired. But parliament was unable to meet to elect a successor and Gemayel appointed Aoun - who then was army commander - as prime minister of a caretaker military cabinet until a new president was elected. Hrawi was elected president Nov. 24, 1989, but Aoun rejected that election on grounds it was held in Syrian-controlled territory. Aoun contended that his three-man cabinet remained the only legitimate authority in the country. Chamoun, who sided with Aoun, was dismayed when Aoun fled his command headquarters in the presidential palace in Baabda minutes after the air-supported attack of Hrawi's troops and the Syrian army began Oct 13. ``I can't believe the general has done this to us,'' Chamoun said the next day. ``May God help us.''

DOC.HEAD: Wealthy Property Owner Kidnapped in Sardinia
DOC.TEXT: Police set up roadblocks across this Italian island Sunday to search for three masked gunmen who kidnapped a wealthy property owner. Giovanni Murgia, 42, was abducted Saturday night as he and a friend emerged from a small house on one of his properties outside Cagliari. Police said the kidnappers tied the couple up and drove off with them in the woman's car. The woman was later released, and the kidnappers headed off with Murgia in another car. There was no immediate word on whether the kidnappers had made contact with Murgia's family. Murgia is one of seven Italians in the hands of kidnappers. Kidnapping for ransom is especially common in Sardinia, where the mountainous interior offers ideal hideouts.

DOC.HEAD: Former Labor Minister Stabbed at Military Ceremony
DOC.TEXT: A former mental patient wielding a kitchen knife on Sunday stabbed an official from the governing party as he walked to a ceremony at a military base, police said. The former labor minister, Hyosuke Niwa, was in a coma Sunday night, said officials at Aiichi Medical University Hospital. Niwa, 78, a Liberal Democratic Party parliamentarian, was attacked at the Moriyama military base in Nagoya, about 170 miles west of Tokyo. The assailant was identified as a 47-year-old mental patient. He was immediately apprehended. A police official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the attacker told investigators he recognized Niwa and ``was trying to kill anyone who is a member of Parliament.'' Police refused to disclose the name of the assailant.

DOC.HEAD: Neo-Nazis Demonstrate in Southeast Germany
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Nazi sympathizers shouted ``Foreigners out!'' and anti-Communist slogans in a march in the southeastern city of Dresden, the news agency ADN reported. There were no reports of any violence Saturday night as the protesters snaked through the center of Dresden, a former East German city 110 miles southeast of Berlin. Police estimated that about 350 neo-Nazis took part in the demonstration, ADN reported. It took place without permission of city authorities, the agency said. The march was led by Michael Kuehnen, a well-known pro-Nazi activist, the agency said. Small groups of neo-Nazis have emerged in the eastern part of Germany since the Berlin Wall fell a year ago. German leaders have warned that pro-fascist sentiments, which were suppressed by the former Communist government, must not be allowed to develop in the newly united country.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Kill 20 Rebels in Capturing Strategic Village
DOC.TEXT: Government troops captured a strategic coastal village in northern Sri Lanka, killing 20 Tamil rebels in an air, naval and ground operation, officials said Sunday. The reported capture of Mawaddipuram village on Saturday opened a passage to Kankesanthurai, a vital, rebel-controlled port one mile away. There was no immediate response to the government claim from the rebel militia, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. Military officials, who cannot be identified under briefing rules, said three soldiers were killed and many more were injured in the taking of Mawaddipuram, 195 miles north of Colombo. They said 20 rebels were killed but did not give further details of the fighting. With Mawaddipuram's capture, the military now claims to control a wide swath of the western coast in the Jaffna peninsula, a mainly Tamil area and a rebel stronghold. The military launched the offensive in the peninsula, the northernmost part of the island, on Wednesday. By Saturday, it claimed to control at least eight rebel camps. Officials said more than 100 militants and 14 soldiers had been killed in fighting until Saturday. The militia disputed the claim. Rebel leader Lawrence Thilaker said on Friday that 50 soldiers and 15 militants were killed. Both sides are known to have made exaggerated claims of the toll in the past. The latest report could not be independently confirmed because communication with the north is cut off. Fighting is also going on in the east, where troops killed six rebels after ferreting them out of a hideout in Kirankulam village Saturday, military officials said. The latest round of civil war started in August, ending a 13-month cease-fire in the seven-year-old insurrection for a separate Tamil homeland in the north and the east. More than 14,000 people have been killed. The separatist demand stems from the militants' complaint that the island's Sinhalese majority discriminates against the Tamils in jobs and education. Sinhalese comprise 75 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people and control the government and the army. Tamils account for 18 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Hold Anti-Government Demonstrations
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of demonstrators held rallies and anti-government marches Sunday to press demands for President Hussain Muhammad Ershad to resign and hold elections under a caretaker government. Riot police backed by paramilitary forces were deployed in key points in the capital, Dhaka, but did not intervene. The nationwide demonstrations, which have been held periodically since Erhsad assumed power in a bloodless coup in 1982, intensified after eight protesters were killed in Dhaka in clashes with police on Oct. 10 and 13. Nasim Ahmed, a senior leader of the opposition Awami League party, claimed that processions held in major cities drew hundreds of thousands of activists. A senior police officer said the protests were peaceful.

DOC.HEAD: Will The Army Let Benazir Bhutto Return to Power?
LaserPhoto NY7
DOC.TEXT: Benazir Bhutto's opponents might bar her from office even if she gets the most votes in next week's election, or she could let them take over and risk political disaster in the economic crunch ahead. ``It's not everything that I be prime minister,'' Ms. Bhutto told a reporter during a break in the campaign. ``Why should I raise prices by 40 percent, which is what they said they'll have to do after the elections? They'll have egg on their faces and we'll come back smiling next March. They won't last six months.'' Economists say Pakistan is in for hard times because of a large debt, dwindling reserves, higher oil prices and a sharp decline in exports. Whether Ms. Bhutto will be permitted to resume office has been a nagging question ever since she was ousted Aug. 6. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan used his constitutional power to dismiss her 20-month-old government on charges of corruption and abuse of power. He called elections three years ahead of schedule. Suspicion has grown that martial law will be declared to keep Ms. Bhutto out of power, although top generals deny it. The army and the president wouldn't kick her out just to let her return three months later, the argument goes. After 11 weeks of name-calling and nearly a dozen unresolved court cases, 50 million voters will be eligible to deliver their verdict Wednesday. Despite increasing economic and social problems in this Moslem nation of 110 million people, Ms. Bhutto has been the only campaign issue. Her Pakistan People's Party and its smaller allies are pitted against the Islamic Democratic Alliance, a loose coalition spanning the ideological spectrum and united only by opposition to Ms. Bhutto. At stake are 217 seats in the National Assembly, the law-making lower house of Parliament that elects the prime minister. Pakistani campaigns usually are noisy, but this one has been relatively quiet, reflecting the cycnicism of an electorate that has seen too many promises broken and democracy derailed too many times in the country's 43-year history. Few disagree that Ms. Bhutto's administration was disappointing. Her inexperience and alleged widespread corruption in her administration drained the large reservoir of goodwill that made her the first woman to lead a modern Moslem nation. More than anything, both critics and supporters say, her downfall stemmed from growing reliance on middlemen and a policy of giving party supporters jobs, contracts and other rewards. ``We made mistakes, no doubt about it,'' Ms. Bhutto said in the interview. ``Any government is going to have differences of perceptions, but it's in the national interest that they be resolved.'' Getting her out of office was easy enough, but the president and caretaker government made serious miscalculations afterward. Ms. Bhutto, 37, was dragged from court to court in an attempt to prove she was Pakistan's most corrupt and incompetent leader. Her husband and dozens of supporters were arrested on what they claimed were trumped-up charges. Her opponents portrayed her as a bad Moslem, a traitor who gave state secrets to India and sympathized with Israel. Their main accomplishment was to deflect attention from Ms. Bhutto's dismal record, revive memories of the military overthrow in 1977 and subsequent execution of her father, Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, and cast her as the martyr. Her opponents were plagued by internal rivalries, and growing impatience in the military indicated things weren't going as the generals had planned. Most analysts predict neither side will win a decisive majority, giving the civilian and military establishment room to form a coalition government that will keep Ms. Bhutto out of power. Still, her political organization could emerge as the largest single party, as in November 1988. Analysts predict the Pakistan People's Party will sweep Sindh, the former prime minister's home province, and possibly win Punjab, her opponents' stronghold and the largest and most populous province. The party has been perceived as the party of the poor and downtrodden since Ms. Bhutto's father founded it nearly 30 years ago. Ms. Bhutto inherited his mass support. She still faces the threat of disqualification because of the half-dozen court cases pending against her. Ms. Bhutto predicted the caretaker government would make a last-ditch attempt to pressure the special tribunals to exclude her from politics. Even if they succeed, she said, there is still her mother to contend with. ``These little guys think it's that easy to get rid of the Bhuttos?'' she asked with a grin. ``They shouldn't forget the name Begum Nusrat Bhutto.''

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Proves Again: War's Bad for Business at Suez Canal
DOC.TEXT: War and rumors of war are bad for business at the Suez Canal. When politics get sticky, revenues go down. In the waning weeks of 1990, politics are sticky indeed. ``When the world is happy, the Suez Canal is happy; when things go wrong somewhere else, they go bad here,'' said Capt. Adel Abdel Salam, the canal's chief pilot. Oil, the black gold of the Middle East, has been the savior and bankroll of the Suez Canal since the late 1940s. As the strategic connection between Western oil consumers and Middle Eastern oil producers, the canal felt an immediate impact when Iraq seized Kuwait on Aug. 2. Warships steaming to and from the Persian Gulf keep the waterway busy, but they don't pay much money. Tankers ferrying oil to Europe pay a lot, but fewer are coming through. Egypt, debt-ridden and deeply involved in the gulf crisis, desperately needs the dollars the canal should be providing. Its most lucrative revenue source is the paychecks sent home by Egyptians abroad. That is dwindling with the return of about 350,000 workers from the gulf, many of them penniless. The assassination of a leading Egyptian politician Oct. 12 in downtown Cairo devastated an already reeling tourist industry. Until Aug. 2, tourism was Egypt's second-best source of money. For ordinary Egyptians, a problem at the Suez Canal is a personal misfortune. They view it as a monument to national pride, much as ancient Egyptians viewed the pyramids and Sphinx. ``We dug the canal with our lives, our skulls, our bones, our blood,'' President Gamal Abdel Nasser said in announcing on July 26, 1956, that Egypt was taking the canal from a British-French concession. The United States had little interest in the canal until its troops found themselves defending North Africa in World War II. Afterward, a burgeoning consumer society demanded more oil, ores and rubber from the East, and they came cheaper via Suez. Trouble never has been far from the 101-mile-long ditch linking the Mediterranean and Red Seas via Egypt's Bitter Lakes and the Gulf of Suez. As many as 20,000 laborers are thought to have died digging the canal, which was inaugurated in 1869 in an orgy of opulence that nearly bankrupted the country. During the 20th century, Suez often has been at or near the center of conflict. Russian warships passed through it in 1905 en route to catastrophic defeat by the Japanese off Korea. In World War I, German U-boats tried to sever England from its colonies east of Suez by keeping cargo ships from using the canal. In 1939, Italian dictator Benito Mussolini used it as a pathway to conquer Ethiopia. Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, Germany's World War II military genius, was unable to capture the canal and the Persian oil fields beyond. Germany bombed it 64 times, stopping traffic for 76 days. Ships sunk during Egypt's 1967 war with Israel blocked all traffic for eight years. Canal business soured during the 1980s because of the Iraq-Iran wqar, in which hundreds of oil tankers were attacked in the Persian Gulf. For Egypt, which owns the canal, Iraq's invasion of Kuwait was far more than a problem between Arab brothers. Both countries were good customers of Suez, each year shipping seven million tons of oil westward. The U.N. embargo ended that. Oil that would have passed through the canal to Europe is being consumed east of Suez by forces sent to confront Iraq. Through August, the canal's monthly tanker tonnage averaged more than 13.5 million tons. In September, the first full month under embargo, the tonnage was 11 million. ``War makes civilization go faster, but on the Suez Canal, things slow down,'' said Abdel Salam, the chief pilot.'' ``It's not devastating . . . but yes, we're suffering.'' How much became evident in September. Ezzat Adel, chairman of the Suez Canal Authority, said the gulf trouble ould cost $400 million in the fiscal year that started a month before the invasion. In 1989, canal revenues brought the government nearly $1.4 billion. The crisis brings into focus two persistent irritants for the Canal Authority: neutrality and nuclear ships. Under the 1888 Constantinople Convention, the Suez Canal must accept all ships, but Egypt interprets one clause as allowing it to deny access to those likely to endanger Egypt's security. That was the basis of a ban on ships flying Israel's flag until 1979, when Egypt signed a peace treaty with the Jewish state, and on vessels either carrying nuclear weapons or powered by nuclear energy. Iraqi ships now use the canal despite Egypt's strong anti-Iraq position in the gulf crisis. If war began, Egypt probably would ban them. The nuclear ban is so politically sensitive that nobody will talk about it. In August, as the United States built up its forces to face Iraq, the nuclear-powered aircraft carrier Dwight D. Eisenhower passed through the canal to the Red Sea, then returned two weeks later. Egypt did not ask about the carrier's propulsion system.

DOC.HEAD: Chess Buffs Follow Their Masters In World Championship
LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: The two greatest minds in chess sit on the stage in a newly refurbished theater near Times Square, agonizing over each move in absolute silence. But just a short walk uptown, about 30 chess aficionados of all stripes are gathered in a cramped, run-down lecture room, second-guessing each move the masters make as the thump-thump-thump from a nearby exercise studio reverberates through the open windows. ``Is Karpov really taking this long, or is it the computer?'' asks one woman as they wait for the next move to be relayed from the theater to their board at the Manhattan Chess Club. ``That's a very old opening,'' someone else complains. ``Can't they come up with something original?'' As world champion Garry Kasparov battles Anatoly Karpov in the World Series of chess, hard-core fans are getting nearly instantaneous play-by-play analysis at chess clubs across the country. Game 5 of the best-of-24 World Chess Championship series will be held Monday, after Kasparov took one of his three allowed timeouts Friday. Karpov used one of his timeouts after losing game 2. The other three games ended in draws, making the score Kasparov 2{, Karpov 1{. The two are playing for the crown and the winner's share of a $3 million purse. The first 12 games will be in New York; the rest in Lyons, France. Watching the match at a club with a direct link to the Hudson Theater, where the series began Oct. 8, is the next best thing to being there, maybe better, fans say. Talking is encouraged at the clubs, and most have arranged for grandmasters to explain the intricate strategies as each game unfolds. ``Here you can ask questions,'' said Ruth Cardoso, an international master from Brazil. ``Sometimes it's a stupid question. But you get an answer.'' It's cheaper, too. Tickets to the match run up to $100 a game, while the show at the Manhattan Chess Club is free for members, $10 to non-members. The world championship is played every three years, but this one is an especially intense grudge match. Karpov is trying to regain the title that Kasparov, the highest-rated player in the history of chess, won from him in 1985. ``Everybody's excited, even though it's only two Russians playing each other,'' said grand master Pal Benko, who provided commentary for Game 4 last week at the 113-year-old chess club. ``No American like Bobby Fischer'' - a club member from the 1950s. The Game 4 crowd, mostly men, included players of all levels. Retired computer programmers sat next to long-haired students in jeans and carrying backpacks. Businessmen in well-tailored suits outnumbered the stereotypical ``chess nerds'' in plaid polyester jackets. Almost everybody is holding his or her own mini-chessboard or writing down the moves as they are announced in chess notation. ``Entertainment is part of it, but it's a different kind of entertainment,'' said Russ Garber, the club's director. ``People like to be able to say, `I predicted that Kasparov would play this move.' So they feel like, `I, too, can think like a world champion.' ... It's an ego thing.'' On the wall at the front of the room is a 6-by-6-foot chessboard with magnetic pieces. Benko stands at the front and rearranges the markers, sometimes even before the computer operator runs in with a new move. ``I put already the bishop here,'' he says. ``I know the next move.'' He's right. White's pawn looks vulnerable. ``Can he take it, or is it a trap?'' someone asks. Benko explores several possibilities before deciding it's not a trap. For most, nothing can match the excitement of watching the two best players in the world - not computer glitches, shabby surroundings or dance music pulsating loudly outside. ``Chess is a religion to some of us,'' said Bruce Albertson, a national master. ``This is what we wait for.''

DOC.HEAD: Charges Increasing in AIDS Assault Cases
DOC.TEXT: An increasing number of states now have laws that make it a crime to knowingly expose another person to the AIDS virus. Since 1986, 22 states have passed laws making it illegal to engage in conduct that could transmit the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, believed to cause acquired immune deficiency syndrome, according to the AIDS Policy Center at George Washington University. ``The idea of trying to prosecute somebody for attempted transmission of HIV is increasingly, almost alarmingly, common,'' said Lawrence O. Gostin, director of the AIDS Litigation Project of the U.S. Public Health Service and a professor at the Harvard University School of Public Health. But, he said, ``when somebody is actually having sex with somebody, I think the risk is significant enough that prosecutors are well within their rights to prosecute.'' While the number of AIDS-related prosecutions nationwide is not known, the military seems to be having the best success with such cases, the experts say. Last week the Supreme Court rejected without comment an appeal by Nathaniel Johnson Jr., an Air Force sergeant who was convicted in a military court of aggravated assault because he had homosexual relations at McChord Air Force Base, Wash., while knowingly infected with the virus. The Air Force Court of Military Review said at least six previous courts-martial had been convened based upon AIDS-related assaults. Such conduct, it said, ``can be analogized to attempting to put poison in the drink of a victim.'' The outcomes in civilian courts so far have tended to be different, Gostin said. ``It is enormously problematical to try to reach into the bedroom and create a criminal prosecution around it, and the only ones who have been successful in doing that are the military,'' Gostin said. Part of reason is because most civilian cases involve biting, spitting or splashing blood rather than intercourse. ``It is virtually impossible - if not impossible - to transmit the virus that way,'' Gostin said. ``It appears to me to be much more punitive than effectuating any clear public policy.'' ``Most of the cases of (infected) men sleeping with people are military cases,'' said Gostin, who is also executive director of the American Society of Law and Medicine. ``Often the charge is willful disobedience of a military order. Sometimes it is assault or even attempted murder. ``In civil court it is very difficult to get a conviction on those kinds of cases,'' he said. ``If your intention is to kill somebody else, having sex with them is a highly indirect modus operandi.'' Gostin said most cases in the state courts are brought under general criminal laws rather than specific AIDS-related legislation. He said he had not found one such case in which HIV was transmitted. James R. Klimaski, a Washington lawyer who specializes in ilitary law, said the military has an easier time with sexual cases because it is a much more controlled environment. The Defense Department and each service have regulations governing sexual conduct by service people who know they are infected with the AIDS virus. Under Navy policy, a sailor found to have the virus is given counseling and ordered to avoid unsafe sexual practices, said Lt. Beci Brenton, a Navy public affairs officer. The sailor signs a statement saying he understands the order, and any violation is prosecuted as disobeying a commanding officer. In Johnson's case, he was dishonorably discharged and sentenced to six years in prison. His lawyers contend he was never told about an Air Force policy that HIV-infected military members could be subjected to disciplinary action for engaging in unsafe sex. But Klimaski said it had become ``pretty settled law'' that knowingly having unprotected sex while HIV-infected can be prosecuted as assault under the Uniform Code of Military Justice. According to the Aids Policy Center, intentionally exposing someone to the virus is a felony in Arkansas, California, Colorado, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Michigan, Missouri, Ohio, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Texas and Virginia. It is a misdemeanor in Alabama and Maryland. The center said Nevada, Mississippi and Louisiana passed similar laws without specifying whether the offense was a felony or misdemeanor. The laws vary as to the circumstances in which they apply. AIDS attacks the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to a wide variety of infections and cancers. It is most often transmitted through sexual contact, mostly between homosexual males.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Research Lost In Hospital Blaze
DOC.TEXT: Fire swept through a hospital wing early Sunday, destroying five years of research on muscle disorders and causing damage estimated at more than $1 million, officials said. Sixty firefighters prevented the blaze at Hammersmith Hospital in west London from spreading to the wards and the adjacent emergency department. Nurses, police and ambulance crews alerted by automatic fire alarms moved 46 patients, some bedridden, from three wards as smoke from the research department on the top floor of one wing filled the hospital. One patient suffered from smoke inhalation and was transferred to Charing Cross Hospital, where he was reported to be ``quite satisfactory.'' Police said they are treating the fire, which started in the unoccupied research wing, as suspicious. Fire crews took 2{ hours to bring it under control. Pioneering research into muscle disorders, led by Professor Victor Dubowitz and funded by the Muscular Dystrophy Group, had been carried out in the laboratory. Hospital general manager Paul Herbage said: ``The whole area has been destroyed. Five years of research has been lost.''

DOC.HEAD: Who's Hiding Their True Views; Which Way Will They Really Vote?
With AM-Florida Governor Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Harvey Gantt isn't worried about watching a large lead evaporate on Election Day. He doesn't have one. Other black candidates have seen their comfortable cushions vanish at the polls. But Gantt, the black former mayor of Charlotte, N.C., says his dead-heat race against Republican Sen. Jesse Helms is different. He maintains he's the one with hidden support among white voters. ``Everybody keeps saying don't you think you need a 15-point lead because people are going to lie to pollsters,'' said Gantt's press secretary, Susan Jetton. ``No. Because why would somebody who voted for Jesse Helms three times in the past lie about voting for him a fourth time?'' It's more likely, under the Gantt camp's theory, that a white rural conservative voter would feel uncomfortable telling people he supports Gantt - so he'd say Helms but pull the Gantt lever. ``We're not worried about the fudge factor,'' Jetton said. ``Any fudge factor on one side might be balanced by a fudge factor on the other side.'' The fudge factor can be defined as a poll respondent's tendency to hide out in the undecided column or give an answer that's socially acceptable but dishonest. It was illustrated last year by the elections for Virginia governor and New York City mayor. Black candidates won both races, but only by fractions of the margins they were expected to get. Neil Newhouse, a Republican poll-taker, said it would be a mistake to assume that all pre-election polls involving minority candidates are unreliable. ``I don't think it's correct to try to extrapolate what happened in two polarized races - black vs. white, abortion vs. anti-abortion ... to Cincinnati, Ohio or Waterbury, Conn.,'' he said. Black Republicans are running for House seats in those two cities. Newhouse predicted race would play little or no role in the two contests, particularly the heated Cincinnati competition between Democratic Mayor Charles Luken and former Mayor Kenneth Blackwell, who is black. ``He's been elected city-wide. He has a track record,'' Newhouse said of Blackwell. ``I'm positive you're not going to see any kind of turnoff by white voters.'' In Connecticut, former Democratic congressman Toby Moffett is in a competitive race with black Republican Gary Franks, an alderman from Waterbury. White voter turnoff was behind last year's unexpectedly narrow wins for Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder and New York Mayor David Dinkins. Wilder had a 9-point lead in the polls and won by a half-point, while Dinkins was ahead 16 points in voter surveys and won by 4 points. Another variation of the fudge factor was evident this year in strong showings by two unconventional primary candidates considered socially unacceptable in some circles. Outspoken Democrat John Silber won his party's gubernatorial nomination in Massachusetts by a 9-point margin though polls showed his opponent with an 11-point lead. And ex-Klansman David Duke garnered 44 percent of the vote in the Louisiana Senate primary - not enough to win but far greater than the 26 percent indicated in the last major poll before the election. Undecided voters tilted to Duke and Silber, swelling their vote totals. In contrast, virtually all of those who were undecided right before the New York and Virginia elections shunned Dinkins and Wilder in favor of their white opponents. That would ordinarily spell bad news for Gantt, since the undecided voters who will determine the tight North Carolina race are almost all white. But Geoff Garin, a Democratic pollster, said his research in North Carolina indicates there is some reason for Gantt to believe he can get an even break on the undecided vote there. ``The undecided voters in North Carolina are not secret Helms voters,'' he said. ``They are people who don't like Jesse Helms and haven't figured out exactly what to do.'' Helms, an outspoken conservative, has hammered at Gantt for his ``extreme liberal values'' and criticizes his support for a women's right to an abortion. Gantt depicts Helms as an ideologue who votes against the interests of his state, particularly on education and the environment. Helms pleads with his supporters, meanwhile, to help him out of ``the fix I'm in'' by turning out to vote in large numbers. Said a key Helms adviser, Carter Wrenn: ``It's looking right now like that's going to be the deciding factor.''

DOC.HEAD: One-Day Depression Program Points Sufferers Toward Help
DOC.TEXT: June recently lost a relative, and her sorrow would not abate. Then she read an article about a hospital's daylong program on depression, and found herself among 150 neighbors in need of help. Douglas G. Jacobs of Quincy Psychiatric Associates said his unusual session, which he hopes will be a model for programs nationwide, provided potent evidence of the wide reach of depression. In fact, three of the people who came to the free session held earlier this month at Quincy City Hospital were immediately hospitalized because ``they were in the midst of a suicidal crisis.'' Jacobs was concerned but not surprised. He said statistics show fewer than 30 percent of depressed people ever get help. Although most people who do seek counseling can recover in six to nine months, the recovery period involves severe bouts of stress and disruption at home and work.
