Fifteen percent don't recover; they commit suicide, Jacobs said. ``At any time, 7{ (million) to 10 million people suffer from depression,'' Jacobs said. ``Many depressions go unrecognized, and the ultimate loss is suicide. We're trying to encourage people to identify depression in themselves.'' Jacobs, a psychologist who specializes in suicide research, has been on the Harvard Medical School faculty for 12 years. He developed the idea of the one-day program at the hospital as a way to familiarize people with the symptoms of depression and to encourage treatment. ``This is not a substitute for a psychiatric evaluation. This is to learn about depression, to learn about the signs and symptoms,'' Jacobs said. ``I'm going to propose this to be conducted statewide and perhaps nationally. That will take a lot of planning.'' About 15 participants in the session contacted him or another mental health professional for follow-up treatment, and in all, ``at least 50 percent could have benefited from treatment,'' Jacobs said. Mental health professionals say doctors need to be more familiar with the symptoms of depression, which often manifests itself physically. Many have depressed patients and don't know it, said Melvin Sabshin, medical director for the American Psychiatric Association in Washington. ``A lot of people who have depression start with physical symptoms,'' said Sabshin. ``Loss of sleep, physical problems of other kinds - fatigue, general lack of energy, headaches, gastric problems. They suffer from sexual problems, too.'' Jacobs called the APA for some guidance on the program, and the national organization couldn't name a similar endeavor. ``The program that (Jacobs) had in Quincy was excellent,'' Sabshin said last week. ``It could be a prototype that we could consider for a program on a national basis.'' Every October, the APA promotes National Mental Awareness Week. Sabshin said once he receives Jacobs' data and discusses the program with his 75 district branches, a national program may be established next fall. The one-day session in this city just south of Boston consisted of three, two-hour sessions including a half-hour lecture by Jacobs, a videotape of depressed people discussing their condition, informational literature, and a questionnaire. Each participant also got a brief session with a counselor. The set of questions wasn't the kind of test you wanted to pass, but June, who asked that her real name not be used, joked about it. ``It was a very good questionnaire,'' she said. ``Unfortunately, I did pretty well because of my bereavement. I'm still going through the grief process.'' June realizes that the loss of a loved one is an unavoidable part of life. But people often need help accepting and coping with such inevitabilities. ``I had gone to two counselors, but I felt I needed more help,'' she said. ``Some people have depression all of their life and they don't always know it.'' Jacobs stressed that programs such as the one at Quincy City Hospital aren't the long-term solution to depression. But in a world of disappointments of varying degrees, every bit helps.

DOC.HEAD: Monks, Under Threat, End Boycott Against Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Rebellious Buddhist monks on Sunday ended a boycott on ministering to soldiers after government troops surrounded their monasteries. Defiant monks were also threatened with death. Reports reaching the capital, Rangoon, from Mandalay, center of the defiance campaign, said the monks ended their boycott after troops ringed at least six major monasteries. The monks' apparent capitulation also came as Burma's prime minister, Gen. Saw Maung, gave army commanders the power under martial law to bring monks before military tribunals for activities deemed disruptive to Buddhism, official Rangoon Radio said. Sentences dispensed by such tribunals range from a minimum of three years in prison to a maximum of death. Monks emerged at the forefront of anti-government protests during a 1988 pro-democracy uprising that the army crushed, killing thousands of people. Burma held free elections in May, which were easily won by the National League for Democracy, the main opposition group. But the military government has refused to hand over power and arrested the main opposition leaders. The state radio said 29 monks attended a ceremony Sunday in Mandalay formally ending the boycott. Nearly 200 monks in Rangoon also withdrew in writing their support of the boycott, according to the broadcast. Mandalay is Burma's second-largest city and its religious center. Rangoon Radio said one monk had persuaded an unnamed political party to press for a speedy transfer of power in Burma and organized monks to overthrow the government. It said he had confessed under interrogation to his political activities. The state radio broadcast a decree that accused members of illegal monks' organizations of ``engaging in activities that disrupt the purification, perpetuation and propagation of Buddhism.'' ``Commanders ... have been empowered to investigate, expose and take effective action against such people,'' it said. Armed troops cordoned off Buddhist monasteries in Mandalay, in central Burma, on Saturday. A state radio announcement repeated throughout the day Saturday, interspersed with martial music, said ``illegal'' monks' organizations had been participating in politics. ``Such illegal organizations will be dissolved ... from (midnight) tonight, and members of such illegal organizations are not eligible to be members of the Sangha,'' Rangoon Radio said. The Sangha is the main religious governing body in Burma, a predominately Buddhist country. The government said the illegal monks' groups have ``jeopardized the peace and stability of the country and threatened the breakup of the central Sangha organization by various means, including threats, blackmail and boycott.'' Eyewitnesses contacted by telephone in Mandalay said the monastery gates were opened and monks came out on their morning alms rounds Sunday without interference from the troops. Monks traditionally received offerings of food from the faithful in the early morning. A large number of Mandalay monks joined the boycott following the brutal suppression of an anti-government demonstration in the city in August. The boycott spread to other areas, including Rangoon, 350 miles south of Mandalay. About 85 percent of Burma's 40 million people are Buddhist and about 300,000 monks live in monasteries around the country. Monks are regarded as spiritual leaders of the community and play a key role in popular celebrations and various rites.

DOC.HEAD: Joyous Summertime at Lacroix Fashion Show
LaserPhotos PAR1,2
DOC.TEXT: Christian Lacroix brought spring into bloom Sunday in a joyous riot of summer shades and shapes at his luxury ready-to-wear fashion show. The young designer from the south of France continued his trend of favorite silhouettes in luscious, expensive styles and added some new tricks as well. The multicolored striped jersey T-shirt outfits - mainly short with some long pants thrown in - came out with original panels of sequined Provencal flowers on shirts and skirts. Lacroix also stepped in line with some other designers here, bringing out clinging bodysuits and bathing suits. A few sported little ruffled skirtlets. A new swirly abstract print called Le Marquis was mixed all over the place in pique cotton suits and flowing silk crepe outfits. Silhouettes ranged from simple pants and beach shirts to the favorite Lacroix trapeze coats and babydoll dresses. Though every color of the rainbow showed up in his line, Lacroix strongly favored reds, from orange to poppy to shocking pink. He sometimes combined solids with a wide gridiron pattern or fuzzy stripes in pants or the modified bubble-shaped skirts he loves. Lacroix simplified a few outfits using solids only - buttercup yellows, lavender, pastels or purple. But often he mixed up bright solids on pockets, sleeves and lapels. The Lacroix exuberance stayed mostly under control, slipping only a bit in certain flounced, mixed-print outfits rimmed and underlined by black lace petticoats. They looked a bit too flower-child for Lacroix's sophisticated clientele, who pay high prices for his clothes. Issey Miyake scored a solid hit Saturday for artistry and versatility with his individual approach to fabric and draping. Not always wearable, the clothes always intrigued as objects. In his sporting line, yellow-and-black stretch suits in abstract designs gave a futuristic cast to the current rage for body stockings. With customary wit, Miyake sometimes added real handbags - with the purse growing right out of the glove. Dinosaur jackets with pointed, folded sleeves in sandy shades of gazar silk looked anything but prehistoric, marching out over finely-pleated white skirts. Another wild idea featured bicolored tunic-suits in a crimped fabric. When held above the head, the rounded arm shapes looked like cheery commas. Dressy clothes for the beach were a strong item at Enrico Coveri's show on Sunday. The beaded, sequined or embroidered beige fishnet trapeze minis, maxis or pants outfits could look nearly nude or fine enough for a sunny terrace restaurant. As usual, Coveri used plenty of strong color, from flowered body suits to matching sheer duster tops. Raw silk in sizzling shades of orange, cornflower yellow, amethyst and shocking pink came out in fitted shortie suits, some with sleeveless vests or jackets. Other options included solid, short satin trench coats, shorts, beach wraps and bush jacket styles in African colors and patterns.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Live Crew Jurors Say Music Was Fun, Verdict Was Easy
DOC.TEXT: The six jurors who helped 2 Live Crew beat an obscenity rap say their ``not guilty'' verdict was almost as instantaneous as it was unanimous. The moment they took the case behind closed doors and sat down to a pre-deliberation lunch, they discovered a common opinion: Not only was the Miami rap group's music a form of art, it was fun. ``We found many of the things very humorous,'' said Beverly Resnick, 65, a mother of two who gathered briefly with the other jurors to discuss the verdict after court was adjourned Saturday. ``Our feelings were, the musicians in the band were telling the public how they felt inside of themselves, and they were doing it with music. We thought it had some art in it.'' Band leader Luther Campbell and members Mark ``Brother Marquis'' Ross and Chris ``Fresh Kid Ice'' Wongwon each faced up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine had they been convicted on the one-count misdemeanor of staging an obscene performance. Assistant State Attorney Pedro Dijols said after the verdict that he was unsure whether a similar case would be prosecuted in the future. But he said the verdict showed Broward authorities needed to do a better job of gathering evidence. Jurors had noted that the recording police made of the disputed concert was difficult to hear. The charges stemmed from an adults-only show at a nightclub in nearby Hollywood on June 10. On June 6, a federal judge in Broward County ruled the group's album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' was obscene, and on June 8, a merchant was arrested for selling the album, which includes references to oral and anal sex and sexual violence against women. The jurors said that although they took more than two hours to finish their meal, elect a foreman, wrap up their debate and fill out the verdict form, their feelings about the music were never in doubt. ``It was humorous,'' said juror David Gilliland, 26, a mechanic. ``And I do believe humor is an art form.'' The jurors also said they didn't think race was an issue. 2 Live Crew is a black group, and part of their defense was that their music represented their culture, using time-honored devices such as exaggeration, humor and bawdiness. ``I like the music, and my kids like the music,'' said Gertrude McLamore, 61, a retired cook and the only black on the jury. Juror Helena Bailie, 76, a retired sociology professor, said the band's performance in the face of threatened arrests may have been an act of political defiance. ``Maybe the band felt threatened, and they were thumbing their noses back,'' she said. Foreman David Garsow, 24, said prosecutors made a mistake in playing tinny, garbled tapes of the concert again and again, although the words were barely discernible because of the poor quality of the recordings made by police with pocket-sized recorders. ``It wore us down,'' said Garsow, a one-time musician. ``After we heard it once, we felt like we didn't need to hear it a third and a fourth time.'' But although the tapes ``just weren't clear enough for us to decide what happened,'' Garsow said the jury heard enough to not be offended. ``As the cross-section of the community that we are, it was just not obscene,'' he said. Charles Freeman, the record-store owner convicted by an earlier jury of selling obscene material when he sold a ``Nasty'' album to an undercover policeman, lauded Saturday's verdict, calling it ``true justice.'' Milt Hirsch, Freeman's trial attorney, said the cases were different because the prosecution in his had to prove only that the recording Freeman sold was obscene. In the band's case, ``the state had no case at all'' since it lacked a videotape or other conclusive evidence to support the charges. ``Unfortunately, in Charles' trial, the only issue was the obscenity of the record itself,'' Hirsch said. ``Whether this will come back for consideration at Charles' sentencing is another question.'' Freeman faces sentencing on Nov. 2.

DOC.HEAD: N.Y., Ohio Youths Receive Bravery Awards
DOC.TEXT: A 9-year-old Ohio boy who died after boosting his best friend to safety when they fell through the ice on a frozen pond was among four recipients to receive 1989 Young American Medals for Bravery Sunday. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said Andrew William D'Alesio of Reynoldsburg, Ohio saved his friend's life on Feb. 19, 1989 after they sank through the ice playing hockey. D'Alesio pushed his friend to safety, but then fell underneath the ice and died. The second recipient of the bravery award was Jason Frank Guntert, then 17, of Hudson, N.Y. He pulled a woman from a burning, smoke-filled car that had been involved in an accident. Guntert suffered serious burns when he extinguished the flames on the woman's coat and body with his hands. Two other young people also received the 1989 Young American Medals for Service. - Gregory D. Bassuk, then 17, of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., has served both the youth and the elderly of his community through a series of volunteer activities. He has worked as a community aide for senior citizens and hosted a radio talk show that focused on youth-related issues. - Christopher E. Daly, then 17, of Gaithersburg, Md., has served his community through membership in various organizations. He planned a one-day regional conference for teen-agers with orthopedic disabilities, their parents and their friends. The medals program, established in 1950, recognizes young people for acts of bravery and community service. It directs the Department of Justice to pick the recipients, who are then given medals by the president.

DOC.HEAD: Clashes In The Holy City
With AM-Israel-Violence, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
The Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation has led to increased clashes between Jews and Arabs in Jerusalem. Following are some major incidents of recent years.
1989: -Feb. 7: A curfew is imposed on the Jerusalem refugee camp of Shufat after riots and repeated stoning attacks on cars. It is the first curfew in Jerusalem since the uprising began in December 1987. -April 10: A Palestinian is shot to death and two others are wounded as they sit near the Jaffa Gate entrance to Jerusalem's Old City. The attack is claimed by a Jewish underground group, the Sicarites. -May 2: Two elderly Israelis are stabbed to death and three others wounded by a Palestinian at a downtown Jerusalem bus stop. -July 6: A Palestinian man grabs the wheel of an Israeli bus en route to Jerusalem and plunges it over a ravine, killing 16 passengers, most of them Israelis. The Palestinian is jailed for life. -Dec. 30: Police break up an Arab-Israeli human ``peace chain'' around the old city. More than 50 people are injured, including an Italian peace activist who loses an eye. 1990: -April 11: About 150 Jewish activists take over a Christian hostel in the Old City's Christian Quarter, sparking several days of Arab riots in the old walled city. An Israeli court orders most of the Jews out until ownership of the hostel is sorted out. -May 28: A bomb explodes in the crowded Mahane Yahuda market, killing an Israeli and injuring nine others. Arab cars are stoned and photographers beaten up. -Aug. 6: Police find the stabbed, strangled bodies of two Jewish teen-agers who disappeared while hitchhiking in northern Jerusalem. The incident sets off three days of anti-Arab rioting in which an Arab was killed when his car was stoned and it overturned. -Oct. 8: Israeli police open fire on Palestinians on the Temple Mount after stones were thrown at Jews below at the Western Wall. At least 19 Palestinians are killed. -Oct. 21: An Arab laborer stabs three Israelis to death. Police believe he may have been trying to avenge the Temple Mount killings.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill Former Soldier, IRA Claims Responsibility
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen killed a former soldier near a crowded Roman Catholic church, police said Sunday. The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility. The slaying Saturday night was the fourth within a week resulting from religious and sectarian strife in Northern Ireland. The victim was identified as David Pollock, 30, a Protestant who left the locally recruited Ulster Defense Regiment several years ago. The gunmen, using a car stolen from a family they had taken hostage, rammed the vehicle being driven by Pollock in County Tyrone near the border with the Irish Republic, police said. The attack took place just a few hundred yards from Melmount Church where more than 1,000 Roman Catholic worshipers were just leaving a service celebrating peace and reconciliation. ``It's a miracle that no one else was killed or injured,'' said The Rev. Patrick Arkinson, the church curate. ``This killing ... was a direct contradiction of our faith and a violation of the Fifth Commandment, Thou Shalt Not Kill.'' Dr. Charles Sullivan, a local doctor, said he went to help the man but he was already dead, the body slumped over in the driver's seat. The gang fled on foot and then hijacked a second auto from a woman and her daughter driving home from the church, said a spokesman for the Royal Ulster Constabulary, the province's police force, who by custom was not identified. The mainly Catholic IRA, which is fighting to end British rule in the mainly Protestant province and unite it with the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republic, claimed responsibility for the attack in messages to Belfast media. Leading politicians in the province were united in their condemnation of the shooting. Peter Robinson, deputy leader of the hard-line Protestant Democratic Unionist Party, said: ``There is a tremendous need for the government to react to this increase in violence, and we must have a resolute military initiative against the IRA immediately.'' Seamus Mallon, deputy leader of the moderate Catholic Social Democratic and Labor Party, called it ``another pointless, brutal murder which will be as futile and counterproductive as the almost 3,000 murders which have already taken place. ``The IRA campaign has become a war of attrition which can lead to nothing but further suffering.'' Dr. John Alderdice, leader of the centrist Alliance Party, said ``all the terrorists can offer is to go around destroying people's lives and families. ``I feel angry about it and distressed for the family who is going to suffer this loss.'' On Oct. 15, a police dog handler died in the hospital, two days after he and a fellow dog handler were shot by an IRA gunman in central Belfast. Dermot McGuinness, a Roman Catholic, and former police reservist Steven Craig, a Protestant, were killed in separate shootings in north Belfast on Tuesday. The IRA claimed responsibility for shooting Craig. The Ulster Freedom Fighters, an illegal Protestant paramilitary group committed to retaining British rule over the province, said it killed McGuinness.

DOC.HEAD: Romantic Scandal Could Lead to Economy Minister's Fall
DOC.TEXT: Economy Minister Zelia Cardoso de Mello could fall victim to a scandal that already has cost the job of her romantic partner - former Justice Minister Bernardo Cabral. The economy minister denies any intention of resigning. On Friday, President Fernando Collor de Mello made a carefully staged public appearance with his embattled official, in what was clearly meant as a show of support. But Ms. Cardoso de Mello's job - arguably the most important Cabinet post in a country whose economy is reeling - is the subject of much speculation. News reports of the affair forced Cabral to resign Oct. 13. Few predict Ms. Cardoso de Mello's resignation is imminent, but a concensus is growing that her days are numbered. ``Her position is extremely fragile,'' said political consultant Alexandre Barros. ``If I were a bookmaker, I'd say there is an 80 percent chance she'll be gone within three months.'' The scandal broke out in late September when Ms. Cardoso de Mello, 37 years old and single, was disclosed to be having an affair with Cabral, 58, who has been married for 35 years. At a Sept. 19 birthday party for the economics minister, the two danced cheek-to-cheek at a posh Brasilia club before hundreds of gawking journalists and dignataries. Political scientist Walder de Goes of the Universty of Brasilia said Brazilian society is extremely sexist, and that ``whispering and gossip'' about the minister's love life had greatly damaged her authority. ``She can only save her job if she marries Cabral,'' he said. ``Otherwise, she'll be seen as someone foolish and weak, who was used by an older man.'' De Goes said Ms. Cardoso de Mello appeared to come unglued during a Senate hearing Wednesday, when Cabral unexpectedly showed up during a brief break. Those in the chamber cleared the room to leave the two alone. ``It's obvious she is completely in love,'' he said. ``If the situation is not resolved, she may be unable to concentrate on the country's problems.'' Others say the Cabral affair was merely the last straw, and that Brazil's continuing economic woes are the primary reason for Ms. Cardoso de Mello's tenous hold on power. Prominent political analyst Janio de Freitas said Collor has been angry with his economic minister since August, when he announced inflation would be 3 percent, based on a guarantee from Ms. Cardoso de Mello. ``It was 10 percent, and has gone up since then,'' he said. ``That, along with the romantic scandal, has her with one foot out the door.'' He said that if monthly inflation was not in the single digits by January, the minister's fate would be sealed. September inflation was 12.58 percent and little decline is expected soon, especially with international oil prices soaring because of the Persian Gulf crisis. Barros said the only sign in Ms. Cardoso de Mello's favor was that her dismissal would be seen as a confession the president's economic austerity policies had failed. He said it would also weaken Brazil's position in its talks with foreign creditors. ``If she goes, everything gets very shaky,'' he said. ``That may at least delay her fall.'' The minister's firmest show of support last week came from her mother, 70-year-old Auzelia Martoni Cardoso de Mello. ``Brazil needs to learn to pay attention to more important subjects ... and forget about my daughter's personal life,'' she said in a newspaper interview.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhotos NY44, NY4
DOC.TEXT: Mike Tyson reached an out-of-court settlement with a parking attendant who claimed the boxing champion punched him when he refused to let Tyson's white Mercedes-Benz park in a particular spot. Michael Devine, 35, said the terms of the settlement reached Friday prevent him from disclosing how much money he received. But it was less than the $250,000 he was seeking, he said, and too small to make up for his suffering. ``It was lousy, lousy,'' Devine said Saturday. ``The settlement was a lousy amount for all the trauma I've been through. I'm not fussy when it comes to money, but that was lousy.'' Telephone calls seeking comment from Tyson's attorney, Howard Weitzman, were not immediately answered on Sunday. The attendant and part time stand-up comedian was working a lot on Vine street in Hollywood near the Palace nightclub the night of April 10, 1989. Tyson's driver pulled up in a white Mercedes-Benz and parked the car in a spot reserved for the club owner's wife, Devine said. Devine said he asked the driver to move the car and the driver started to do so. Just then, Tyson, who was attending a function at the Palace, ran out of the club and started yelling at him. Devine said Tyson hit him three times in the stomach with the back of his hand. The city attorney declined to prosecute Tyson on misdemeanor assault charges saying there was not enough evidence for a conviction. Tyson has denied hitting Devine. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Actor Nicolas Cage is the proud owner of a 1920s castle, complete with at turret, in the Hollywood Hills, a newspaper reported Sunday. The sloe-eyed, 25-year-old actor known for his oddball roles in movies such as ``Raising Arizona, ``Moonstruck'' and ``Wild at Heart,'' has purchased the 5,367-square-foot residence in the Los Feliz neighborhood, according to the Los Angeles Times. The castle sits atop a promontory with a 360-degree city view and the master suite has a black marble fireplace. The 11-room home has three bedrooms, 4{ bathrooms and a maid's quarters, according to the listing by Dorothy Carter and Jodi Hodges of Douglas Properties. The house was listed for $1,695,000. Cage paid about $1.5 million for the gated property, the newspaper said. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Deposed New York Yankee boss George Steinbrenner took to the airwaves as host of ``Saturday Night Live,'' joking about his fondness for firing underlings and the World Series upset win by the Cincinnati Reds. In one skit on Saturday's show, he was a store manager who can't bring himself to dismiss an inefficient employee. ``I can't fire people,'' he says. ``It's just not in my nature.'' ``Where is it written that if you don't get results right away you fire someone? ... Only a jackass would do that.'' The opening sequence featured him dreaming that the New York Yankees were completing a sweep of the World Series: George Steinbrenner pitching to catcher George Steinbrenner, George on first, George on second, George as shortstop, George on third .... The show came on just minutes after the Cincinnati Reds - managed by ex-Yankee manager Lou Piniella - finished their unexpected World Series sweep of the Oakland Athletics. ``I want you to be the first to know,'' he said. ``At 11:15 tonight I bought the Cincinnati Reds.'' --- SANTA FE, N.M. (AP) - Academy Award-winning actress Greer Garson was honored with a film studio in her name and she said she hopes it will spread ``understanding and peacemaking among all peoples.'' Hundreds of actors and prominent New Mexicans turned out Saturday evening for a dinner to commemorate the opening of the Greer Garson Communications Center and Studios at the College of Santa Fe. Miss Garson, 82, was unable to attend because she was recovering from the flu at her Dallas home. But in a telephone call to the audience, she said wants the center to advance the cause of communication around the world. ``The true value of communication is spreading understanding and peacemaking among all peoples,'' she said. ``I'm very proud indeed to be part of the program.'' The center at CSF was built with a $3 million gift from Miss Garson and her late husband, E.E. ``Buddy'' Fogelson. Among the 650 attending the dinner were actor Cesar Romero, master of ceremonies Art Linkletter, actor turned producer Tab Hunter, and Ray Buktenica, star of television's ``Life Goes On,'' who is an alumnus of the college. ``She's a dear lady,'' said Romero, who co-starred with Miss Garson in the 1948 film ``Julia Misbehaves.'' Romero and others agreed that while Miss Garson is well known for her acting career, including her 1942 Oscar winning performance in ``Mrs. Miniver,'' the studio will be a more enduring legacy. ``She was a great actress,'' said New Mexico Gov. Garrey Carruthers. ``While we enjoy her films, her philanthropy is what will endear New Mexicans to her.'' --- SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Actress Claire Bloom says she doesn't understand how actors ``slog on'' in long-running Broadway plays. ``I haven't left the theater. It left me,'' says the 59-year-old actress, who nonetheless maintains a hectic schedule. ``The plays are not that interesting, the theater district in New York is a horror and the audiences aren't that terrific there. It's only when you go off Broadway that you still have enthusiastic people, younger people and interesting things.'' In an interview published Sunday in the San Francisco Examiner, Bloom said she hates repeating a performance night after night but she will do a short, six-week run. During the last week or so, Bloom has performed performance in Washington, D.C., and three nights with the Los Angeles Symphony as a narrator for Mendelssohn's version of ``A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' On Monday, she is scheduled to appear at San Francisco's Herbst Theatre in her one-woman show, ``Then Let Men Know: A Portrait of Shakespeare's Women.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Children Die in Cleveland House Fire
DOC.TEXT: A fire trapped five children in their upstairs bedrooms early Sunday, and all five died of smoke inhalation, authorities said. A woman and her son survived the fire by jumping from a second-floor window, said Fire Investigator Albert Lugo. The woman was hospitalized in fair condition with burns. The blaze began on the first floor of the 2{-story frame dwelling in a working-class neighborhood, Lugo said. Firefighters found the house engulfed in flames when they arrived. The fire drove back firefighters attempting to rescue people inside, Lugo said. The cause of the fire remained under investigation, he said. The dead, four boys and a girl, ranged in age from 2 to 12, said Cuyahoga County Coroner Elizabeth K. Balraj.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli-Allied Militiamen Kill Four Guerrillas
With AM-Israel-Violence, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israeli-allied militiamen on Sunday killed four Lebanese guerrillas in a firefight north of Israel's self-proclaimed security zone in Lebanon, Israeli army officials said. The guerrillas were first seen by an Israeli army patrol before dawn Sunday near Shaba, a village in the zone's eastern sector about a mile north of the Israeli border, a military official said on condition of anonymity. The patrol fired and the guerrillas retreated to the north, apparently planning to leave the security zone, he said. In the morning, Israeli soldiers backed by Israeli-trained South Lebanon Army militiamen found the guerrillas' tracks and launched a pursuit, the official said. ``About four kilometers (2.4 miles) north of the zone, a South Lebanon Army unit came in contact with the guerrillas and killed them in a short firefight,'' he said. No militia casualties were reported. The guerrillas were armed with the assault rifles and carried explosives, the official said. It was not immediately clear to which organization they belonged. Israel carved out the 2- to 10-mile-wide security zone as a buffer protecting its northern border against guerrilla raids in 1985, when it withdrew the bulk of its forees from Lebanon after a three-year occupation. The zone is jointly patrolled by Israeli soldiers and some 2,500 members of the mostly Christian South Lebanon Army, which is financed by Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnapped Former Premier's Letters Reflect Bitterness, Despair
By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: The discovery of 46 letters written by Aldo Moro while held by Red Brigades terrorists has reopened old wounds from the sensational 1978 kidnap and murder of the former prime minister. While shedding little new light on the abduction and slaying, publication of the letters was a chilling reminder of Moro's bitterness and frustration over the refusal of his Christian Democrat Party to negotiate his release. ``I have been killed three times: by insufficient protection, refusal to negotiate, inconclusive politics,'' he wrote. Moro, kidnapped on March 16, 1978, was murdered 55 days later and his bullet-riddled body dumped in teh trunk of a car in downtown Rome. Photocopies of 421 pages of Moro's letters to family members, friends and political figures were discovered Oct. 9 in a Milan apartment that served as a hideout for the leftist Red Brigades in the 1970s. The safe house had reportedly been used by some of the terrorists who kidnapped Moro. Police said the letters, along with two guns, 30 detonators and $50,000 in cash, were discovered by chance by workers who were restoring the apartment and found the material in a hollow space behind a wall. Political leaders, however, say they are convinced the letters did not turn up by accident. They question how police could have missed the hiding place when they raided the apartment in 1978 and arrested three Red Brigades members. Some say they believe the letters were planted in the apartment later, possibly very recently, in an attempt to discredit certain political figures, especially President Francesco Cossiga. Senate President Giovanni Spadolini, who was a close friend of Moro, suggested Friday that the sudden appearance of the letters was a maneuver to destabilize politicial institutions and leaders. Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti said Saturday he shared Spadolini's suspicions and promised authorities would find out who is responsible. Otherwise, he said, ``someone will have to go'' - a comment newspapers described as a threat to fire secret service chiefs. The speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, Nilde Iotti, suggested that Parliament hold a special debate to examine the circumstances surrounding the appearance of the letters. Political commentators said the main target of the alleged plot appeared to be Cossiga, who was interior minister at the time of the abduction. In one of the letters, Moro criticized Cossiga as being ``out of place ... hypnotized'' by Andreotti and Communist Party leader Enrico Berlinguer. Cossiga's office said he would not comment out of respect for the privacy of Moro's family, which sought in vain to prevent the publication of the letters. Arnaldo Forlani, secretary of the Christian Democrats, visited Cossiga over the weekend to offer the party's solidarity. The contents of the letters reiterate much of what had emerged earlier from other letters, documents and trials. Other than the attack on Cossiga, the Italian media have focused on Moro's jibes against other Christian Democrat colleagues. Moro wrote that Andreotti, who was also premier at the time, ``moved with ease in relations with colleagues from the CIA.'' He described the then Christian Democrat leader, Benigno Zaccagnini, as ``the most fragile secretary'' in the party's history. During his captivity, Moro sent numerous letters to his party and leading political figures asking them to negotiate an exchange of ``political prisoners'' with the Red Brigades. The government rejected negotiations. Moro was kidnapped shortly after he arranged the ``historic compromise'' with the Communist Party. The accord gave the Communists a direct say in running the government for the first time since early after World War II. The deal collapsed after about nine months.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Politician Assassinated in Punjab
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen on Sunday assassinated a moderate Sikh politician in an ambush near his farm in Punjab state, where Sikh militants are fighting for independence from India, police said. Police said Shishpal Singh, a former state Cabinet minister and four-term legislator, was killed instantly in gunfire from five or six weapons. The attackers, hiding in a sugar cane field, fired on Singh's car as it left the farm, seven miles north of the state capital of Amritsar, said police Superintendent P.S. Gill. Singh's bodyguard, who was in the back seat, returned fire, but the gunmen escaped. Singh, 70, belonged to the Badal political faction, which has been targeted by the militants for its moderate position. In other scattered incidents in Punjab, 11 people were reported killed in terrorist actions or clashes between militants and police, news agencies said Sunday. Sikh extremists have killed more than 2,400 people this year, making this the deadliest year since they began a separatist insurrection in 1983. Sikhs have a slight majority in Punjab, a rich farming state bordering Pakistan, though they are only 2 percent of the 880 million people in Hindu-dominated India.

DOC.HEAD: Battleship Heads To Mothballs Carrying Heroic and Tragic Past
With AM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
LaserPhoto RM1
DOC.TEXT: Enemy planes and artillery could not sink the battleship USS Iowa, but budget tightening and the costly damage left by a tragic explosion are sending the proud ship back into mothballs. The decommissioning Friday will be the third for the Iowa since it sailed into combat in World War II, and crew members are looking on the event with sadness, says the ship's commander. ``This crew today would like nothing more than someone to say: `That's it. Reverse course. You are to make preparations to sail for the Persian Gulf,''' said Cmdr. John P. Morse. But that order is not likely to come. In an effort to cut costs in face of a rising budget deficit, the Navy has decided the Iowa is expendable. The USS New Jersey also is being mothballed, leaving only two battleships in active service, the Missouri and the Wisconsin. In addition to the cost of operating a battleship, more than $35 million a year, the Iowa has another strike against it: the expensive scars of the April 19, 1989, explosion in one of its massive gun turrets that killed 47 sailors. The Navy concluded the explosion probably was sabotage by a gunner's mate who died in the explosion, but a congressional inquiry found the report to be lacking. Earlier this year, the Navy reopened its investigation. The explosion did not seriously damage the ship itself, but it would cost $13 million to repair turret No. 2. In its glory days in World War II, the Iowa's 16-inch guns hammered shore fortifications on South Pacific islands, hurling 2,000-pound shells more than 20 miles. During the bombardment of the Marshall Islands in March 1944, the Iowa took two hits from Japanese shore batteries. Henry Schwartz was three decks down in turret No. 2 when the first shell landed that month. ``I didn't feel the impact. One shell hit on the turret, the other on the deck. One guy got hit by a piece of shrapnel, and that was it,'' said Schwartz, 72, of Indianapolis. A fist-sized dent high on the port side of the turret still marks the Japanese shell's impact. When the war ended the following year, the Iowa entered Tokyo harbor as part of the fleet accepting the Japanese surrender. ``We were all at general quarters wondering what was going to happen ... whether they really were going to surrender or what. It was pretty tense,'' said retired Capt. Frank Sellers Jr., 77, of San Diego. He served as the Iowa's gunnery officer in the closing days of the war. The ship was put in mothballs following the war, but was recalled in 1951 for the Korean conflict. It was retired again in 1957. With the planned buildup to a 600-ship Navy under President Reagan, the Iowa was recalled and refitted as a launch platform for cruise missiles. Its 16-inch guns were just an added benefit, said Capt. Fred Moosally, the ship's commander at the time of the turret explosion. Its 17-inch armor was thought impervious to any conventional weapons, such as the type of missile that damaged several British ships during the Falklands War with Argentina and killed more than 30 sailors aboard the frigate USS Stark in the Persian Gulf. ``Any tinhorn dictator has access to those types of weapons,'' said former Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. ``The ship to send to a crisis area is a battleship. We ought to have learned that from the Stark and the Samuel Roberts.'' The Roberts was damaged by a mine in the gulf. To Morse, the reasons for keeping the Iowa in the Navy are more visceral: ``This ship has an excitement and a life to it and an emotional attraction to it more than any of the five ships on which I have served. ``We are very mindful of the thousands of men who have come before us on this ship. We try very hard to preserve their integrity and honor. We think we have done that.''

DOC.HEAD: Mitchell Says Only Congress Can Declare War in Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, insisting only Congress has the right to declare war, said Sunday congressional leaders are prepared to return from their break if a crisis flares in the Persian Gulf. Mitchell, D-Maine, reiterated a position that has put Congress at odds with top Bush administration officials. With more than 200,000 American troops based in Saudi Arabia, lawmakers and the White House are tussling over which one has the constitutional right to commit the nation to war. ``It is important to remember that under the American Constitution, the president has no legal authority - none whatsoever - to commit the United States to war,'' Mitchell said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program. ``Only Congress can make that grave decision,'' he said. ``And in this respect, if the United States is to be committed to war, it requires action by Congress.'' Mitchell said he and House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., have considered several measures that would bring Congress back into session should that become necessary because of the Persian Gulf crisis. Congress is supposed to quit for the year after finishing the 1991 budget, probably this week, and stay away until mid-January. Secretary of State James A. Baker III told senators last week that the administration would consult with Congress if military action were needed in the gulf. But he refused to commit the administration to getting any advance congressional approval for any action. The administration contends President Bush, as the commander in chief of the military, has the right to declare war. Moreover, Baker told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, that advance notification to Congress could deprive the military of any surprise factor. In an attempt to clarify the constitutional conflict after the Vietnam War, Congress passed the War Powers Resolution in 1973. It requires the president to consult with Congress before deploying troops into hostilities or when hostilities are imminent. Within 48 hours of deploying troops, the president must file a report to Congress. Additionally, U.S. forces must be withdrawn after 60 days if Congress has not voted its approval. Meanwhile Sunday, the Pentagon said it had no information about a report that Iraqi troops, tanks and armored vehicles have been pulling out of parts of Kuwait, positioning themselves closer to Kuwait's major oil field in the Matla region. But Lt. Col. Steve Roy, a Pentagon spokesman, said the report, which appeared in the newspaper Al-Khaleej, printed in the Sharjah, one of the United Arab Emirates, was ``entirely possible'' because Iraqi troops are continually repositioning themselves inside occupied Kuwait. U.S. officials estimate the Iraqis have put some 400,000 troops in or around Kuwait since Iraqi President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. In other gulf developments: - The Pentagon confirmed the destroyer O'Brien fired a warning shot across the bow of an Iraqi tanker in the gulf Saturday. U.S. Navy officials then intercepted the ship, boarded it and allowed it to proceed. There have been roughly a half-dozen warning shot episodes since Aug. 2. - The Middle East Policy Survey, a newsletter published in Washington, reported that a few days before Saddam invaded Kuwait, Bush sent a message to the Iraqi president. The message expressed the administration's concern for Saddam's troop movements, but said the United States wanted improved U.S.-Iraqi bilateral relations. April Glaspie, the U.S. ambassador in Iraq, delivered the message to Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and Saddam's son-in-law, Hussein Kamal, the paper said. Kamal is the minister of military industries. The Washington Post in Sunday's editions quoted sources as confirming that Bush wrote a presidential message which was supposed to be relayed to Saddam through Glaspie. The message was transmitted to the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad on July 28, the Post said. The newspaper said the exact wording of the Bush document could not be learned, but sources said it was a mixed message on policy towards Iraq. White House officials could not be reached immediately for comment on the report. - The Washington Post also reported Sunday that Iraqi military forces are beginning to learn how to operate sophisticated U.S. Hawk anti-aircraft missiles and radars that were captured in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Second Jogger Trial to Open; Defense Cites Defendants' IQ
DOC.TEXT: The second trial in the case of the Central Park jogger opens Monday with the defense claiming that incriminating statements at the heart of the prosecution's case were coerced from mentally deficient boys. But the prosecution will contend - as it did in the first trial - that the two teen-age defendants voluntarily and knowingly made the admissions, and that they convict themselves with their own words. There are two defendants on trial this time: Kharey Wise, 18, and Kevin Richardson, 16. There were among six teens who were charged with attempted murder and gang rape in the highly publicized attack on a female jogger in Central Park on April 19, 1989. They also are charged in attacks on two male joggers that night. In August, the first trial ended in the conviction of three teens for rape, first-degree assault, robbery and riot, and acquittals on the charges of attempted murder and sodomy. Yusef Salaam, Raymond Santana and Antron McCray, all 16, received 5-to-10-year sentences, the maximum for juvenile offenders. The victim, now 30, suffered brain damage and testified at the trial of the first three defendants that she has no memory of the attack, that she has lost her sense of smell and that her sense of balance is impaired. Despite her lingering problems, she has returned to her job at the Salomon Brothers investiment firm, where she is now a vice president. Like the first trial, the second will feature written and videotaped statements the youths made to police and prosecutors after their arrests. In his statements to police, Richardson denied he attacked the female jogger. He said he tried to help her and that she scratched his cheek when he got between her and the other youths. Wise made two videotapes. In the first he admitted only that he was with a marauding gang of about 30 youths. In the second, which he asked to make, he admitted he participated in the attack. Wise's attorney, Colin Moore, said he and his client's mother, Dolores Wise, have rejected plea negotiations because they are convinced the teen-ager is innocent. But Moore was rebuffed Friday when he asked state Supreme Court Justice Thomas Galligan to allow expert testimony that his client is not intelligent enough to have knowingly and meaningfully waived his Miranda rights against self-incrimination. Supreme Court in New York state is a trial-level court. Moore said Wise has an overall intelligence quotient of 73. He cited cases in which appeals courts held that defendants with an IQ of less than 75 did not have the capacity to understand what waiving their rights would mean. Galligan said the motion was too late because by law it should have been made within 30 days of arraignment. He said he saw no reason to waive that deadline. Richardson's lawyer, Howard Diller, has said similar things about his client. At the teen-ager's arraignment, Diller told the judge that Richardson ``is not what you and I would call `all there.' '' Wise, 16 at the time of the attacks, faces adult penalties that could total up to 57 years in prison if he is convicted on all counts. Richardson, 14 when he was arrested, faces the same five to 10 years as the three youths in the first trial.

DOC.HEAD: Day Care Worker Sentenced to 10 Years' Probation for Formula Spiking
DOC.TEXT: A former day care center employee has been sentenced to 10 years' probation for spiking an infant's formula with rubbing alcohol because she was angry at co-workers. Patricia Ann Escarenio, 21, pleaded guilty to injury to a child in connection with the April 24 incident and was sentenced Friday by State District Judge Mike Wilkinson. She also was fined $5,000. The 4-month-old boy who drank the formula was hospitalized but authorities said he suffered no lasting effects because he vomited the concoction. Assistant District Attorney Carol Davies said authorities believe Ms. Escarenio was angered at the boy's mother, her co-worker at Chuckles & Grins day care center, because of a job assignment that day. Later that day, Ms. Escarenio checked herself into the psychiatric unit of St. Joseph Hospital and admitted tainting the bottle, Ms. Davies said.

DOC.HEAD: Shutdown Set For Last Reactor in Old East Germany
DOC.TEXT: The new German government will shut down the last Soviet-made nuclear reactor in what was East Germany because the reactor is unsafe, an Environment Ministry spokesman said Sunday. The spokesman, Berthold Goeke, said in a telephone interview from Bonn that the last operating reactor at the Greifswald power plant in northeastern Germany would be shut down by mid-December. Three other reactors at the Greifswald plant and another reactor at an older plant in Rheinsberg, just north of Berlin, were shut down earlier this year. All are Soviet-designed plants. Soviet-designed nuclear power plants throughout Eastern Europe have come under heavy criticism from Western environmental officials for failing to meet safety standards. The use of nuclear power is a sensitive issue in Germany, which has a powerful network of anti-nuclear groups. The 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster in the Soviet Union helped fuel the anti-nuclear movement. Goeke said it would be too expensive to modernize the Greifswald plant to make it safe and would take nearly two months to shut it down. The Greifswald and Rheinsberg plants also fail to meet European Community nuclear safety standards that took effect when the Germanys united Oct. 3. Goeke said security inspectors have found that the East German plants were not properly maintained and often were poorly constructed. The environment ministers of both Germanys had decided in the spring to shut down all nuclear power reactors in what was then East Germany. Environment Minister Klaus Toepfer informed the Soviet government of the decision during a visit to Moscow just after unification. Goeke said the German government had allocated $20 million to build an oil-fueled heating plant in the Greifswald region to make up for the loss of power when the reactor is shut down. The oil-fueled plant is scheduled to start operating in mid-December. In June, officials shut down part of Greifswald because of safety problems. They said the plant management had permitted operation of a power-producing block at the plant even though a leak had been discovered in what they called its cleaning system. The magazine Der Spiegel reported in January that a nuclear accident had narrowly been averted at Greifswald in 1976, when fire destroyed some electrical cables, disabling all but one of 12 water-cooling pumps in one of the plant's four power-producing blocks. The five states on the territory of East Germany derive only 10 percent of their electricity from nuclear power. The majority of their power plants are fueled by brown coal, which has seriously polluted much of eastern Germany. Clouds of the noxious brown coal emissions also float into western Germany, prompting protests from environmental activitists.

DOC.HEAD: Convict Charged in Alleged Racial Shooting Goes on Trial
DOC.TEXT: Joseph O'Cain remembers lying on the parking lot, unable to move as he watched his best friend stumble toward the grocery store door and collapse. His friend, Darren Jessie, had been shot in the head, fatally. O'Cain also had been shot, and left paralyzed from the waist down by a bullet in the spine. Two months after the March 31 shooting in rural Theodore, sheriff's deputies arrested a white convict who had been out of prison on parole only a few weeks before the incident. They said he shot Jessie and O'Cain because he hated blacks. Daniel Amos Pilot, 34, goes on trial Monday charged with murder in Jessie's death and attempted murder in the crippling of O'Cain. District Attorney Chris Galanos says the state will present evidence that the shootings were racially motivated, but has provided no elaboration. Pilot's lawyer says his client is not racist and was not at the shooting. O'Cain says he and Jessie, 21, were listening to the radio, sitting in a car belonging to Jessie's girlfriend and waiting for her to get off work. The store is in a predominantly white unincorporated area on the western edge of Mobile. ``I never thought I'd be shot,'' said O'Cain, now 18 and struggling to adjust to life in a wheelchair and finish his final year at Blount High School. He said a man approached the car and asked them for marijuana. ``We don't mess around with weed,'' O'Cain said. ``He shot me in the back and I just fell. I never lost consciousness. Darren was walking toward the store already shot.'' He said he didn't know his assailant, but said he recognized Pilot as the shooter. ``Some whites out there are good and some are bad; some blacks out there are good and some are bad,'' O'Cain said. ``I don't want this hyped into some kind of prejudice thing.'' Cautious about being in the public spotlight, O'Cain thinks his attacker should receive the ultimate sentence - ``I think he should get the chair.'' However, the charges against Pilot do not carry a death sentence. But he is classified as a ``habitual offender,'' having served prison terms in Alabama and Mississippi, which could bring a maximum sentence of life in prison without the chance of parole if convicted. State officials said Pilot was paroled March 12, after serving about a third of a 12-year sentence for receiving stolen property. He reportedly was arrested based on information supplied to sheriff's deputies by an informant. Jim Zeigler, Pilot's court-appointed lawyer, said, ``They've got the wrong man.'' He said Pilot planned to present an alibi. ``He says he wasn't there and doesn't know anything about it.'' The attorney also said Pilot is not a racist and has affidavits from two black inmates saying he never hated blacks. Jessie's mother, Catherine McCants, said her son went to summer school to obtain his diploma from Blount High School and had joined the Army before he was shot. She said he had been scheduled to leave for military service the month after the shooting. Jessie had worked at odd jobs around Mobile, while O'Cain hoped to become a brick mason, a job that attracts many black craftsmen in this Gulf Coast area. O'Cain's mother, Jacqueline McQuay, said that after her son was crippled they had to give up their apartment in a housing project because it had stairs that could not be negotiated with a wheelchair. They moved in with a relative. O'Cain has been going to physical therapy twice a week. A van takes him to high school classes. Michael Davis, a counselor at the Independent Living Center, said, ``He's just doing extremely well and not harboring any resentment.''

DOC.HEAD: State Attorney General Goes On Trial
DOC.TEXT: Arkansas' attorney general goes on trial Monday in a case that could see judges, legislators, reporters and the governor called to the witness stand. Whether Attorney General Steve Clark goes to jail may depend on whether state law required him to report expenditures on his state-issued Visa card and to be accurate and honest when he did so. There was no such law, his attorney says. And Clark claims that discrepancies in his state expense account records are no more than bookkeeping errors. Clark, 43, is charged with one count of felony theft by deception. If convicted, he could be sentenced to 20 years in jail and fined up to $15,000. He was charged July 11 and released without bond. He reported as business expenditures on his state credit card meals with people who say they didn't eat with him or that it wasn't business. Some who ate with him said they paid the tab. The allegations forced Clark in February to give up his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for governor, improving Gov. Bill Clinton's re-election chances. The state says Clark was financially strapped but wined and dined family, friends, girlfriends and benefactors. Prosecutors say political contributions he sought at some of the meals ended up in his habitually overdrawn personal checking account. A congressman, a federal appeals court judge, two state Supreme Court justices, lobbyists, former Clark employees, more than a half-dozen members of the Little Rock media and at least 14 state lawmakers are on the state's witness list. Most of them were listed by Clark as dining guests. Clark, who is finishing his 12th year in office, has admitted record-keeping errors. ``I made a mistake. There's no doubt about it. It was an honest mistake but I made a mistake,'' Clark said Jan. 31, the day he reimbursed the state $3,951.29. ``I am sorry, and I apologize.'' He said records of the lunch and dinner meetings were reconstructed from notes, his calendar, receipts or memory. He said he spent less than 30 minutes every 60 to 90 days attempting to put together the expense reports. The attorney general, whose job includes giving state agencies his interpretation of the state Constitution and statutes, said he wasn't required to keep those records. State employees are required to report and itemize travel and meal expenses. But elected officials who hold offices named in the Constitution have long been thought to be exempt from that requirement. Pulaski County Prosecutor Chris Piazza says Clark entertained supporters on the taxpayers' tab to generate campaign contributions that ended up in his pocket. ``To support his lifestyle, he would wine and dine some of his biggest contributors at the state's expense,'' Piazza said at a pretrial hearing. The attorney general's salary is $26,500, among the lowest for the office in the nation, as mandated by the Arkansas Constitution. Clark also gets $1,250 a month in public relations money from the state with no itemized accounting required. His deposits in a personal checking account for three years beginning July 1986 were at least twice as much as his net income, a state auditor, James Ridgell, said at a pretrial hearing. Clark deposited less money in each of those three years than he withdrew, Ridgell said. The auditor said $28,564 of state money was spent by Clark on nonbusiness or personal expenses in the same three years. He also said Democratic National Committee member Ed Miller of Texarkana donated $14,000 to Clark or his campaign in the three-year period. The money was almost immediately put in Clark's personal account to pay bills, including an electric bill 18 months overdue. Miller, U.S. Circuit Judge Richard S. Arnold and U.S. Rep. Tommy Robinson, R-Ark., are among the 249 people subpoenaed for the trial, which is expected to last three weeks.

DOC.HEAD: University of Missouri Ordered to Shut Down Nuclear Research Project
DOC.TEXT: An administrative judge for the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission has ordered the University of Missouri to shut down a nuclear research project, citing a possibility of danger to the public. Administrative Judge Peter B. Bloch said in an order issued Saturday that the university had failed to comply with nuclear licensing regulations. ``Hence, I presume that the activities are unduly dangerous to public safety,'' he wrote. Bloch noted that a fire battalion chief had indicated he would respond to fires at the laboratory but ``might stand by while the laboratory burned'' because he had not been supplied with a firefighting plan. Bloch said that problem alone would have swayed him to stop the project. The project involves efforts to separate the most long-lived elements of nuclear waste from short-lived ones that will soon lose their radioactivity. Environmental groups and 10 individuals had challenged the university's request to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for changes in its nuclear licenses. The changes were needed for the project. University spokesman Mary Still said lawyers for the school hoped to file documents or talk with the judge Monday to end the temporary shutdown order. Still said the university had complied with all federal regulations regarding the project. ``We have an excellent safety record,'' she said. Mark Haim, director of the Mid-Missouri Nuclear Weapons Freeze, said the judge's order was good news. ``We are very pleased. It validates what we've been saying all along.'' The project began about Feb. 1 and will take four years, said Truman Storvick, principal investigator for the project. The university is working under a contract for the project with Rockwell International, an aerospace, electronics and automotive technology corporation based in California. The project is jointly sponsored by the U.S. Department of Energy and Japanese firms.

DOC.HEAD: Diver Dies in Wreck of USS San Diego
DOC.TEXT: A diver was killed when he ran out of air in the wreck of the U.S.S. San Diego, a World War I cruiser submerged upside down 15 miles off the Long Island coast, police said. The diver, whose name was not immediately released, became separated from a group shortly after 10 a.m. Saturday while inside the wreckage. He was found a short time later entangled in a guide line with an empty air tank, Suffolk County police said. At least seven divers are known to have lost their lives in the 13,600-ton ship, which lies 80 feet below the surface off the coast of Fire Island. The San Diego is the only U.S. ship sunk by the Germans in World War I. Six crewmen died during the 1918 attack, caused either by a torpedo or a mine laid by a U-boat, and 1,108 crew were rescued.

DOC.HEAD: Curfew in Place to Quell Riots In Nicaragua's Caribbean Region
DOC.TEXT: The government imposed a curfew in a large area along Nicaragua's northeast Caribbean coast after rioting and looting broke out there last week, an official said here Sunday. Information Minister Danilo Lacayo told reporters that authorities had taken control of the situation in the autonomous region about 450 miles northeast of the capital. But he refused to disclose what happened there. Newspapers and other media in Managua said riots broke out Thursday because of food and other shortages in Puerto Cabezas, 450 miles northeast of Managua, and that several people were killed. News reports from the isolated, sparsely populated Atlantic Coast have been contradictory. The area, inhabited mostly by English-speaking descendants of escaped slaves and Miskito, Sumo and Rama Indians, has been isolated from the rest of Nicaragua for centuries. Sources said the 11 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew was imposed Friday. Most government officials refused to provide information about the riots, and there are no telephone links to Puerto Cabezas, the main port in the region. The newspaper La Prensa and other pro-government media accused the opposition Sandinistas of setting off the riots. The Sandinista media claimed some 300 former Contra rebels of the Yatama Indian organization did the rioting. Radio Sandino said in a broadcast Saturday night the former Contras looted a warehouse in Puerto Cabezas belonging to a Moravian Protestant church and stole food there. The Contras, including various Indian groups, were backed by the United States in their fight to overthrow the Sandinistas during the decade the leftist party was in power. President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro led a coalition that defeated the Sandinistas in Feb. 25 elections. Since taking office April 25 she has struggled to pull the country out of a grave economic crisis. Under a deal between the government and the Sandinistas, the Nicaraguan Defense Ministry is still controlled by Gen. Humberto Ortega, a former Sandinista official. The Contras were disbanded shortly after Ms. Barrios de Chamorro took office, but many of them are having a hard time finding jobs and settling down. There have been reports that a few former rebels were still launching attacks against the government.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Hostage in Tehran Embassy a Quiet Celebrity in Saudi Arabia
LaserPhoto DHA5
DOC.TEXT: This is Marine Lt. Steve Kirtley's second time in a Middle East crisis with no rotation date out. But last time, as a hostage in Iran, he was less confident of getting home. ``I don't understand why some of the younger Marines are so set on going home right away,'' said Kirtley, of Little Rock, Ark., shaking a close-cropped blond head that is fit for a recruiting poster. At 32, he leads a combat supply company. On Nov. 4, 1979, he was asleep at the Marine guards' quarters at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran when 5,000 Iranians stormed the walls and seized all 52 Americans inside. As a young corporal, he spent 444 days helping calm others while he was just as worried himself. It has made him a better man, he said, but he still does not like waiting around. ``I sit and I think about the waiting,'' he said of his experience now in the desert. ``It's kind of like being a hostage. We're here, and we don't know when the hell we're going home. But we have it a little better. At least I know I'm going home.'' Kirtley, who now oversees trucks, learned the hard way what Middle East deserts can do to machines. During the hostage ordeal, a U.S. helicopter rescue attempt failed when three helicopters were disabled in a sandstorm and other aircraft were thwarted by dust. The mission, dubbed Desert One, was aborted when the blade of a helicopter fouled by sand struck a C130 transport plane and triggered a ball of flame which lit up the nighttime sky. After Iran, he lectured to potential recruits. He decided to be a drill instructor in San Diego. Then he was accepted for officer training at the University of Florida in Gainesville. He was stationed in Hawaii and Camp Pendleton, Calif. For the last 62 days, he was been within striking distance of the Iraq border with the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force. Kirtley is a moviemaker's Marine, 200 pounds of sculpted bulk, with corn-colored hair on a sunburned neck. As a football player, he played lineman for the University of Florida in a Gator Bowl. Strict Saudi customs don't bother him. He doesn't drink anyway, and says his wife's letters are all the female companionship he needs. Kirtley's past has made him a celebrity among the older hands. For most younger Marines, America's last hostage crisis is vague history. ``They want to know about it,'' he said. ``They ask what happened, what I did, how it was.'' Mostly, Kirtley is concerned with getting freight on the road. His trucks move ammunition, water, food and fuel to Marine units scattered across a wide sweep of Arabian sands. He speaks proudly how the service support group has driven 500,000 miles while moving 27 million pounds in two months. Sometimes the idea of imminent war seems to recede, but Kirtley knows the dangers. In three days, he noted, the Marines will commemorate the 1983 Beirut terrorist bombing which killed 241 of their comrades. Kirtley's unit is better off than some, with hot food and a small post exchange nearby. Outside his camouflage-netting tent, a smaller shelter is jokingly labeled in large letters, ``HBO Available.'' ``I'm luckier, with a company to command,'' he said. ``I can sit around at night and worry about things ... It keeps me busy.'' He also thinks about the occasions he is missing. His birthday was Oct. 18. His wedding anniversary was Aug. 23. Asked if he had a word for his mother in Little Rock, Kirtley allowed himself a rare, brief smile. He replied: ``Tell her, `Hi, Mom. I'm doing a little better than the last time I was here, and I hope to be home sooner.''
