Fewer Dropouts Seek GED Diplomas
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 3rd graf, ``The number xxx to CORRECT Develop to Development in name of organization
DOC.TEXT: Educators say evidence that fewer dropouts seek high school equivalency diplomas may threaten the nation's economic future. In a study of diploma candidates, the American Council on Education found 683,000 took the tests during 1989, 7 percent less than in 1988 and less than 1.3 percent of the 43 million adults over 18 without a high school diploma. The number of candidates aged 18 to 24 declined by 26 percent, and only half of the drop may be due to the 12.5 percent decrease in the size of the U.S. population within that age range during this period, according to the study released Sunday by the council's General Educational Development (GED) Testing Service. ``If young people are choosing to work rather than complete their schooling, the price may be high for both individuals and society -individuals lose opportunities for additional training, advanced education, better jobs, and higher wages, while society loses the increased productivity of better educated, more highly skilled workers,'' said the study. ``In order to qualify for training, further education, jobs, and higher earnings, these adults must have opportunities to earn high school diplomas.'' Earning diplomas were 376,000 who took the tests, which represents about 18 percent of all high school diplomas awarded that year, said the study. Program director Douglas R. Whitney and Janet Baldwin, senior research associate, said the study showed a great need for more outreach efforts to increase access to programs for high school completion. ``The GED is the gateway to educational and economic opportunity for millions of Americans,'' said Whitney. ``It's a matter of national concern that too many adults who would benefit from these opportunities find their paths blocked by obstacles that could be removed by more enlightened policies and programs to facilitate their participation.'' Since 1942, the GED program has been recognized nationwide by employers and colleges. Adults must surpass the performance of about 30 percent of a national sample of graduating high school seniors to earn equivalency diplomas and qualify for college enrollment, training programs, jobs and job advancement. In other key findings, the study showed: -About 200,000 adults, or 33 percent of candidates in 1989, took the GED Tests primarily to meet educational admissions requirements, compared with 29.1 percent in 1980. -The percentage of candidates who took the tests for employment reasons declined from 38.6 percent in 1980 to 32.2 percent in 1989. -The proportion of Hispanic candidates increased from 6.8 percent in 1980 to 11.2 percent in 1989, while the percentage of black candidates fell from 17.1 percent in 1980 to 14.2 percent in 1989. -The percentage of GED candidates who reported having left school due to pregnancy or marriage tripled. In 1989, one in five adults taking the GED Tests, 19.7 percent, cited this reason as the most important, compared with 6.4 percent in 1980. -In 1980, 68.5 percent and in 1989, 69.9 percent reported having completed 10th grade or higher before leaving high school, while 36.9 percent in 1980 and 38.6 percent in 1989 reported having completed 11th grade or higher. -About three of every four candidates reported having grades while in school of ``mostly 'C' or better'' in both 1980, 76.8 percent and 1989, 74 percent. More than one in five candidates reported in-school grades of ``mostly 'B' or better''in 1980, 23.2 percent and in 1989, 21.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Chiles Runs a Crusade That May Hurt Him
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 2nd graf, ``Gov. Bob Martinex xxx to update fund-raising figure from $9 million to $10.2 million
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Lawton Chiles has made his run for Florida governor a crusade against big-money politics, and now he may have to pay the price. Gov. Bob Martinez has waged a $9 million campaign, erased his opponent's lead and is on the move with sharp attacks on Chiles' Senate record. ``We've gone up, and my opponent has declined, and the campaign is where it was about this time in 1986,'' said a delighted Martinez. Four years ago, Republican Martinez defeated Democrat Steve Pajcic, becoming only the second GOP governor in Florida since Reconstruction. Chiles held double-digit leads in the polls shortly after he joined the race last April. He and running mate Buddy MacKay declared a campaign against the politics of special interests. Chiles has a self-imposed $100 limit on contributions. Some 59,000 people - by far a state record - have donated to his campaign. But the approach has brought in just over $4 million. The latest polls show the race a dead heat. In recent days, Martinez has sought to capitalize on the federal budget mess, calling Chiles and MacKay ``Washington insiders'' and members of ``the liberal Eastern establishment.'' Chiles was Senate budget chairman when he retired and MacKay is a former three-term congressman. Chiles retired at the end of his third Senate term in January 1989. Chiles suggests Martinez is the insider and that it's time for a change. ``I think he senses that people are ready to turn the rascals out, and he's trying to turn it away from himself,'' Chiles said. Both parties consider this a watershed election in the state, with Democrats, still the majority party, trying to come back after a decade of Republican gains. Chiles is worried about Martinez' commercials. Two of them say Chiles repeatedly voted against senior citizens in the Senate. ``I want you all to be my truth squad and go out and set the record straight,'' Chiles told a meeting of the American Association of Retired Persons. Chiles says his votes reflect the dilemma posed by the federal deficit. He says he helped start many senior programs and increased funding in most cases, but did cast votes against some ``budget-busters.'' Martinez says Chiles will raise taxes. Chiles said fast-growing Florida will need to increase revenues, but he first wants to see how Martinez has managed $3.8 billion in a variety of tax increases since taking office. The Republican has turned down all but one Oct. 30 debate appearance. The governor didn't want to be set up in debates sponsored by pro-Chiles groups, explained Martinez' campaign manager, J.M. ``Mac'' Stipanovich. Chiles, 60, used six debates against Democratic primary foe Rep. Bill Nelson to help push aside questions about his vitality. Chiles, who said he was burned out after three terms in the Senate, takes the anti-depressant drug Prozac. Both camps also are seeking big-time help. President Bush made two campaign appearances for Martinez. The governor's staff - which includes presidential son Jeb Bush as campaign chairman - hopes for another. Chiles is calling in Georgia Sen. Sam Nunn to tour the military-minded Florida Panhandle this week. One issue that hasn't been central to the race is abortion. Martinez last year called an ill-fated special legislative session in hopes of further restricting abortion. But Chiles says he won't use what polls indicate could be an effective weapon. Most Floridians identify themselves as for abortion rights. Chiles personally opposes abortion and has cast anti-abortion votes in the past, but he supports a woman's choice. After listening to a female supporter fervently ask him to highlight the abortion issue, Chiles threw his arms up and said no. ``I have to do what my conscience tells me,'' he said. ``I'm comfortable telling people what my position is, but I'm not comfortable in making a big deal issue about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Joel McCrea, Leading Man Best Known For Westerns, Dead at 84
DOC.TEXT: Joel McCrea's death was seen as an end of a Hollywood era, another passing of a show business cowboy who personified the Old West. ``He was the last great `A' Western film cowboy,'' said John Langellier, director of the research center at the Gene Autry Western Heritage Museum. ``Along with Randolph Scott and certainly a few others like John Wayne and Gary Cooper, he created the strong, silent stereotype of the rugged Western hero,'' Langellier said. ``There will never be another like him. His death marks the end of an era.'' McCrea died Saturday at age 84 in the Motion Picture and Television Fund Hospital. His wife of 57 years, actress Frances Dee, and son, Peter, were with him at the time. Following private services, McCrea will be cremated and his ashes scattered at sea, Peter McCrea said. McCrea also leaves sons Jody and David. McCrea's last public appearance was Oct. 1, with first lady Barbara Bush at a Beverly Hills fund-raising dinner for Republican gubernatorialcandidate Pete Wilson. After her speech, Mrs. Bush went over to McCrea, took his hand, and said, ``My hero,'' said A.C. Lyles, a friend of McCrea's for many years. ``He lit up,'' Lyles said. ``That summed up everybody's feeling about Joel.'' Descended from pioneers - one grandfather fought Apache Indians and drove stagecoaches - McCrea's early ambition was to own a ranch. ``He loved the outdoors. He loved the West and history of the West,'' said producer Walter Mirisch, who worked on six films with McCrea. While most of his 87 roles were Westerns, McCrea also was adept at light comedy and drama. He was the trenchcoat-wearing reporter in Alfred Hitchcock's 1940 ``Foreign Correspondent.'' ``He had the quality of childlike innocence, and yet there was a strength of character that comes through,'' said Peter McCrea. ``When the chips were down, you felt he could handle a situation.'' One of McCrea's comedies, ``Sullivan's Travels,'' was listed by the Library of Congress as one of 25 outstanding films worthy of historic preservation. The 1941 film was written and directed by Preston Sturges. ``I think one reason he appealed to Sturges was his low-key style,'' Peter McCrea said. ``He wasn't a superstar, and he wouldn't overwhelm the story. He didn't try to be an actor's actor. He tried to play the part the way it would be if he were in that person's shoes.'' In a 1985 interview, McCrea said he always ``wanted to be the guy who rode off into the sunset,'' to represent ``right over evil.'' Born in South Pasadena, he grew up in Hollywood and got his start in movies as a volunteer ``horse holder'' for Western stars Tom Mix and William S. Hart. At 12, McCrea got his first paying job riding a horse in a movie mob scene. ``They dressed me up in buckskins and for two days' work I was paid $5,'' McCrea once said. ``Boy, that appealed to my Scotch blood. I forgot about wanting to be a cowboy and decided to be an actor.'' Bob Ward, a friend who said he first met McCrea in 1947, said McCrea told him about a conversation he had with cowboy comedian Will Rogers, who ``told him that he was not a very good actor so he'd better buy some real estate.'' In the 1930s, McCrea and his wife bought a ranch in Ventura County, northwest of Los Angeles, that eventually totalled nearly 3,000 acres. McCrea later made millions of dollars when he sold off parcels to developers. He kept about 300 acres. In April 1969, McCrea was inducted into the Hall of Fame of Great Western Actors in Oklahoma City.

DOC.HEAD: World Temperatures Set Record Last Spring
DOC.TEXT: The average worldwide surface air temperature was the warmest on record last spring, a Commerce Department agency said Sunday. Temperature readings recorded at 63 sites around the globe during March, April and May averaged more than 1.5 degrees Fahrenheit above the 30-year average of 54 degrees, said Dr. James K. Angell of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's air resources laboratory. The readings were about 0.5 degrees warmer than the previous highest temperature recorded in the March-May period, Angell said. He cautioned that his analysis should not be construed as confirming claims that global warming is occurring. During the June-August period, the global surface temperature was only about 0.5 degrees above average. He termed that a ``typical value for this season'' over the past decade. The most unusually warm temperatures recorded in the March-May period were in the Arctic, where temperatures were about 7.2 degrees above average and 4.5 degrees higher than previously observed, Angell said. At the same time, the temperature in the 30,000-foot to 60,000-foot altitude range was about 10.8 degrees below normal, Angell said. He said scientists were trying to determine whether very cold temperatures in the stratosphere might also be associated with destruction of the Earth's protective ozone layer in the Arctic region. He said preliminary evaluation of ozone data in the Arctic last spring showed concentrations 8 percent lower than the average of the previous decade, and 2 percent lower than in th next lowest year, 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Machine Company Must Stand Trial on Felony Toxic Waste Charges
DOC.TEXT: A machine company has been ordered to stand trial on five felony counts of dumping thousands of tons of hazardous waste at an old Navy shipyard. Judge Charles James issued his ruling on Friday after an 11-month preliminary hearing, which is the longest conducted in an environmental case in California. The civil action against Triple A Machine Shop also is San Francisco's first felony toxic pollution case, said prosecutor Steve Castleman, who's in the district attorney's environmental unit. The prosecution is seeking fines of $5,000 to $10,000 for each day that hazardous waste remains on site at the Hunters Point Navy Shipyard, a 500-acre facility the company leased from the Navy from 1976 to 1986. According to estimates, it could cost $100 million to clean up the site. The district attorney's office alleges that the company dumped waste oil and acids, polychlorinated biphenyls, asbestos, sandblasting materials contaminated with lead and copper and other hazardous wastes. Triple A's attorneys, Fred Blum and Carmen Trutanich, said they considered the preliminary hearing a success since the number of felony counts pending against the company was reduced from an original 16. Trutanich added that the Navy should be prosecuted in the case because it allegedly dumped hazardous materials at the site for years before Triple A leased the facility. ``It's ludicrous that we're going through this now without the Navy sitting next to me in the defendant's chair,'' Trutanich said.

DOC.HEAD: Knife-Wielding Attacker Kills Three Israelis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with details, scene of suspect shown on Israeli television. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `Angry Israelis...' ADDS 1 graf at bottom on Gaza incident.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JRL1-3, LaserColor JRL103
DOC.TEXT: An Arab laborer shouting ``God is Great!'' stabbed three Israelis to death Sunday as he rampaged through a Jewish neighborhood, apparently seeking revenge for the Temple Mount killings, police said. One victim managed to shoot and wound the attacker, who was then seized by furious residents, ending the rampage in the Baka area of southern Jerusalem, police said. The attack inflamed tensions in the capital and brought in a stream of police reinforcements as vengeance-seeking Jews took briefly to the streets. Police spokesman Aharon Elchayani said his forces would bar Arabs from traveling into Jerusalem on Monday. Two Palestinian factions claimed responsibility for Sunday's attack, but police said they believed the assailant acted alone. The suspect was identified as Omar Abu Sirhan, a 19-year-old Arab laborer from the village of Ubbadiyeh in the occupied West Bank. Police said his motive apparently was revenge for the Oct. 8 blood bath on the Temple Mount, in which Israeli police fired at stone-throwing Palestinians, killing at least 19 of them. Avi Cohen, the officer leading the interrogation, said the attacker seemed to have chosen his victims at random. He said Abu Sirhan had no known criminal background. Israel television showed scenes of Abu Sirhan being led down a corridor by policemen. He wore a bloodstained hospital smock, his head and leg were bandaged and his ankles were chained. Shouting ``Allahu Akbar'' - Arabic for ``God Is Great'' - the attacker killed an 18-year-old woman soldier, a 43-year-old garden nursery owner and a 28-year-old member of an elite police anti-terrorism unit, police said. The off-duty police officer managed to shoot the assailant as he was being attacked. Angry Israeli youths stoned Arab-owned cars on a Jerusalem highway. Shouts of ``Death to the Arabs!'' resounded in the streets of Baka. Defense Minister Moshe Arens voiced fears that Arab-Jewish communal violence was reducing prospects of a Mideast peace settlement. He told Israel television that he feared ``a chasm is opening.'' Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek appealed for calm, saying the attack was ``a tough test of people's patience and tolerance.'' Some Israeli politicians demanded broader powers for troops and police to fire on attackers. They also said the off-duty policeman should have immediately shot the assailant dead. Instead, the officer fired his pistol in the air, then shot the attacker in the legs. ``If someone attacks with intent to kill, he should be killed on the spot,'' Agriculture Minister Raphael Eitan said. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's senior adviser, Avi Pazner, said the U.N. Security Council's condemnation of Israel for the Temple Mount clash created ``an atmosphere that incites extremist actions against innocent Jewish civilians.'' After the killings on Temple Mount, known in Arabic as Haram es-Sharif, leaflets distributed by leaders of the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising called for vengeance in these ``bloody days of total escalation.'' According to police accounts, the rampage began when the Arab plunged his 16-inch blade into the chest of Iris Azulai, 18, just outside her home. He then ran to a nearby street where he slightly injured a 13-year-old boy, then assaulted nursery owner Eli Eltratz, stabbing him fatally in the chest. Police said the assailant used a knife. Israel radio said the weapon was the bayonet of a Kalashnikov assault rifle. The off-duty policeman, Charlie Chelouche, wearing civilian clothes, fired two warning shots in the air and then shot the attacker twice in the legs, but was himself stabbed in the chest. The two struggled in a dusty lot outside a preschool for 3- and 4-year-olds, where Abu Sirhan was arrested. Afterward, witnesses covered the bloodstains with dirt. Miri Rechtshaffer, a neighbor, said she was in bed when she heard the first victim screaming: ```I'm being stabbed, I'm being stabbed!''' ``Then I saw her on the street dying, and now she is dead. So beautiful, killed only two minutes from her home,'' Mrs. Rechtshaffer said, weeping. The slain young woman was buried in Jerusalem nine hours later in a military funeral attended by about 1,000 mourners. ``Iris, my flower,'' cried her mother as the coffin was lowered and clumps of earth thudded softly onto the pine. Wails rose from the crowd. ``Iris ... her only crime was that she was a Jew,'' said the chaplain. An anonymous phone caller to a Western news agency in Amman, Jordan, claimed the Islamic Front for the Liberation of Palestine had carried out the attack in revenge for the Temple Mount killings. A news agency in Jerusalem received a telephone claim on behalf of the Palestine Liberation Organization's Force 17. During the uprising, 761 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 283 by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Before Sunday, at least 48 Israelis had died in the violence. On Sunday, an Arab man suspected of collaborating with Israel was kidnapped by masked Palestinian activists from his Gaza Strip home on Sunday and shot to death, Arab reports said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Says 700 Soviet Soldiers on the Run
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet human rights lawyer claims that about 700 Red Army troops, underfed and ill-treated at their bases, have deserted and fled into the woods of eastern Germany, German media reported Sunday. The German weekly magazine Bunte quoted Moscow defense attorney Oleg Lyamin as saying some of the soldiers were armed and had been stealing food to stay alive. Lyamin has been defending a Soviet army deserter in Weimar, about 150 miles southwest of Berlin. A military court on Oct. 12 exonerated the soldier, who claimed he fled his unit when other troops tried to extort money from him. The Berliner Morgenpost on Sunday quoted Lyamin as saying that nearly 1,000 Soviet soldiers die each year in Eastern European units due to bullying and brutality. He made the charges during ``open door'' day at a Soviet base in Weimar, the newspaper said. There are an estimated 380,000 Soviet soldiers stationed in former East German territory. The Soviet troops are scheduled to completely pull out by 1994. Living standards of Soviet soldiers have deteriorated in the months following the July 1 economic union of the Germanys, which unified politically on Oct. 1. Soviet privates earn about $16 a month, and prices in the east have risen sharply. The Interior Ministry in Bonn last week said 53 Soviet soldiers have demanded aslyum in Germany. But the number could be much higher, because it takes weeks for the cases to be registered.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rain in South
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered across the South on Sunday, and rain and high wind lashed the Pacific Northwest. Showers and thunderstorms associated with a slowly moving cold front were over Arkansas, Louisiana, and eastern and south-central sections of Texas during the afternoon, with some locally heavy rain. Showers and thunderstorms also produced locally heavy rain over northern and central Florida. Heavier rainfall totals for the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 2.31 inches at Shreveport, La.; 1.70 inches at Mayport, Fla.; 1.37 at Fort Polk, La.; 1.33 at Pine Bluff, Ark.; 1.24 inches at Daytona Beach, Fla.; 1.11 inches at San Antonio, Texas; and 1.10 at Alexandria, La. Killeen, Texas, got 2.99 inches of rain during the 12-hour period up to 2 p.m. EDT. A cold front crossing the northern Pacific Coast region carried rain and high wind to parts of Washington and Oregon. Quillayute, Wash., got 1.49 inches in six hours during the night. Showers were scattered from eastern Washington state into the northern Rocky Mountains. Strong southwesterly wind blew over the northern high Plains, with a gust to 66 mph during the morning at Livingston, Mont. Blustery northwesterly wind carried cold air into Oklahoma and Texas during the afternoon. Temperatures in the 70s extended as far north as the Carolinas and southern sections of the Ohio Valley. But clouds and northwesterly wind kept afternoon temperatures in the 30s and 40s across the northern half of the Mississippi Valley, and afternoon readings were mostly in the 40s from the Dakotas to the northern and central high Plains. Temperatures were in the 40s and 50s across much of the West, and in the 80s in the desert Southwest. Overnight temperatures dipped into the teens and 20s in the Great Basin that includes Nevada and western Utah, and in the Rockies. Readings dipped below freezing during the night across upstate New York and northern New England, over the Texas Panhandle and Oklahoma Panhandle, and from the northern and central high Plains to Minnesota. Wheat Ridge, Colo., tied its record low for the date of 23. Sunday's low for the Lower 48 states was 3 above zero at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Killed in Tank Battle Remembered
DOC.TEXT: EL-ALAMEIN, Egypt (AP) - World War II veterans, diplomats and dignitaries on Sunday honored thousands of soldiers killed in a tank battle that stopped Germany's march through North Africa 48 years ago. The battles of El-Alamein pitted Axis forces led by Field Marshal Erwin Rommel against Allied armies of British Field Marshal Bernard Law Montgomery. The Allies lost 13,500 dead and wounded. Half the forces of Germany and Italy - close to 60,000 men - were killed, wounded or captured in the battle that turned the tide against Nazi forces. The vast desert battlefield 190 miles northeast of Cairo includes a military museum and separate memorials for the fallen soldiers from Italy, Germany and the British Commonwealth. Since 1978, ceremonies honoring the dead have been held on the Sunday falling closest to Oct. 23, when the battle began in 1942. The ceremony is held at a different monument each year. This year was Italy's turn. Sunday's ceremony opened with prayers at the modernistic Italian monument atop a seaside hill. A band played solemn music as officials, diplomats and aged veterans placed wreaths at the monument. Security was heavy, reflecting concerns in the wake of last week's assassination in Cairo of Rifaat el-Mahgoub, the speaker of Egypt's parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators, Police Accuse Each Other of Prompting Violence
DOC.TEXT: Protesters and police on Sunday traded accusations over who was to blame for violence that marred a demonstration the day before against Britain's controversial poll tax. Saturday's protest was the second violent anti-tax demonstration this year. An demonstration in Trafalgar Square on March 31 turned into one of the worst riots in London this century. Home Secretary David Waddington demanded a report from police on the riot Saturday that left six officers and six civilians injured and resulted in 120 arrests. Five shops were damaged. The confrontation began after a a crowd estimated by police at 2,500 left a peaceful anti-tax rally at Brockwell Park in south London. They marched to Brixton Prison to show solidarity with four prisoners jailed after the Trafalgar Square riot. Dave Morris, coordinator of the Trafalgar Square Defendants Campaign, which organized the protest, told a news conference Sunday that police staged ``a pre-planned attack in order to discredit the poll tax movement.'' He accused officers of ``incompetence and brutality.'' Scotland Yard said it stood by the comments made Saturday night by Deputy Assistant Commissioner John Metcalfe, who blamed the violence on ``the anarchist movement.'' ``I've no doubt at all that the people who started the violence intended it and came to the demonstration intending it,'' he said. More than 2,000 extra police were on duty to prevent a repetition of the Trafalgar Square riot. That rioting left 331 police and 86 civilians injured, caused hundreds of thousands of dollars in damage, and led to 341 arrests. The poll tax is part of Mrs. Thatcher's crusade to wipe out British socialism by hitting at its last bastion - local government. Instead of a tax on property owners, the community charge is paid by every adult, and the amount is determined by the local council. Critics say the tax is unfair because all adults in a district pay the same charge, regardless of wealth.

DOC.HEAD: Lava from Kilauea Overruns Another House
DOC.TEXT: Lava flowing from the Kilauea Volcano burned down a fourth home Sunday in the Kalapana Shores subdivision and threatened to wipe out what little is left of the coastal community. All seven homes remaining in the subdivision are in immediate danger of being overrun by the flow, said Hawaii County Civil Defense administrator Harry Kim. The home destroyed Sunday was the first since Thursday as lava flowed along the coastal area fronting the ocean subdivision. The recent loss of homes in Kalapana Shores brings to 180 the number destroyed since the current volcanic eruption began in January 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Groups Form Largest Soviet Opposition Movement
LaserPhoto MOSB1
DOC.TEXT: More than 30 Russian groups united on Sunday to form the nation's largest political bloc opposing the Communist Party, and the new movement demanded that Kremlin leaders resign. National legislators and key officials of the Russian republic attended the two-day founding conference of the Democratic Russia Movement, the broadest grouping yet to openly challenge President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. But the conference glossed over sharply divergent views among the republic's various groups, and gave them the right to pull out of the movement. The movement's chances of becoming a unified political force were uncertain. Many small parties have been created since the Communist Party surrendered its constitutionally guaranteed monopoly on power last February. None, including the new bloc, have anywhere near the Communists' 18 million members. The new movement joined Christian Democrats with labor unions, scholars with peasants, and Red Army officers with disabled veterans. They united around a sweeping platform that called for Russian sovereignty as well as the resignation of Gorbachev and his prime minister, Nikolai Ryzhkov. The platform underlined growing disenchantment with the Soviet leader. The conference also formed a commission to organize ``civil disobedience'' if necessary. It was not clear under what conditions civil disobedience would be used. It delegated another commission to find ways to create a market economy in Russia, the largest and most populous of the 15 Soviet republics. A fledgling coalition between Gorbachev and Boris N. Yeltsin, the reformist president of the Russian republic, fell apart after the Soviet president balked at the radical economic program backed by Yeltsin. ``Gorbachev finally showed that he has moved to the right'' by rejecting radical economic reforms last week, prominent legislator Yuri Boldyrev told the 1,272 delegates. They met in a central Moscow movie theater. After his speech, delegates voted by a show of hands to approve a draft declaration forming the Democratic Russia Movement, then applauded for nearly a minute in a standing ovation. ``The task of the movement is coordination of the activities for the unity of democratic forces ... to carry out the progressive, radical political and economic reforms in Russia,'' according to the draft, published Sunday by the independent Postfactum news agency. The movement will be run by a 21-member Coordinating Council and will include a Council of Representatives and consultative body to make sure all members' views are heard, according to the declaration. The draft also ``guarantees the independence of every associated member ... in choosing his strategy and tactics.'' The final version will be published next week in the movement's newspaper, said Oleg Rumyantsev, leader of the Social Democratic Party of Russia and member of the new Coordinating Council. Following the vote, the celebratory air in the hall subsided and officials proposed several supplementary planks and dozens of minor resolutions. In an indication of disagreements to come, several delegates demanded that the initial call only for Ryzhkov's resignation be expanded to include Gorbachev. Others from the floor applauded the suggestion. ``But we have no union, so what does it matter whether the president resigns?'' an official retorted. A delegate echoed, ``Why demand either resign? Just create a market economy and the government will fall anyway.'' The delegates changed the wording to include Gorbachev, and the resolution passed by a large majority. Cooperation among the various groups was not assured. In a survey of 628 delegates taken Saturday by the independent firm ``Monitoring,'' nearly a quarter said they would not subsume their own goals to those of the movement. Only 11 percent said they would follow the movement over their own party, while 57 percent said they would seek a compromise position. The poll gave no margin of error. In a poll of support for leaders, Yeltsin was by far the most popular with 89 percent, followed by Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak with 55 percent. Gorbachev received only 8 percent support. The poll concluded that delegates were united mainly in their opposition to the Communist Party and in their support for Yeltsin.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Test Planned for Babies' Blood Without Consent
DOC.TEXT: Tests for the AIDS virus will be conducted on unidentified blood samples taken routinely from newborn infants in Pennsylvania without parents' consent, a newspaper reported Sunday. The program is designed to measure the presence of the virus in the general population. The state Department of Health begins the federal program next month, but the project will include about 50,000 blood specimens taken from infants since July 1 and stored, The Pittsburgh Press reported. Dr. Bobby Jones, epidemiology director for the state Bureau of AIDS, said the state didn't publicize the program because parents might have refused all medical tests on their new babies. ``We don't want it to have an adverse impact on the metabolic screening we do,'' Jones said. Jones said there was no need for the state to announce the program because parents won't learn the results. The tests will be performed on samples after they are stripped of the donor's name and birth date. Some parents objected to the additional testing without their consent; others did not. Janice Stifter of Plum said she was unaware the state was storing her baby's blood. ``But it wouldn't have bothered me if I had known,'' she said. Her daughter, Laura, was born Aug. 10 at Magee Womens Hospital in Pittsburgh. ``They shouldn't be doing any tests without letting us know,'' said Duane Szymanski, father of 11-week-old Samantha. ``They're using her blood.'' Mothers complained of being kept in the dark about their babies' health. ``If my child had AIDS and I wouldn't know, if seems kind of senseless,'' said Robbie Wojciewchowski. ``I really think they should let the parents know the results.'' Her daughter, Kimberly, was born Aug. 22 at Allegheny General. State figures show 4,226 people have suffered or are suffering from fully developed AIDS in Pennsylvania since 1981, when records were first kept. There are no statistics on people found to be carrying the virus without developing symptoms.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Coalition Takes Early Election Lead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with results, adds background; No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto KL1
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's ruling coalition was swept back into power in weekend elections, defeating a loose grouping of opposition parties. With all but one seat accounted for, Mahathir's National Front coalition had 127 seats in the 180-member lower house, to 48 for the combined opposition. Four seats went to independents. ``We are happy that the people have returned us to power with a more than two-thirds majority. This will enable us to give a strong, peaceful and stable government,'' said Mahathir, 64. It was his third election victory since becoming prime minister in 1981.The ruling coalition's lost a few seats overall in the voting. Polling started in remote areas of Sabah and Sarawak states on Borneo on Saturday. The rest of the country voted Sunday. Also at stake was control of 11 of the 13 state legislatures. Sabah and Sarawak hold separate state elections. The ruling coalition had controlled all 13 state bodies up to Oct. 5, when Mahathir called the elections. But the Sabah United Party, a Christian party, defected from the coalition on Oct. 15. In the weekend's voting, the ruling coalition also lost control of the legislature in Kelantan, the home state of Tengku Razaleigh Hamzah, a 53-year-old former ally of Mahathir who now heads the opposition alliance. Malaysia has been ruled by a multiracial coalition, based on parties made up of different ethnic and racial groups, since independence in 1957. Malays comprise about 53 percent of the population of 17.8 million. Chinese make up about 32 percent, with Indians and other races making up the balance. The National Front includes the Malaysian Chinese Association, Malaysian Indian Congress and seven smaller parties. Malaysia has had seven previous elections since independence, but in those votes, the fragmented opposition made little headway against the National Front, establishing only regional bases of power. In the weekend vote, however, the electorate for the first time had an organized alternative representing the same ethnic mosaic as the National Front. But the campaign was largely devoid of issues, focusing instead on personality attacks. The opposition charged the National Front with economic mismanagement, corruption, indifference to ethnic tensions and erosion of judicial powers. None of these allegations made much impact. The opposition also promised sweeping tax cuts. Mahathir claims credit for one of the fastest growing economies in Southeast Asia and he dismissed the other accusations as groundless. He derided the promised tax cuts as ``the height of irresponsibility and money politics.'' In two major upsets, Defense Minister Ahmed Rithaudden was defeated in the Kelantan state district of Kota Baharu, and Science, Technology and Environment Minister Stephen Yong lost in Sarawak. The two-thirds majority won by the ruling coalition is necessary to amend the constitution and symbolic as a measure of the prime minister's power. In the old Parliament, the coalition held 133 of the 177 seats. The new one was enlarged by three seats. Voting was not compulsory and turnout of the 7.9 million voters ranged from 60 to 70 percent throughout the country. Fifty thousand police officers were on duty and 25,000 on standby for election day, authorities said. No violence was reported. No outdoor rallies or political processions have been allowed in Malaysia since race riots after the 1969 elections left hundreds dead in the streets of Kuala Lumpur. That bloodshed occurred after Chinese parties made inroads on Malay political dominance.

DOC.HEAD: Neighbor Sought in Triple Death Arrested in Florida
DOC.TEXT: The neighbor of a family found hacked to death in their beds was in custody in Florida while officials worked to bring him home to face charges, a prosecutor said Sunday. Eric Robert Motis, 19, was arrested late Saturday night in Miami Beach while driving a car belonging to Louise C. Hoopes, 42. She was killed with her sons Douglas, 16, and Daniel, 14, as they slept last Monday, said Bucks County District Attorney Alan Rubenstein. The county coroner said they were stabbed and slashed in the head and neck with a sharp instrument. After the bodies were found Monday, Rubenstein described the victims as members of a classic suburban household who appeared to have no enemies. Mrs. Hoopes' husband, Howard, died two years ago from cancer. The killer made an effort to be undetected and went in and out of the darkened house without making noise or damaging anything, he said. Motis had lived across the street from the Hoopes' home with his parents and grandparents. After the killings, police said they wanted to question Motis. Rubenstein said at a news conference that Motis was charged in a warrant with three counts of first-degree murder, burglary, robbery and related offenses. Bucks County authorities have requested his extradition from Florida ``as soon as possible,'' Rubenstein said. Rubenstein said he obtained information that Motis might be in Miami Beach and sent agents from his office, along with state and local police, to help track him down. Mrs. Hoopes was a part-time secretary at Grand View Hospital in nearby Sellersville. Manny Motis, 47, told authorities last week that his son, Eric, had played pool with Douglas Hoopes. He described the family as ``the nicest people you'd ever want to meet.'' In August, the elder Motis reported to Hilltown police that his son had left home, taking with him two handguns and a truck that belonged to the father. Eric Motis was arrested Sept. 4 in Montgomery County and held in the county prison until Sept. 12, when he was released to Bucks County authorities. Hilltown police arrested him Sept. 17 on charges of attempted theft of gasoline, theft of two handguns and unauthorized use of a motor vehicle. His father posted $5,000 bail for him and an Oct. 1 preliminary hearing was set. Eric Motis failed to appear for the preliminary hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Main Opposition Parties to Boycott Coming Election
DOC.TEXT: Four of Egypt's main opposition parties announced Sunday they would boycott next month's parliamentary elections to protest what they said were unfair voting conditions. This would leave President Hosni Mubarak's National Democratic Party virtually unchallenged. The opposition New Wafd, Labor and Liberal parties and the Moslem Brotherhood are protesting conditions they say encourage vote-rigging. Those include loopholes they said would allow the use of names of dead and absent voters, and an emergency law that has led to arrests of thousands of opposition supporters. The government denies their claims of election fraud, saying the emergency law is only being used to combat terrorism and black market dealings in drugs and currency. The state-run Middle-East news Agency quoted Information Minister Safwat al-Sherif as saying the ruling party welcomed any dialogue that would help convince the opposition to participate in the elections. At a news conference, the opposition leaders declared that any opposition candidate who stood for election in defiance of the boycott would be expelled from his party. The four groups held 95 of the 458 seats in the parliament, the People's Assembly, which was dissolved last week by a national referendum after Egypt's Supreme Constitutional Court ruled it was elected under unconstitutional law. The court's ruling was in May and the assembly had been in recess, effectively suspended, since June. Using his executive lawmaking powers in the assembly's absence, Mubarak decreed an election law that appeared to satisfy the court's stipulation. The opposition argues that it was not consulted over the new law, which it says is still far from satisfactory. Only the small leftist National Unionist Progressive Party has announced it will participate in the Nov. 29 election. There has been no word yet from four other small parties that have not run previously. The emergency law allows wide powers to the police. It has been in effect since the assassination of President Anwar Sadat in 1981. On Oct. 11, a few days after the old parliament's suspension was decreed, gunmen assassinated Rifaat el-Mahgoub, the speaker of the former parliament. But his death apparently had nothing to do with the current dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Frigate Rescues Eight Iranians In Gulf
DOC.TEXT: A Dutch Navy frigate patrolling the Persian Gulf on Sunday rescued eight Iranians whose ship sank after colliding with another vessel off the coast of Dubai, a navy spokesman said. The Witte de With, one of two Dutch Navy frigates that are part of the multinational flotilla confronting Iraq in the gulf, saw the eight Iranians clinging to wreckage early Sunday off the coast of Dubai, said navy spokesman Wim Geneste. No one was reported missing in the accident. The Iranian ship had been carrying a cargo of fruit bound for Dubai, Geneste said. ``They said they didn't remember what kind of boat hit them,'' he said. The man had been in the water about eight hours and one of them was treated for hypothermia. They were put ashore at the Dubai port of Mina Saqr, Geneste said.

DOC.HEAD: Southern Governors Setting Up New Regional Literacy Organization
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf, `Also attending ...' to UPDATE with governors' comments. Picks up 8th graf, `The report ...'
DOC.TEXT: Officials from 13 Southern states and Puerto Rico on Sunday labeled their region the least educated in the nation, and announced formation of the Southern Literacy Forum to combat the problem. ``There are thousands of individual literacy programs out there. A lot of good is going on, but it's like dipping the Mississippi River dry with a teaspoon,'' former Mississippi Gov. William F. Winter wrote in a report released at a news conference. ``A center will help us coordinate, on a regional basis, what has to be one of the most important projects that anybody can be involved in,'' he wrote. In the 13 Southern states, at least 30 percent of adults are high school dropouts. This is true in only three of the other 37 states, the report said. The forum will be an offshoot of the Southern Growth Policies Board, which southern governors created to develop their economies and people. The agency is based in Research Triangle Park, N.C. The board received the report Sunday from its chairman, Louisiana Gov. Buddy Roemer, who also announced creation of the forum. Also attending the board's 18th annual meeting were North Carolina Gov. James Martin and officials from Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia, West Virginia and Puerto Rico. ``Literacy would improve the quality of our work force, lower the unempooyment rates, and make our citizenry have a higher self-esteem,'' Roemer said. ``It will be helpful to join with our neighbors and put together a plan to develop literacy opportunities for the region.'' ``What the forum does is show which ideas are best and promote them,'' Martin said. ``It's sort of like blocking and tackling, we've got to deal with the fundamentals.'' The report, ``Literacy is Everybody's Business,'' noted the very meaning of literacy has changed throughout the century. ``Today's literacy would seem like higher education to our grandparents,'' it said. ``In fact, the education that was once sufficient to enable any ambitious adult to get ahead now can't even help him hold his place on the assembly line.'' During World War II, a worker able to read at a 4th-grade level could manage entry-level jobs. An 8th-grade education was enough to get by in the mid-1960s. Today even entry-level jobs may require some college education. And farming, a crucial part of the Southern economy, needs more than a field hand's skills. ``Once it was enough to read the ripeness of a tomato or the sky's forecast of rain. Today's farmer is the chief executive officer, purchasing agent, personnel officer, and financial manager of a rapidly evolving, highly sophisticated business,'' the report said. ``At the same time he must be a scientist to select his seed or stock plants; a computer operator to disburse the proper fertilizer to his fields or feedstuffs to his livestock; a production expert to manage the harvest; and a marketing whiz to sell his commodity,'' it said. The report estimated that literacy programs currently are attended by fewer than 10 percent of Southern adults who need to improve their reading, speaking and mathematics skills. A regional partnership is needed to expand such offerings because no single Southern state has the money or other resources to reach and teach all the people who need help, the report said. The Southern Literacy Forum will help states put together such programs, pay for or conduct research to improve them and provide information, training and other help to local literacy programs. The policies board has a $1.2 million budget, 31 percent of it from state dues and appropriations and the rest from grants, associate memberships and publications. Initial support for the organization will come from $175,000 the board hopes to raise from foundations and private donors.

DOC.HEAD: South Dakota State University Homecoming Gets Out of Control
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with about 50 arrested, details. Picks up 5th graf, `On Friday ...'
DOC.TEXT: An estimated 1,000 people roamed city streets and the South Dakota State University campus, setting bonfires and throwing rocks and bottles as a homecoming celebration got out of hand for a second night. Police arrested about 50 people on charges ranging from aggravated assault and intentional damage to property to fleeing arrest and alcohol violations involving minors. They were being held Sunday in Brookings County Jail and bond hearings were scheduled for Monday. ``You always have some incidents that occur as a result of Hobo Day,'' the school's homecoming, said university President Robert Wagner. But Friday and Saturday night's events were the most extreme in many years, he said. Several hundred people marched across campus toward downtown Saturday, tearing down signs and light poles. Small fires were started at two intersections near the campus, and some students pelted police and firefighters with eggs and beer bottles. On Friday, people clogged a street near the campus and overturned a car, started a bonfire and threw rocks and beer cans at police. ``They just took over the street,'' city Police Chief Dennis Falken said of Friday night's disturbance in the city of 16,000 people. No injuries were reported Friday and police made some arrests for underage alcohol consumption, he said. Wagner called the violence ``inexcusable'' and said steps would be taken to teach students to behave better. The violence started late Friday when people attending several off-campus house parties spilled out into the street, Falken said. They overturned an old car, tried to start it and then set it on fire, according to sophomore Kim Fischer, who stopped to watch. She said people in the crowd pelted police when a tow truck arrived, throwing bricks, rocks and beer bottles and cans. ``They (police) tried to break it up and the kids were just throwing beer cans,'' said Doug Mikuska, a junior who lives nearby. ``They just left. The cops were outmanned.'' The crowd moved down the street and started a bonfire at an intersection. ``Then groups of people kept coming and throwing things on - anything they could get their hands on,'' including a tire and a doghouse, Falken said. Some residents believe violence and mischief have gotten worse in recent years since the legal drinking age was raised to 21. Younger students can't be in bars anymore, so thy attend off-campus house parties. Liquor is banned in dormitories at the university, which has an enrollment of about 7,000.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Showing Signs of Succumbing to Sanctions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 10th graf, `The rationing ..' with gasoline price staying the same, picks up 11th graf pvs, `For the ...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Suez, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's decision to ration gasoline and motor oil starting Tuesday indicates the worldwide trade embargo on Iraq is finally taking hold where it hurts most: the petroleum industry. Although Iraq now controls an estimated 20 percent of global oil reserves, the rationing belies the fragility of Iraq's main industry and brings into question how long it can keep its army running. Even the government admits that the sanctions are beginning to hurt. ``Day after day, effects of the economic blockade being imposed on Iraq conspicuously affect it, the formula which was invented by the U.S. administration for building economic, political and psychological pressure on the Iraqi people,'' the ruling Baath Party newspaper Al-Thawra said Sunday. ``There is no doubt that this policy has direct impact on the individual and the family,'' it said. The party organ's acknowledgment echoes what Western governments have hoped for weeks the embargo would achieve. ``We believe it is beginning to have an effect, and that it will have an effect not only on the Iraqi economy but on this massive military machine (Iraq) has in Kuwait,'' U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Thursday. Kuwaiti economist Jassem al-Saadoun estimated last week that the loss of oil exports alone costs Iraq $54 million a day. ``Iraq's inability to sell its oil is the cornerstone of the embargo,'' said al-Saadoun, head of the al-Shall financial house. The rationing move constitutes an Iraqi admission of its inability to refine oil on its own. Oil Minister Issam Abdul Rahim al-Chalabi ordered the rationing to conserve additives that Iraq could no longer obtain because of the ban on imports. The price of gasoline is being kept at the pre-sanctions level of 26 cents per liter, or about $1 a gallon, but motor oil prices have increased in recent weeks. For the moment, food is less of a problem. Iraqi stores and markets are chock-full of fruits, vegetables, fish, canned goods, juice, cooking oil, wheat flour and rice, much of it from abroad. Restaurants do a bustling business. But milk, sugar, tea, cooking oil, soap and rice have been rationed for weeks, and farmers have been urged to plant more grain on unused lands. The two-month-old trade embargo has kept out machinery and spare parts, oil-producing equipment and materials needed for construction and agriculture. Building projects have halted, petroleum production is down 43 percent, and people are being urged to cut back on electricity use. President Saddam Hussein has even appealed to citizens to conserve their clothing. ``My personal understanding is that the sanctions bite, every day more and more,'' says Marjatta Rasi, chairwoman of the U.N. Security Council's sanctions committee. ``The functioning of the society will slow down, because they cannot receive spare parts, even though they have taken everything they could from Kuwait,'' she said. While it is difficult to accurately quantify effects of the sanctions, experts seem to agree that Iraq cannot hold out more than a few months. Kuwaiti economist al-Saadoun said Iraq likely had consumer and industrial supplies stockpiled to last three months. ``This means that six months of the embargo would be sufficient to have the country explode,'' he said. The government, which first distributed food ration coupons for two months, will issue them for six months starting in November. ``Psychologically this is important because the Iraqi government is preparing the people for a long embargo,'' a Baghdad resident said. The front line of enforcement are the naval ships implementing the two-month-old blockade. Western warships have intercepted about 2,600 vessels, boarded some 270 and diverted a dozen. Shipping, aviation and military sources say the naval blockade is virtually impermeable. U.S. Vice-Adm. Henry Mauz, commander of naval elements in Operation Desert Shield, said last week that a small quantity of goods were trickling into Iraq through Jordan. Some goods arrive in Aqaba, Jordan's Red Sea port, and are repackaged and sent on to Iraq, he said. Jordan, Turkey and Iraq's erstwhile archenemy Iran have emerged as the weak links in the embargo chain. Soon after the trade sanctions were adopted on Aug. 16, a convoy of supplies sent by Palestinians left Jordan for Iraq in a cheerful but flagrant violation of the U.N. order. Smuggling, mostly small-scale, from Turkey and Iran began soon after the embargo, and some Turkish cargo sent to Iran was diverted to Iraq by Iranian border guards. But a senior Turkish official said last week there had been no increase in traffic to Iran, indicating that Iran is largely abiding by the embargo. ``I don't think there is a great amount of smuggling,'' said the U.N. Sanction Committee's Ms. Rasi. `I don't think the smugglers want to take the risk for the Iraqi currency.'' The Iraqi dinar is not covertible on currency markets and has been shunned in the wake of the trade ban. The air embargo, adopted in late September, is enforced mainly in Jordan, where Iraq's only commercially scheduled flights arrive. They are checked by Jordanian authorities as well as U.N. officials.

DOC.HEAD: Scientist Collars Problem of Barking Dogs
DOC.TEXT: A veterinarian has developed a dog collar he says can silence chronic barkers with a high-frequency beep. ``It's not an electric shock collar. It will not hurt the dog,'' said Jon Hunter, 48, an associate professor of veterinary physiology and pharmacology at Texas A&M. The device needs fine-tuning and its effectiveness is uncertain, he said. But the principle is simple. When the dog barks, a miniature microphone in the collar emits a burst of high-intensity sound, startling the animal into silence. The sound is inaudible to most humans. ``It will not be so effective that it will stop dogs from barking completely,'' Hunter said. ``Many people want their dogs to bark in order to warn them of intruders.'' ``The people who have tested the collar have said the collar has had an immediate effect,'' Hunter said. ``It causes the dog to become distracted from its barking.'' Hunter's invention was inspired by his experience as an 11-year-old Missouri farm boy. ``We were milking cows and a thunderstorm occurred,'' he said. ``When the thunder occurred, the cattle and dogs would seek shelter. ``Later, in attempting to modify the behavior of animals, I thought of different sounds that would change an animal's behavior,'' he said. In three years of research, Hunter tried electronic simulation of thunder, explosions and gunfire. But a high-pitched sound few humans could hear turned out to be the best antidote. Hunter said his collar is more humane than other solutions owners employ. Some fit their pets with electric-shock collars or subject them to vocal cord surgery. Others may give them away or even destroy the animal. Hunter said he has a contract with a manufacturer whose name he wouldn't disclose and hopes to have a model on the market in six months. But, already, Hunter said he has been besieged by pet owners offering their yelping dogs as guinea pigs to test the collar. ``I have people call me and say, `Please give me a collar or I'll have to put my dog to sleep,''' Hunter said. ``We're trying to help people as quickly as we can, but they want the collar tomorrow.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Deny Taking Medical Equipment from Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: Associated Press reporter Salah Nasrawi was among a group of reporters flown to Kuwait and permitted to visit a hospital there Sunday by the Iraqi Information Ministry. ---

A senior Iraqi official said Sunday that allegations Iraq has taken medical equipment from hospitals in occupied Kuwait were false. Abduljabbar Abdulabbas, the Iraq official in charge of hospitals in Kuwait -which Iraq calls its 19th province - told reporters that normal services continue at hospitals in the occupied emirate. ``Although medical equipment exceeds by far the needs of the population, we did not move any of them to other places,'' said Abdulabbas, a physician who heads Baghdad's health department. He spoke during a tour of the main maternity hospital in Kuwait. The Iraqi manager of the maternity hospital, Qais Abdulsattar, said the 500-bed hospital is still providing services, including health care, to prematurely born babies who need to be kept in incubators. The United States and the exiled government of Kuwait have reported that Iraq moved medical equipment to Iraq, including a large number of incubators, causing the death of some Kuwaiti babies. Reporters were flown into Kuwait and given a tour of the hospital Sunday in an attempt to dispel these reports. Abdulsattar showed reporters 12 babies in incubators in the main intensive care unit of the hospital, which is staffed mostly by Asian and non-Kuwaiti Arab medical staff. ``Why should we send incubators to our maternity hospitals in Iraq? We have plenty of them there,'' said Abdulsattar, who was sent from Baghdad to run the Kuwaiti hospital. Reporters also visited Al-Razi Hospital for bone disease in downtown Kuwait, where about 30 patients were being treated in the luxurious 295-bed hospital built by the royal family in 1984. Kamal Mustafa, an Egyptian specialist in bone surgery, said most of the patients are suffering from injuries incurred in industrial accidents. He said he was not considering leaving Kuwait, where he has worked for more than 25 years. ``It's my sacred duty to be near my patients as long as they need me and I am keen not to let them down at this hard time,'' he said. But many of the foreign and non-Kuwaiti medical staff in the 14 Kuwaiti hospitals and 35 health centers left the small Persian Gulf state after Iraq took over on Aug. 2. Abdulabbas was asked whether the departure of foreign medical staff will have have any adverse effect on health service. ``It was extravagance. Why should a 500-bed hospital have 400 nurses?'' he said. Ali Abdulrahim al-Hawail, a Kuwaiti neurologist who heads the technical section at the newly set up health department, agreed that the shrinking of the population by more than two-thirds makes the remaining staff sufficient to run the hospitals and health centers. ``I don't feel the medical service has been affected, but hope they will continue with the same standard,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Daredevil Pilot Undertakes Hostage Mission
DOC.TEXT: A daredevil pilot who infuriated French authorities two years ago with stunt flights over Paris left Sunday on a private mission to try to liberate French hostages in Iraq. Albert Maltret, 54, captured public attention in the summer of 1988 when he made noctural flights over rooftops, monuments and the Champs-Elysees in a tiny ultralight aircraft, evading authorities for weeks. His flight on Sunday was more conventional - as a passenger in a Royal Jordanian Airways flight to Amman, Jordan. From there, he planned to travel on to Baghdad. Iraqi diplomats gave him his airline tickets. ``I'm undertaking this mission on my own; it's purely humanitarian,'' Maltret said before leaving. An estimated 400 French nationals are believed held hostage in Iraq and occupied Kuwait in the wake of the Aug. 2 Iraqi takeover. In 1988, police staked out airfields for weeks to bring down the pilot the press dubbed ``le Baron Noir'' -the Black Baron. Finally captured, Maltret was fined and lost his pilot's license for three years. French authorities briefly jailed him in April for plotting physical violence to settle a family quarrel. Two weeks ago, he volunteered to go to Iraq as a hostage mediator. He also at one point offered to serve as a mercenary for Iraq. But Maltret downplayed that offer on Sunday. ``My image has been tarnished,'' he said. ``I need to regain some credit. This mission will help me.''

DOC.HEAD: Leap of Faith Needed to Accept Deficit-Reduction Assumptions
With AM-Budget-Taxes Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf pvs, bgng: From their, to include current economic figures
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Would you believe oil prices falling more than 40 percent next year? How about interest rates in the 5 percent range by 1992? Probably not. But those are only two of the predictions the budget writers in Washington have manufactured to tout their $500 billion deficit-reduction plan. All federal budgets are, by necessity, built on assumptions of how the ecoomy will perform, because that determines how many dollars will flow into the Treasury in taxes and flow out for costs such as unemployment claims. But in trying to get the public to accept a huge package of tax increases and cuts in federal benefits, Congress and the White House have settled on assumptions that, at the least, strain credulity. For example: By the end of 1993, if the budget is passed, the nation should be enjoying a balanced budget; Treasury bill rates will be 4.4 percent and inflation 3 percent; and the economy will be humming along with nearly 4 percent annual growth, they agree. ``From their mouths to God's ears,'' said Stan Collender, a budget expert at the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse who predicted the $500 billion in deficit reduction will look more like $300 billion when reality unfolds. The rate for 12-month Treasury bills was 7.62 percent last week. The inflation rate soared to 9.5 percent on an annual basis in September, up from a 6.2 percent annual rate in August. The economy grew at a barely perceptible 0.4 percent in the second quarter of this year, down from a 1.7 percent annual growth rate in the 1st quarter and down from a 2.5 percent annual rate in 1989. Even as Congress was struggling to nail down the final deal over the weekend, government data was emerging that showed the fragility of their house of cards. On Thursday, the government said the cost of living increase for Social Security and other government entitlements will be 5.4 percent in January. Last January, the president's budget assumed it would be just 3.9 percent, and the figure is nearly a point higher than most recent estimates. Translated into the budget, government costs increase roughly $2 billion next year and $15 billion over the next five years. Budget negotiators have yet to find a source for that $15 billion. One of the reasons for the steep consumer price increases is the cost of oil, which has soared to nearly twice the $21.15 average assumed for this year. The budget predicts it will fall back below $25 next year and then below $22 the following two years. Oil prices affect the government directly, too, with military and civilian agencies operating huge fleets of airplanes, trucks, cars, etc. Continued high oil prices could add billions more to those costs over the next five years. Economic assumptions aside, some of the budget is just pretend. The costs of the Persian Gulf operations, $1 billion a month now and many times that if shooting breaks out, doesn't get counted. Nor does the huge savings and loan bailout. And one of the most questionable assumptions in the budget is that Congress and the administration will abide by its restraints on spending. ``This package will not have the effect on the deficit that the (budget) summiteers claim,'' said Jim Miller, former director of the Office of Management and Budget. ``There are just all sorts of loophole ways Congress can get away with spending.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Steven Komarow writes on budget matters for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Courts Old Foe in Tehran, Expels Mujahedeen Opposing Iran
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 3rd grasf prv with three grafs, not beginning, ``However, the xxx to include Mujahedeen denial of reports
DOC.TEXT: Iraq, responding to a request from Iran, appears to have expelled members of a major Iranian opposition group, U.S. officials say. Members of the People's Mujahedeen of Iran, the largest group trying to overthrow the clerical government in Tehran, have apparently started leaving Iraq for Paris and other European sites, said the officials who spoke only on condition of anonymity. However, the assessment from the U.S. officials was strongly challenged by Mujahedeen spokesman Farid Soleimani, who telephoned news agencies to insist that his group remained intact in Baghdad and elsewhere. ``We claim very firmly that none of our members have left Baghdad involuntarily,'' Soleimani said. ``There are comings and goings, that's natural, and it has nothing to do with expulsions.'' The reputed explusion move would be in keeping with Iraqi attempts to end its economic and diplomatic isolation by courting Iran, a one-time enemy with which it fought a disastrous eight-year war until 1988. In recent weeks Iraq has ceded many of its war gains, sending back thousands of war prisoners, withdrawing troops from areas it captured in the war, and agreeing to share sovereignty over the strategically important Shatt-al-Arab waterway. In return, Iraq asked for permission to hook into a major Iranian oil pipeline and circumvent the international naval blockade that's preventing the export of its oil. The Iraqis also asked Iran for food and medicine. Iran has sent some truckloads of food, but has not responded to the pipeline request, U.S. officials say. ``We're very watchful of what kind of relations Saddam Hussein is able to establish with Iran,'' said CIA Director William Webster in an interview this week with The Associated Press. ``So far, Iran is in a kind of win-win situation.'' Iran and Iraq have restored diplomatic relations and restaffed their embassies in each others' capitals. ``The sense is that with this new understanding between Iran and Iraq, an organization like that (the PMOI) is not welcome there any more,'' said another administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Iran's official news agency IRNA reported several times last month that Massoud Rajavi, the PMOI's Baghdad-based leader, had asked his people to leave Iraq and was himself leaving for Germany. The Mujahedeen sent telexes and communiques from Baghdad denying the reports as ``garbage allegations'' designed to discredit and destroy the organization. But PMOI representatives in the United States, who used to bombard reporters with phone calls, interview offers and news conferences, have all but disappeared in recent weeks. Repeated calls to their officials have not been returned. The group did hold a news conference at U.N. headquarters last Wednesday to complain about Iran's human rights record, but the officials refused to discuss their relations with Baghdad despite repeated questioning. The PMOI is no stranger to expulsions. Rajavi and his supporters fled to Paris in 1980 after their former allies, Khomeini and his fundamentalist leadership, turned on them in a bloody purge of leftists and liberals. In 1986, France asked the organization to leave its territory, under pressure from the Iranian government, and Rajavi moved to Baghdad. There, the PMOI was warmly received and encouraged to form its own military force, the National Liberation Army. The force launched incursions into Iranian territory, boasting 15,000 fighters. But claims of the losses they inflicted on Khomeini's troops could not be verified and were believed to be exaggerated. Although they continued to enjoy popularity and support in Iraq, the organization's power appeared to wane in recent years. The PMOI was forced to stop its military activity when Iran and Iraq agreed on a cease-fire in 1988. Thousands of its supporters in Iran have been rounded up and executed. Iraq has expelled Iranian opposition groups before. The late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini spent 15 years exiled in the holy Iraqi city of Najaf but was asked to leave in 1978 during a moment of detente in Iraqi-Iranian relations.

DOC.HEAD: Wichita Woman's Kuwati Husband Freed By Iraq
DOC.TEXT: A 3-week-old son he has never seen will be waiting for Nabil Seyam when he gets back to Wichita this week after more than two months trapped in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Carrie Seyam said her husband called her Sunday morning from Jordan. Hours later, a Wichita television station let her see a 17-second videotape of Seyam talking to reporters there. ``He looks good. He looks a little bit tired, but he's the same,'' she said. Seyam talked about his parents and siblings he had to leave behind in Kuwait. ``I'm going to do my best, hopefully, when I get back to the States to get my family out,'' he said. Seyam knew his U.S. citizenship made him a potential hostage soon after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Earlier this month, he was stopped at a checkpoint and taken into custody after soldiers read his nationality on his driver's license. The State Department told Mrs. Seyam they would try to get him out since Iraq was allowing some Arab-Americans to leave. Seyam called from Baghdad on Wednesday to say he was being released. ``It was six o'clock in the morning. The baby had just woke up,'' Mrs. Seyam said. ``I heard that phone and I just flew out of bed.'' The couple, both 29, met when Seyam was an engineering student at Wichita State University. They married almost 11 years ago. By the time he went to work at Kuwait Metal Pipe Industries as a safety engineer, the Seyams had a girl and a boy to move with them back to his homeland. Mrs. Seyam worked in Kuwait as a teacher's assistant at the American school. On June 1, more than six months pregnant, she left Kuwait with her children to visit her parents in Wichita. She planned to return in August and be in Kuwait for the birth of her third child. Instead, Yusef was born in Wichita.

DOC.HEAD: Immigration Group Expects 40,000 New Refugees Soon
DOC.TEXT: An international relief agency said Sunday that it expected up to 40,000 foreigners to flee Iraq and Kuwait soon and appealed to world governments for $13.5 million in contributions to repatriate them. ``IOM estimates that between 25,000 and 40,000 foreign residents of Iraq and Kuwait remain in need of international repatriation in the short term,'' the International Organization for Migration said in a statement. The European Community immediately announced it had allocated $4.9 million to repatriate thousands of Sri Lankan refugees expected to cross into Jordan before Nov. 4. Neither organization provided an explanation for why the flood of refugees was expected. Not long after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the migration organization launched a major repatriation program for refugees from Iraq and Kuwait who had landed in Turkey, Iran, Saudi Arabia and Jordan. The organization said it had flown home 122,307 evacuees since Sep. 3, including 114,633 from Jordan. Jordanian Interior Ministry official Salameh Hammad said last week that although 100,000 Asian and Arab refugees were stuck in the country at one point in mid-September, the desert camps are almost empty now.

Following is a list of major legislation and issues yet to be resolved as Congress heads toward adjournment of the 101st session:
BUDGET AND TAXES The House and Senate continue their search for a compromise deficit-reduction package that can be accepted by President Bush. The government is operating on temporary spending authority that expires at midnight Wednesday, by which time both sides hope to have a final agreement. The two sides continued to exchange proposed tax packages on Sunday, but hit a snag late in the day. Final passage is needed, as well, on the 13 appropriations bills financing government agencies in the new budget year, which started Oct. 1.
ARTS-OBSCENITY An $11.7 billion appropriations bill that would reinstate strict anti-obscenity restrictions on the National Endowment for the Arts is pending in the Senate. The bill would trim the agency's $175 million budget request by $5 million. Opponents favor a House-approved proposal to let the courts decide whether federally subsidized art works are obscene.
CLEAN AIR Members of a House and Senate conference are nearing completion on compromise clean air legislation, which would be the first major rewrite of the federal air pollution law in 13 years. The conferees tentatively approved provisions Sunday to sharply reduce pollution that causes acid rain, the last major section of the 700-page bill. Earlier the conferees tentatively agreed on new auto emission requirements to curtail urban smog and on reductions in toxic chemical pollution by industry. Several minor issues remained to be worked out by the conferees. The compromise package also still would have to be approved in both the House and Senate.
CHILD CARE Senate leaders and the Bush administration have reached agreement on the broad outlines of legislation providing assistance for low-income families. But major differences with the House remain an obstacle to passage. The latest Senate version is a five-year, $15 billion package. Most of the money would go for an expansion of earned income tax credits for low-income working families with children.
ASSAULT WEAPONS The Senate has approved an omnibus anti-crime bill that would ban the sale of nine semiautomatic assault weapons. But the House version contains no such provision. Instead, the House may vote on a bill to outlaw ownership or sale of semiautomatics the Treasury Department deemed not suitable for sporting purposes. The politically influential National Rifle Association opposes both bills and House sponsors are clearly nervous over whether their measure could survive on the floor at this stage.
FARM BILL A compromise $40.8 billion farm bill covering government agriculture programs for the next five years awaits final passage by both the House and Senate. The bill would slash farm spending by $13.5 billion over the next five years, as part of a larger deficit-reduction package.
US-EGYPTIAN AID Forgiveness of $6.7 billion in past military debt Egypt owes the United States is part of a $15.5 billion foreign aid bill pending in the Senate. The move is badly wanted by President Bush as a reward for the country that has led Arab support for the multinational military deployment in the Persian Gulf crisis. But Bush faces a difficult choice over whether to veto the bill because it includes a sharp cut in El Salvador's military aid that the administration strongly opposes.
KEATING INVESTIGATION The Senate Ethics Committee is pressing ahead with its investigation of senators who assisted Charles H. Keating Jr. as his Lincoln Savings and Loan was sinking toward collapse.
CIVIL RIGHTS The White house says Bush will veto the Civil Rights Act of 1990, which is aimed at overturning the effects of recent Supreme Court decisions reversing some affirmative action programs. A veto override attempt could take place in Congress once Bush has acted.

DOC.HEAD: Church Leader Lauds Cut In U.S. Military Aid To El Salvador
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic Church leader on Sunday praised U.S. lawmakers' decision to cut military aid to El Salvador, saying the reduction could help force both sides to end the country's civil war. The action on a foreign aid bill ``reflects the awareness that many things are not going well here and should change, so that the peace process can end this conflict and establish new bases for a society in which human dignity is genuinely respected,'' Auxiliary Bishop Gregorio Rosa Chavez said. ``Peace cannot be built with weapons,'' he told a news conference after the Sunday homily, which the influential Salvadoran church frequently uses as a platform to speak out against human rights abuses and put forth its vision of how to end the decade-old civil war. The Senate on Friday approved an amendment to halve the $85 million in military aid to El Salvador the U.S. had budgeted for the 1991 fiscal year. A similar version of the amendment was tacked onto a House version of the aid bill. Both bills contain a provision that would restore the aid if the rebels pull out of the negotiations, or if they launch a major offensive. Another provision would eliminate military aid altogether if the government breaks off the talks. Rosa Chavez said the Senate vote would ``give more viability to the peace process.'' So far, all the peace negotiating sessions since President Alfredo Cristiani took office in June 1989 have ended in deadlock. The next meeting between representatives of the two sides and a U.N. mediator is to begin Nov. 4 in Mexico. The government has been demanding that the guerrillas stop fighting and participate in the country's political life. Leaders of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front rebel organization want a political agreement on a number of reforms, including prosecution of officers responsible for atrocities, before agreeing to a cease-fire. Many of the war's 73,000 victims have been civilians suspected of leftist sympathies, slain by rightist death squads or the military. Congress was probably moved to act by the assassination last November of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter. Soldiers have confessed that they shot the priests on the orders of an army commander. The House and Senate bills will have to be reconciled in House-Senate conference, but the provisions are expected to be in the final version sent to President Bush.

DOC.HEAD: 1933 Packard Model 1006 Dietrich Sold for $745,000
DOC.TEXT: A 1933 Packard Model Custom Dietrich fetched the top bid of $745,000 at an automobile auction Saturday that drew more than 10,000 spectators. The intense bidding on two exclusive car collections owned by Marshall businessman Gene Ponder and the late oilman Samuel F. Vaughan III was the talk of this east Texas town, located about 156 miles east of Dallas. Vaughan was killed in an Oct. 6 airplane crash at the Uncertain airstrip.
