Ponder's collection of MGs was recognized as the largest collection in the U.S. and the second largest in the world. Nearly 160 classic automobiles crossed the auction block during the 12-hour event Saturday. The buyer of the 1933 Packard was from Philadelphia but his identity was not disclosed. Among the top sellers were a 1930 Duesenberg Model J-225 Walker La Grande Torpedo Phaeton, which sold for $722,500, a 1932 Duesenberg Model J-490 Derham tourister, which sold for $450,000, and a 1929 Duesenberg Model J-350 Willoughby, which went for $360,000. The weekend auction also attracted more than 600 bidders from the United States, Switzerland, Germany, Holland, Japan, Columbia, Canada, France, England and Sweden.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Says Sanctions Better Than Bloodshed
DOC.TEXT: Prince Sultan, the Saudi defense minister, said Sunday he was troubled by the suffering that trade sanctions were causing Iraqis, but convinced that was a far better thing than war. ``It causes us deep pain to see the Iraqi or any other nation facing a worldwide trade embargo,'' the prince said to Saudi newspaper editors. ``But the premise for the embargo is peace, not war. Perhaps it is meant to spare the shedding of Iraqi blood.'' Prince Sultan, third in the Saudi leadership after King Fahd and Crown Prince Abdullah, said the foreign forces amassed following the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait ``brought an umbrella of peace.'' Any solution to the conflict must include an unconditional Iraqi pullout and the restoration of the al-Sabah monarchy in Kuwait, Sultan said. He denied any plans to form an Arab-Western security alliance in the region. ``It is not acceptable that an Arab country enters into an alliance with a non-Arab foreign power,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Warbler Arrested for Singing Alone at Mass
DOC.TEXT: A church songbird ordered by a judge to sing with the rest of the flock or not at all was arrested during Mass on Sunday for singing from her own repertoire of hymns. Elojia Macias was taken to the Bexar County Jail, and later was freed on $400 bail. She was arrested after trying to enter the altar area at Our Lady of Sorrows Catholic Church, as a morning Mass began, said Father Alexander Wangler. She sang her own songs in the sacristy as church officials waited for police to arrive. In a lawsuit last week, Wangler accused Ms. Macias of disrupting church services by singing her own songs, causing ``confusion and disruption.'' State District Judge John Specia issued an injunction Thursday ordering Ms. Macias to cooperate or risk being held in contempt of court. ``We've been arguing with her for months and months,'' Wangler said Sunday. ``She just wants to do it that way,'' he said. ``Friends and neighbors have talked to her ... she needs help.''

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Slaughter Aoun Aide And Family
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last 7 grafs, bgng `Chamoun inherited ...' with 13 grafs to ADD background on Chamoun's career. No Pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BEI1-3
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen burst into the home of a top supporter of Christian Gen. Michel Aoun Sunday and shot him, his wife and two sons to death, police said. Only an 11-month-old girl survived. The daybreak massacre of Dany Chamoun and his family in their suburban Beirut apartment came a week after a Syrian and Lebanese government troops crushed Aoun's mutiny in Lebanon's Christian enclave. Chamoun, a Maronite Catholic and the son of late President Camille Chamoun, was one of the most outspoken critics of President Elias Hrawi and Syria's military presence in Lebanon. He also was at odds with Christian warlord Samir Geagea, whose Lebanese Forces militia fought a four-month war with Aoun's troops early this year for mastery of the Christian areas of east Beirut. No group immediately claimed responsibility for the slayings, which were branded by Christian and Moslem leaders alike as an attempt to block a plan to end the 15-year-old civil war. Aoun took refuge a week ago in the French Embassy. France has granted him asylum, but the Lebanese government insists he stay and stand trial for alleged crimes, including the theft of $75 million from the state treasury. Five uniformed gunmen, using silencer-equipped 9mm pistols, riddled Chamoun, 56; his wife, Ingrid Abdel-Noor, 35, and their sons, Tarek, 7, and Julien, 5, with bullets, according to police. They said the 5-year-old was taken to a nearby hospital and died a short time later. Of the family, only Chamoun's daughter, Tamara, escaped unharmed. Reporters saw the baby being cradled by her weeping Lebanese governess at the apartment in Baabda, east of Beirut. ``I am shocked by the horrific slayings,'' Hrawi was quoted by several Beirut radio stations as saying. ``That's a crime against the state aimed at sabotaging efforts to reunite the country and army after Aoun's ouster.'' Radios said Hrawi made the comment in Damascus, where he is talking with Syrian President Hafez Assad on how to enforce an Arab League-brokered plan aimed at ending the civil war between Moslems and Christians. ``We have declared that the peace process is open to all to join after the end of Aoun's mutiny and that we should bury the past and begin a new era of fraternity,'' Hrawi was quoted as saying. ``Today's crime is a stab in the back.'' In Paris, Foreign Minister Roland Dumas expressed horror at the slayings. ``Dany Chamoun had opened a perspective toward reconciliation in Lebanon,'' Dumas said. ``It's this chance they wanted to assassinate.'' Guards had been assigned to protect the Chamoun family around the clock. The assailants arrived at 6 a.m., as the guards were changing shifts, police said. ``The assailants snuck in at the moment of change and forced the janitor at gunpoint to climb five flights of stairs to Chamoun's apartment,'' said a police spokesman. The governess answered a knock at the door and the assailants burst in firing, instantly killing Chamoun and his wife, police said. ``The gunmen then shot the two sleeping sons in bed in an adjacent bedroom,'' said the spokesman, who could not be named under regulations. The governess, who was uninjured, gave police an account of the attack. A family maid was also uninjured. Chamoun's hunting dog was found whimpering over the bodies when rescuers arrived. The British-educated Chamoun made his political debut soon after the outbreak of Lebanon's civil war in 1975. He was appointed secretary of defense of his father's rightist Christian National Liberal Party and commander of the party's ``Tigers'' militia. Chamoun forged friendships with Druse warlord Walid Jumblatt and Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat's security chief, Ali Hassan Salameh, who was assassinated in Moslem west Beirut in 1979. These friendships helped free scores of kidnap victims in Beirut's Moslem and Christian sectors during the conflict. Chamoun - who loved hunting, sports cars and scuba-diving - often advocated diplomacy over the gunbarrel. ``Politics sucked him in although he hated politics,'' said his former aide, Rudolf Paulikevitch. Chamoun inherited the leadership of the Christian National Liberal Party upon the 1987 death of his father, who ruled Lebanon from 1952 to 1958. Chamoun sought the presidency in 1988, but the Parliament was unable to meet to elect a successor and Aoun, who then was army commander, was named prime minister of a caretaker military Cabinet. Hrawi was elected as the new president on Nov. 24, 1989, but Aoun rejected the election, and called Hrawi a ``Syrian puppet.'' Aoun contended that his three-man Cabinet remained the only legitimate authority in the country. Hrawi, Aoun and Chamoun are Maronites, the largest Christian sect and the dominant power in Lebanon since it gained independence from France in 1943. The Syrian army entered the country in 1976 under an Arab League mandate to smother the civil war, now in its 16th year. The Syrians currently maintain 40,000 troops controlling more than 70 percent of Lebanon's territory. Chamoun was dismayed when Aoun fled his command headquarters in the presidential palace in Baabda minutes after the air-supported attack of Hrawi's troops and the Syrian army began Oct 13. ``I can't believe the general has done this to us,'' Chamoun said the next day. ``May God help us.'' Chamoun's first wife, Patti Morgan, an Australian-born former fashion model, lives in London with their daughter Tracy, 30, family friends said.

DOC.HEAD: Ice Cream Magnate Dies at 84
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details.
DOC.TEXT: Tom Carvel, the founder of the Carvel chain of 700 ice-cream stores who was widely known for his gravel-voice pitches for his product in TV and radio commercials, died Sunday at his home. He was 84. Carvel sold the Carvel Corp. chain for more than $80 million last year. He died about 1:30 p.m. at his home in Pine Plains, a rural community about 100 miles north of New York City, said Jim Winkle of Riverdale Funeral Home in New York. The cause of death was not given. Dutchess County Sheriff Frederick Scoralick said Carvel's doctor told him Carvel had a history of heart problems. Carvel, who founded Carvel Corp. in 1938, sold his 99 percent share to an investment bank, Investcorp, in November 1989. Based on annual sales, Carvel is the third-largest ice cream store chain in the country after Dairy Queen and Haagen-Dazs. Based in Yonkers, Carvel has more than 700 stores, most of them in New York, Florida, Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Jersey and other East Coast states. The company also owned Nedick's hot dogs and Dugan's bakery products. Carvel was to stay on as a consultant, but stopped making the commercials promoting Fudgie the Whale and Cookie Puss ice cream cakes, Flying Saucers ice cream sandwiches and Thinny Thin dietary frozen dessert. Carvel, who also had a home in Ardsley, was spending the weekend in Pine Plains, where he owned a golf course and was planning a 700-acre residential development. Plans for the project were stalled last year. Born in Greece, on July 14, 1906, Carvel's family emigrated to the United States when he was 4 years old and settled in New York City. In the 1920s, Carvel played drums in a Dixieland band, worked as an auto mechanic and drove an ice-cream truck before opening his first ice-cream store in Hartsdale in Westchester County. In the mid-1920s, Carvel developed the first machine for making soft ice cream, and later sold the machine to store owners. In 1955, he did the first of his many ads in which he appealed to the public in his raspy voice to ``please visit your local Carvel store.'' He is survived by his wife, Agnes. They had no children, Winkle said. Funeral arrangments were pending, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Communists, Military Rebels Form Alliance
DOC.TEXT: Military rebels claim they are forming links with Communists and other disaffected groups and planning a ``big bang'' to oust President Corazon Aquino before her term ends in 1992. Renegade Maj. Abraham Purugganan made the claim during a clandestine interview with Filipino reporters last Saturday. By agreement of the reporters, the interview was made public Monday. Purugganan, sought by the government for his role in a coup attempt last December, said a new coalition, the Democratic Front for Filipinism, would seek to launch a ``nationalist revolution'' to oust Mrs. Aquino and establish a federal system of government with a unicameral legislature. The Philippines currently has a centralized system of government with a bicameral assembly. ``Definitely we will be moving fast before 1992,'' Purugganan said. ``We will just have one big bang.'' Purugganan said the alliance was formed Oct. 17 during a secret conclave, in which a civilian with the pseudonym Felix Servando was named chairman. The alliance includes the Young Officers Union, a military faction linked to the December coup attempt, and members of various Communist organizations. Mrs. Aquino has survived seven military revolts since she took power in the February 1986 ``people power revolution'' that toppled the late President Ferdinand Marcos. In the most recent attempt, military rebels led by Col. Alexander Noble seized military camps in two cities on the southernmost island of Mindanao on Oct. 4 but surrendered two days later. Purugganan described Noble's move as a tactical blunder, but said it did not invalidate the rebel strategy of seeking to promote a series of uprisings that would inspire civilian support for the rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting to correct to 2nd Ld-Writethru
Wildfire Burns In California Forest; Ebbing Winds Give Firefighters Hope
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with fire's range reduced to 500 acres. Picks up 5th graf, `Blustery Santa ...'
DOC.TEXT: A fierce wind early Sunday spread a 500-acre wildfire through parts of the San Bernardino National Forest, but firefighters began to gain on the blaze later in the day when the wind ebbed. The fire, which began Saturday night, burned through brush and timber in the western part of the forest, said Hal Seyden of the U.S. Forest Service. The cause of the blaze, in an area ravaged by fire two years ago, was unknown. Two firefighters suffered minor injuries and a house caught fire in the Simi Valley, Seyden said. The blaze began in rugged Lytle Creek Canyon and burned up 5,000-foot San Sevine Ridge, he said. Officials initially estimated that the fire had spread over as much as 2,000 acres but later downgraded that figure to 500 acres, said Bill Rolls of the U.S. Forest Service. Blustery Santa Ana winds up to 50 mph roared through the mountain canyons, pushing the fire through hundreds of acres overnight and grounding aircraft, forcing crews to chop fire lines by hand. By afternoon the winds had dropped and were helping contain the fire by pushing the fire back on itself. Earlier, water-dropping helicopters and air tankers carrying fire-retardant were aloft on bombardment missions. The blaze halted its sluggish southern advance toward the towns of Rialto, Fontana and Rancho Cucamonga. Thick smoke from the blaze 60 miles northeast of downtown Los Angeles could be seen on the beach in Santa Monica. Ash fell over parts of Fontana, some 10 miles south of the fire line. Late Sunday, about 500 firefighters worked the fire's northern edge, which was feeding on heavy, drought-stricken brush and timber. Dirt roads rutted by recent rains were being widened and graded to help firefighters, who worked mostly by hand, said Mary Bowman of the Forest Service. ``We have a lot of archaeological finds, and they don't want to put the bulldozers up there unless they have to,'' Bowman said. ``You see pottery shards, arrowheads, stuff like that. We want to be careful.'' The fire was burning partially in an area destroyed by a September and October 1988 fire that burned 5,160 acres of national forest land.

DOC.HEAD: Government-Backed Candidate Wins in Runoff
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of Greece's second-largest city narrowly won re-election Sunday in a runoff vote, marking a gain for the ruling conservative party. Salonica Mayor Constantine Cosmopoulos received slightly more than 50 percent of the vote to beat Dimitris Fatouros, jointly supported by socialists and communists. Cosmopoulos' victory gave Premier Constantine Mitsotakis' conservative New Democracy party control of the nation's two largest cities and more more than 90 other mayoral seats in smaller communities. The Athens election was settled in the first round of voting last Sunday. Conservative-backed Antonis Tritsis defeated actress-turned-politician Melina Mercouri by 50.15 percent to 45.78 percent. Ms. Mercouri is a Parliament member for the Panhellenic Socialist Movement, the largest opposition group. The two-stage mayoral and council elections were seen as a referendum on the government's austerity measures, taken to reduce the national debt and ease other economic woes. Socialist and communist-backed candidates secured 116 mayoral posts in the first round of balloting. Independents scored seven victories. Official results are not expected before Monday from most of the 143 municipalities holding runoff elections Sunday. In the third-biggest city, the port of Piraeus, first-round elections were won by Stelios Logothetis, the joint candidate of the socialists and the communist-dominated Coalition of the Left and Progress. After taking office in April, Mitsotakis implemented economic reform measures that include abolition of inflation-linked salaries in 1991 and proposals to sell many ailing state industries. Greece, a member of the 12-nation European Community, has an inflation rate of about 22 percent and a public debt officially estimated at $100 billion. The government's belt-tightening measures provoked many strikes, including five 24-hour general strikes last month. The newly elected mayors and local officials take office January 1.

DOC.HEAD: Former British Prime Minister Meets with Saddam
DOC.TEXT: Former British Prime Minister Edward Heath said Sunday he had won agreement from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein for the release of sick and elderly British hostages. During a three-hour meeting, Saddam agreed to release an unspecified number of Britons, Heath said, adding he did not know exactly how many would be released. They were to fly out of Baghdad on Tuesday, Heath said. ``At this moment, his staff and mine are discussing lists of names of possible people who will return to Britain, so therefore I can't tell you or anybody else of particular names,'' Heath said. When he flew to Baghdad on Saturday, the 74-year-old ex-premier said he was on a private mission to win release of 53 British hostages identified as ailing or elderly. He met with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz Saturday. Asked about the rest of the estimated 1,400 Britons who are trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, Heath said, ``I don't think progress will be made there until there is a removal of fear of lightning attack by the Americans or anybody else, particularly the Americans.'' Thousands of Westerners are being held in Iraq at strategic locations to deter a possible attack by the U.S.-led multinational forces. Heath said Saddam placed ``very considerable'' emphasis on diplomatic action in the crisis in order to achieve a stable Middle East. Saddam ``recognizes its intense danger and the disastrous effect warfare could have on the whole region, and the crisis can have on the world economy,'' Heath said. Heath's trip has drawn fire in Britain, where the government has refused negotiations with Saddam as long as he holds Westerners hostage. ``Every hint that the West is prepared somehow to do deals or to move away from unconditional and immediate withdrawal is succor to Baghdad,'' said David Howell, a conservative member of Parliament and chairman of the Foreign Affairs Select Committee. But Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, also speaking on BBC radio Sunday, said if Heath succeeds in getting hostages freed ``I think everybody would be glad.'' ``He's made it clear his mission is humanitarian, that he's not speaking or negotiating or acting on behalf of the government,'' Hurd said.

DOC.HEAD: County Call to Ban Cheap Liquor Goes Unheeded
DOC.TEXT: Skid Row liquor stores have thwarted a year-old effort to curb sales of cheap, potent wine favored by street drunks. Los Angeles County Supervisor Ed Edelman proposed in September 1989 that winemakers voluntarily stop selling such wines on Skid Row to combat alcoholism. But many liquor store owners said the idea was a waste of time. ``They'd just drink something else,'' said Jack Simone, owner of Jack's Market. ``All this hullabaloo about alcohol being the menace, when it is really crack (cocaine).'' A pint bottle of the wine sells for around $1.75 and is 18 percent alcohol. E.&J. Gallo Winery of California and Canandaigua Wine Co. of New York, two of the nation's largest producers of cheap wines, agreed to halt sales to Skid Rows around the country. The voluntary ban in Los Angeles was based on a similar program in San Francisco's Tenderloin district. ``The ban has been a complete joke,'' said Mike Neely, director of the Homeless Outreach Project. ``The price went up. That's about all that happened.'' A consulting company found that, in Los Angeles County at least, ``the overall availability of fortified wines in general does not appear to have changed substantially.'' Many stores apparently stockpiled the wine anticipating the ban, said Virginia McLain Rusk of the Ernst & Young. Edelman said he favors a mandatory ban if the voluntary effort fails, but Neely said the best way to fight Skid Row alcoholism is to provide more counseling and treatment programs. ``Banning alcohol is not the solution,'' said Neely. ``They tried that during Prohibition. What makes them think it will work in the 1990s?''

DOC.HEAD: Radicals Firebomb Main Intelligence Office
DOC.TEXT: Radical students firebombed the main office of a police intelligence agency in central Seoul Monday and scattered leaflets demanding the government stop spying on dissidents. Police arrested eight of the protesters, who were also demanding the ouster of President Roh Tae-woo. The students hurled about 20 firebombs on the office of the Agency for National Security Planning. The initial reports did not say if the attack caused any major damage to the office in central Seoul. Police said a firebomb exploded at an adjacent police station, burning a motorcycle. Government intelligence offices have been the target of protests by dissidents and radical students since a spy scandal involving a military intelligence unit surfaced early this month. Roh fired the defense minister and head of the military's Defense Security Command amid revelations that officials had spied illegally on more than 1,300 dissidents, intellectuals and opposition legislators. In a speech commemorating Police Day, Roh on Monday urged police to crack down on social unrest and crime.

DOC.HEAD: Fans Greet Champion Cincinnati Reds
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of screaming fans met the Cincinnati Reds' chartered jet Sunday night as the World Series champions returned home after completing one of the biggest upsets in baseball history. At least 500 people gathered at Greater Cincinnati International Airport and cheered wildly as the door of the plane opened and the team descended. ``It's stirring. It's just overwhelming for all these people to be out here at this hour of the night,'' Reds owner Marge Schott said after emerging from the plane to cheers of ``Marge! Marge! Marge!'' and ``Sweep! Sweep! Sweep!'' ``They're great fans. I love them,'' she said. The Reds rallied past the heavily fancied Oakland Athletics by 2-1 on Saturday night, winning the World Series in four quick games. Pitcher Jose Rijo, who won Games 1 and 4 and earned the Series MVP award, said he looks forward to repeating. ``Next year, we've got to win it again,'' Rijo said. ``This is too much fun.'' The city of Cincinnati and the Downtown Council are sponsoring a parade on Monday along a six-block downtown route, followed by a rally. On Saturday night, raucous fans honked horns, exchanged hugs and high-fives, and tipped over plastic roadway construction barrels in downtown Cincinnati. Police estimated the crowd at about 10,000.

DOC.HEAD: Colombia Pledges New Incentives for Foreign Oil Companies
DOC.TEXT: The Colombian government plans to increase incentives for petroleum and gas exploration by foreign companies, President Cesar Gaviria said. ``The government will begin a rapid evaluation of the changes necessary ... to make exploration of inactive areas more attractive,'' Gaviria said Saturday while inaugurating a new gas pipeline in central Colombia. Gaviria did not specify what types of changes the government was considering. The president's comments were reported Sunday by local news media. Current government contracts assign oil exploration to several multinational companies operating in Colombia. If petroleum deposites are discovered, the government and the foreign companies share the cost of developing them. Colombia receives 60 percent of the petroleum produced while the foreign companies take the remaining 40 percent and pay taxes on their earnings. The companies are pushing for a better deal because of the high risks involved in searching for petroleum in Colombia. One of the country's leftist guerrilla groups, the National Liberation Army, or ELN, has repeatedly sabotaged oil facilities and kidnapped employees of foreign petroleum companies. Gaviria said Saturday that the rebels should abandon the campaign and participae in next year's assembly to rewrite Colombia's constitution and reform its democracy. Attacks by the rebels on petroleum facilities have caused $520 million in losses and have produced a steep drop in exploration activity, according to the state oil company Ecopetrol. Of the 450,000 barrels of oil produced each day in Colombia, 220,000 barrels are exported. Petroleum, Colombia's leading export, is expected to earn it more than 1.5 billion dollars in foreign exchange this year.
